articles.title: Neighbors concerned after SWAT team called to Gwinnett County home
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A SWAT team was called to a home in Gwinnett County on Saturday, according to Lawrenceville police.

Law enforcement agencies were outside the house in the 300 block of Dixie Court for several hours. Police said the situation was domestic in nature, with a man refusing to come out of the home.

“We were not clear if the female party was being held against her will,” the department said.

The man was eventually arrested, and the woman was unharmed, according to police. Telemundo Atlanta, WANF’s sister station, captured video of what appeared to be a man surrendering to police.

Destiny Ponder, who lives next door, said police were urging neighbors to leave their houses.

“This is our first time seeing anything like this,” she said. “I’m so glad that they didn’t have to use any gunfire or any firearms or anything like that.”

Naliyah Huger said she was visiting her grandmother, who is another neighbor, when the incident happened. Police were throwing smoke bombs and telling the man to surrender, she said.

According to Huger, the woman walked out of the home with her two children before the man was arrested.

“Honestly, I feared for the woman and her kids,” she said. “It would’ve been real tragic for them to fire, and the kids were in there, and she was in there. It was just a bad predicament.”

This is a developing story. Check back with Atlanta News First for updates.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: 21-year-old woman shot and killed with toddler in the car in northwest Atlanta, police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A 21-year-old woman was shot and killed Saturday morning in northwest Atlanta, according to police.

Near 2 a.m., police were called to the 1400 block of Hollywood Road, where they found the woman with a gunshot wound inside a car. She died at the scene.

Two people were in the car with the woman — the driver, who called 911, and the woman’s 2-year-old child, police said.

While investigating, police learned that the shooting happened around the corner on Center Street near an apartment complex. Surveillance video shows three men open fire on the car, according to Homicide Commander Lt. Andrew Smith.

Smith said the shooting appears to be targeted. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers by calling 404-577-8477 (TIPS).

A woman who lives nearby said she is tired of the crime in the area.

“I’m just coming home from work. I’m tired of this. This is nerve-wracking,” the woman, who did not want to be identified out of fear of retaliation, said. “At what point is anybody gonna take attention to the fact that this is a property with how many children?”

This is a developing story. Check back with Atlanta News First as we learn more.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: President Biden arrives in Atlanta ahead of campaign event, Morehouse commencement speech
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - President Joe Biden arrived in Atlanta on Saturday afternoon ahead of his scheduled commencement speech at Morehouse College.

Air Force One touched down at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport at around 12:30 p.m. Several politicians, including Senators Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff, Mayor Andre Dickens, Rep. Nikema Williams, Fulton County Commission Chairman Robb Pitts and more, greeted Biden on the tarmac before he left in a motorcade.

Biden will attend an event for Black voters before delivering the speech at Morehouse Sunday morning, according to his campaign team.

“We are not, and will not, parachute into these communities at the last minute, expecting their vote,” Trey Baker, senior advisor for the Biden-Harris campaign, said in a statement. “Every day, from now until election day, we will continue working diligently to ensure that come November, Black voters send Joe Biden and Kamala Harris back to the White House to continue delivering for Black America in unprecedented ways.”

WATCH BIDEN’S FULL LANDING:

Morehouse faculty voted to give Biden an honorary degree before his commencement speech. Several people who met him on the tarmac, including Warnock, are Morehouse alumni.

But Biden’s upcoming appearance isn’t without controversy. On May 8, several students from historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) gathered at Morehouse, a nationally acclaimed HBCU, to protest his speech.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE: Morehouse students protest ahead of President Biden’s commencement speech

The protestors said they disagree with Biden’s support of Israel in the ongoing Israel-Hamas war.

“While I understand why some of the older alumni might be excited by the amount of opportunity and press that this would bring to the institution, the general feeling on the ground is we don’t want him here,” a Morehouse student told Atlanta News First. “It’s very obvious that we are being used to score political points and try to get more Black votes.”

The New Georgia Project Action Fund, an organization dedicated to increasing civic participation in minority groups, said it appreciates Biden’s visit. But Keron Blair, the nonprofit’s organizing and field officer, said Biden must give Black voters — especially Black men — reasons to vote for him.

“As an HBCU graduate, a Black man, a Georgia voter, and someone who talks to Black Georgians every day, I’ll be watching the president’s speech closely,” Blair said in a statement. “He’s got five months to show us that he takes us seriously, and we will be watching with sample ballots in hand.”

Biden’s visit marks the president’s first appearance in Atlanta since his March campaign rally. He also agreed to a debate with former President Donald Trump in Atlanta on June 27, which will air live on CNN.

articles.title: Georgia Republicans choose Amy Kremer, organizer of pro-Trump Jan. 6 rally, for seat on the RNC
articles.content:
(AP) - Georgia Republicans on Saturday elected to the Republican National Committee a conservative activist who helped organize the Jan. 6, 2021, pro-Trump rally that led to a mob storming the U.S. Capitol.

Delegates at the convention in Columbus rendered a split decision, choosing Amy Kremer for one of the two RNC seats, but retaining incumbent Committeeman Jason Thompson.

Kremer and other challengers argued that Thompson and Ginger Howard, the other incumbent, hadn’t done enough to support Donald Trump. They pointed out the continued desire of party activists for confrontation with internal and external enemies, even as many in leadership tried to preach unity and ease divisions that have left Republican Gov. Brian Kemp estranged from the party organization.

“We need somebody willing to stand up and fight,” Kremer told delegates. “If you want the grassroots to have a voice, then you need to vote for change.”

Kremer, who got her political start in the Tea Party movement, wasn’t part of the mob that stormed the Capitol as Congress met to certify Democrat Joe Biden’s election win. But it was her group that secured the permit for the “Save America” rally where Trump told the crowd to " fight like hell.” She spoke at the event and was among the most active fundraisers in the “Stop the Steal” movement advancing the lie that Biden’s victory was stolen.

Leaders of the party had recommended against electing Kremer, noting among other issues that she and an affiliated group have unpaid Federal Election Commission fines.

Delegates reelected Thompson despite attacks saying his wife and daughter worked for Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, the Republican chief election official who defended the 2020 election result in Georgia that saw Biden capture the state’s 16 electoral votes. Raffensperger was repeatedly likened to the devil during the weekend convention.

Thompson fell short of a majority in an initial three-candidate race but won in a runoff.

“Together we will fight the forces that seek to destroy America,” Thompson told delegates. “Together we will win the state of Georgia for President Trump.”

Most speakers called on Republicans to put their internal divisions behind them, including U.S. Rep Marjorie Taylor Greene, an unlikely messenger of GOP unity.

Greene, who earned rebukes from other Republicans during her failed attempt to oust U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson, told attendees at a party breakfast Saturday that “there’s nothing wrong with a little bit of arguing in the Republican Party” but those divisions should stop now.

“If we’re too fractured, we can’t work together to hit that home run in November,” Greene said. “And that’s going to be a problem. If we’re too off in different directions, and not working together, we cannot hit that home run in November.”

Greene, though, was speaking at a convention that was once again skipped by Gov. Brian Kemp, who created a rival fundraising and political operation after Trump attacked him for backing the 2020 election results. The fracture deepened when some party leaders supported former U.S. Sen. David Perdue’s unsuccessful, Trump-backed challenge to Kemp in 2022.

There were some signs of unity. Two Kemp allies, Insurance Commissioner John King and state Rep. Tim Fleming, Kemp’s 2018 campaign manager, both spoke to the convention. So did a larger number of state lawmakers than last year. Party Chairman Josh McKoon, a former state senator, said that was part of his attempt fuse the party back together.

“That’s another thing we’ve been working on, is our relationship with elected officials and kind of bringing everybody back to the table,” McKoon said.

Republicans repeatedly said they believe inflation and immigration are the issues that will allow them to win over people who didn’t vote in 2020 or who voted for Biden. Georgia Labor Commissioner Bruce Thompson brandished his wallet during a Friday speech to tell delegates how to reach undecided voters.

“Don’t pound them over abortion, don’t pound over things that maybe aren’t relevant,” Thompson said. “Pound them over what really matters, which is right here. This is relevant to every single American. It’s their pocketbook.”

Copyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Amy Kremer helped organize the pro-Trump Jan. 6 rally. Now she is seeking a Georgia seat on the RNC
articles.content:
(AP) - Amy Kremer stood near the White House on Jan. 6, 2021, and told thousands of Donald Trump’s supporters that the 2020 presidential election was fraudulent.

“Hello, deplorables,” she said, embracing a label Hillary Clinton once lobbed against Trump’s followers.

Kremer, a conservative activist from suburban Atlanta, wasn’t part of the mob that hours later stormed the Capitol as Congress met to certify Democrat Joe Biden as Trump’s successor. But it was Kremer’s group that secured the permit for the “Save America” rally where Trump told the crowd to “fight like hell,” and she was among the most active fundraisers in the “Stop the Steal” movement advancing the lie that Biden’s victory was stolen.

As Trump seeks a return to the White House, Kremer is trying to win one of two Georgia seats on the Republican National Committee. The votes at a state party convention Saturday are expected to show how consumed by the 2020 election the GOP remains in Georgia and everywhere else.

Kremer argues the RNC hasn’t done enough to fight for Trump or protect others who fought for him, like the 16 Georgia Republicans who falsely claimed to be valid Trump electors in a state Joe Biden won.

“It’s not enough to just espouse conservatism anymore,” Kremer told a party group on April 24. “We have to stand up and fight. And the RNC has not done it.”

But like many other state parties, Georgia’s GOP has splintered. Gov. Brian Kemp created a rival fundraising and political operation after Trump attacked him for backing the 2020 election results. The fracture deepened when some party leaders supported former U.S. Sen. David Perdue’s unsuccessful, Trump-backed challenge to Kemp in 2022. Neither Kemp nor his allies will attend the convention.

Some Kemp supporters disdain the state party as irrelevant, saying Republican elected officials better reflect the views of all Georgia Republicans. But the party remains a training ground for future candidates, Kemp will only be governor until January 2027 and Georgia’s majority-Republican legislature continues to translate activist demands into law.

“You can’t dismiss it,” said Jason Shepherd, a former GOP chairman in suburban Atlanta’s Cobb County who has exited state party affairs because of his disagreements with Trump supporters.

State convention delegates will choose one man and one woman to the national party’s governing body on Saturday in Columbus. It’s not as if the incumbents seeking reelection are Trump critics. Jason Thompson and Ginger Howard trumpet their allegiances. Thompson, an attorney, was among the lawyers who helped Trump ask courts for recounts and favorable treatment after Election Day in 2020.

Thompson and Howard are both calling for the national party to repay the state party more than $1.5 million it has spent defending the 16 fake Trump electors. Three have been indicted by Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, while others reached immunity deals to testify for prosecutors.

READ OUR FULL COVERAGE OF THE TRUMP INDICTMENT

But they also warn that Georgia Republicans need experienced leaders who can obtain resources to win the November election in a battleground where wins by Biden and two Democratic U.S. senators have shaken a generation of Republican control.

“There’s more to the RNC than just the election integrity part,” Thompson said April 24. “Obviously, I think that’s the most important part, especially right now. But you also have to have somebody that can raise money.”

Howard is under fire, basically, for being insufficiently confrontational.

“Don’t mistake my sweetness for weakness. I’m a fighter,” Howard said.

Josh McKoon, a former lawmaker elected last year as chair, has tried to dampen some conflicts. He explicitly endorsed Howard at the April 24 meeting, saying she’s doing an “excellent job.”

Thompson is being attacked by opponents for work done by his wife and daughter for Republican Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, who is despised by Trump and party activists for his defense of Georgia’s 2020 results.

“It’s the appearance of being associated with the devil himself and that’s Brad Raffensperger,” one activist told Thompson last month.

Thompson says neither his wife nor daughter have anything to do with how Raffensperger runs elections, calling it “ridiculousness” to imply his family benefits from Georgia’s use of Dominion Voting Systems ballot-marking devices. Many Republicans demand Georgia use ballots marked and counted by hand, citing distrust of machines fanned by conservatives.

Thompson’s challengers include party Second Vice-Chairman David Cross and Jason Frazier, who was denied a Republican place on Fulton County’s election board because Frazier has challenged the eligibility of thousands of voters.

Cross is among a group of anti-establishment officers elected last year. Cross supported retaining First Vice-Chairman Brian K. Pritchard, who was removed on May 10 by the state Republican Committee after a judge found Pritchard voted illegally nine times. Many Republicans viewed the findings as undercutting their arguments that the state must prevent fraudulent voting.

Cross argues the current leaders aren’t representing what Republicans want, saying pro-Trump forces need to complete their takeover.

“One of the major issues that we need to be dealing right now is grassroots engagement,” Cross told party members Monday in Forsyth County, a Republican stronghold north of Atlanta. “There are a lot of people out there who are severely demoralized.”

Frazier argues his experience scrutinizing voter rolls is an asset the RNC needs. Even as the party has been slow to invest in voter outreach, it has pledged a 100,000-person election-integrity program. Thompson claims partial credit, promising there will be lawyers “everywhere” to challenge Democrats, but Frazier says it’s not enough.

“Election integrity needs to be one of the top, if not the top, issue if we’re going to win in future elections,” Frazier said April 24. “It has not been a top priority in the past. It has to be.”

Besides Kremer, Shawn Cross is also challenging Howard. The wife of David Cross said Monday that her lack of experience is a strength.

“It takes more people to stand up and not just vote. Voting is not enough,” Shawn Cross said. “The system is rigged, we all know it’s rigged.”

It’s that sense of grievance and desire for confrontation that all the challengers are counting on.

“We never went to the Capitol,” Kremer said on April 24. “We didn’t tell people to go to the Capitol. But the thing was, the people wanted to do something. So people marched to the Capitol. And we all know what’s happened since then. The federal government has been weaponized against us.”

articles.title: Suspect dead in shooting involving officers at busy gas station, Cobb County police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Authorities are investigating after a traffic stop near a Cobb County convenience store and gas station turned deadly Friday afternoon.

According to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI), an officer saw a box truck with a stolen license plate at around 2:40 p.m. in the area of Mableton Parkway and Veterans Memorial Highway. The officer requested backup, and the units followed the truck into the parking lot of a Chevron gas station off Old Floyd Road.

A passenger in the truck got out and cooperated with officers as they tried to block the vehicle off. But the driver, 40-year-old Clifford Jacoby Beck from Griffin, tried to speed away, the GBI said.

“The box truck just tried to outrun them. They tried to surround him. That is when the box truck started pushing the gas back and forth,” said Alexis Rivera, a regular customer at the gas station who witnessed the incident.

Beck hit a person’s car and several marked patrol cars, and officers fired into the truck, striking Beck, according to the GBI and Cobb County police. The box truck’s tires continued to spin, and the truck and a patrol car caught on fire.

The flames were extinguished by the Cobb County Fire Department. Beck was taken to a local hospital, where he later died, the GBI said.

All the officers involved have been placed on routine administrative leave as the GBI’s investigation continues.

articles.title: Morehouse College prepares for controversial Biden commencement address
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - At Morehouse College on Friday, graduating seniors strolled around campus in their caps and gowns, posing for pictures and taking in their final hours as college students.

But looming over what appeared to be a typical scene just two days before the historically Black college’s commencement ceremony was a sense of tension.

For weeks, some students and faculty members at the storied school have been urging administration to reconsider their choice to have President Joe Biden speak as their keynote commencement presenter. Because of his administration’s staunch support of Israel in their ongoing conflict against Hamas — and the ensuing humanitarian crisis involving the Palestinian people — they don’t want the president on campus.

“I feel a sense of betrayal,” said Morehouse sophomore Anwar Karim, his head draped in a keffiyeh, a traditional Middle Eastern headscarf. “It just feels like there’s a blatant and intentional aversion and ignorance of us as students and, that hurts.”

Karim was one of a handful of students who protested Friday ahead of Biden’s arrival at the school. His planned Sunday commencement address has drawn similar demonstrations at the school known for activist alumnae including Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and Julian Bond.

“This is a moment where our moral fortitude comes into play,” said Karim. “You really have to think about where you stand as a person regardless of where you come from or what you believe in.”

Others were looking forward to having Biden on campus.

“Having a president, a standing president deliver your commencement address is obviously historical,” said graduating senior Dawson Cox.

Dr. David Thomas, president of Morehouse College, said he would respect peaceful and silent protests during Biden’s address Sunday, but would also be prepared to stop commencement ceremonies on the spot if things get disruptive.

RELATED: Morehouse faculty approves honorary degree on President Biden ahead of visit

“I had students ask me about it, what if we, you know, turned our backs on the president or turned our chairs? And I said to them, I’ll be embarrassed, but that’s not your problem,” said Thomas. “Long as you don’t conduct yourself in a way that deprives others from being able to participate, consume, and celebrate this moment for their graduates.”

Ahead of his trip to Morehouse on Sunday morning, Biden will hold an event in Atlanta on Saturday with Black voters.

Georgia is a key battleground state.

According to Team Biden-Harris, they have 10 campaign offices opening across the state by the end of May.

To that point, the president’s visit to Morehouse may have its political benefits too. The Black voting bloc in metro Atlanta delivered him a historic victory in Georgia in the 2020 election, and he’ll need the same support if he hopes to win the state again in 2024.

But some Morehouse students say he’ll have to do more than a speech.

“All of our HBCUs are in predominately Black communities,” said Noah Collier, a Morehouse College senior. “So us as students, we are engaged with these communities, they’re engaged with us. Our politicians need to be doing the same thing.”

At an event to commemorate the anniversary of the landmark education decision Brown v. Board of Education, Biden touted his connections to Morehouse without mentioning the controversy over his visit this weekend, calling the school “one of our nation’s most important institutions.”

“I got more Morehouse men in my administration than Morehouse,” Biden joked. “The founders of Morehouse understood something fundamental: education is linked to freedom. Because to be free means to have something that no one can ever take away from you.”

President Biden was last in the Peach State back in March. He is scheduled to visit again along with former President Donald Trump on June 27 for a debate.

articles.title: New express toll lanes coming to major Metro Atlanta roadways
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - More toll express lanes are coming to some of the busiest stretches of Metro Atlanta’s commute.

The Georgia Board of Transportation is moving forward with adding toll lanes to GA-400 and the upper half of I-285.

“I’ve been stuck in traffic for like an hour,” said Absirloa Anderson.

Atlanta regularly ranks top 10 worst traffic cities in the country. The Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) is spending billions to try and change that.

“Because of the congestion we see in that corridor, so moving forward with that GA-400 express lanes project that will in the long run connect with 285 express lanes on the east side and on the west side,” said Natalie Dale, GDOT’s spokesperson.

Those express lanes will operate similarly to existing ones on I-75 northbound and southbound and on I-85, where drivers will use a Peach Pass to access them.

“Because of the congestion we see in that corridor, so moving forward with that GA-400 express lanes project that will in the long run connect with 285 express lanes on the east side and on the west side,” said Dale.

“I’ve been doing Lyft for a while, I’ve been driving for a while, that could definitely help me out a lot,” said Anderson.

How much would it cost to use the express lanes?

“That pricing is market driven based on how many people want to use it,” said Dale.

“Well, the rich will be over there. The regular people will be on the right side,” said David Glasco. “That sounds like a money grab.”

Even if drivers opt out using the express lanes, Dale says they’ll benefit.

“We saw time saving across the board. So you, you certainly have that reliable trip when you choose to use the express lane system. However, you also get a residual benefit from the managed lane system because we’re sort of moving vehicles out of that when they choose to take it,” said Dale.

Construction should start by fall of next year.

articles.title: Atlanta International Night Market begins two-night cultural experience in Chamblee
articles.content:
CHAMBLEE, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - The Atlanta International Night Market takes place on Friday and Saturday nights in Chamblee.

The event, which brings in over 100 different cultures and vendors, began nearly a decade ago with a simple question.

“What are we doing to give back in a unique way that isn’t already being done?” asked Atlanta International Night Market President Jeff Kuo.

The answer: food and culture in one spot.

“You can find a festival for everything,” Kuo said. “This is the only one where everybody can get together.”

Food and merchandise from all over the world will be available outside Chamblee City Hall, including Arabic children’s books and food from Taiwan, Mexico, Thailand, and Vietnam.

“Every event we do seems to get bigger,” Kuo said.

This is the first time Mouna Abdelhamid and the Alif Institute, which promotes Arabic culture, have participated in the event.

“The best way to learn about something is an experience,” Abdelhamid said.

Visitors will find things they likely won’t find anywhere else, like an oud, a distant relative to the guitar. The instrument is popular in the Arabic world but seldom seen in America.

“It’s not an easy instrument to play, but it’s a beautiful instrument,” Abdelhamid said.

The Atlanta International Night Market isn’t going to price people out with $20 funnel cake, either. Vendors must have multiple items for $5 or less to promote inclusivity and get more people to participate.

“Lecturing will only go so far,” Abdelhamid said. “Talking to somebody will only go so far. But an experience will last forever.”

“There’s nothing else like it right now in Atlanta,” Kuo added. “So, come check it out.”

articles.title: Postmaster general: ‘Substantial time, resources’ devoted to fix issues at Palmetto USPS facility

Postmaster Louis DeJoy the Postal Service is in the middle of a “major new investment in our Georgia operations,” including at the Palmetto facility.

articles.title: Voters to consider Mulberry cityhood referendum | What it would mean for residents
articles.content:
GWINNETT COUNTY, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - One of the metro’s largest counties is closer to adding another city.

A Gwinnett County Superior Court judge ruled a referendum on the city of Mulberry will remain on the ballot for May 21.

If this referendum passes it would carve out a new city in northeast Gwinnett County, creating a city of roughly 40,000 people.

RELATED: Referendum to create new city will stay on ballot in Gwinnett County

According to Gwinnett County’s website, the charter for the proposed city of Mulberry would provide three services directly: planning and zoning, code enforcement and stormwater collection and disposal. Control and maintenance of the roads within the city of Mulberry would also become the city’s responsibility.

“We’ve had a lot businesses, a lot of restaurants, a lot of people,” said Gwinnett County resident Andra Wilson.

Some residents who are in favor of cityhood, like Wilson, have concerns about overdevelopment in recent years and believe they would benefit from local control over planning and zoning in their community.

“With this you would feel you’re more comfortable because you’re in one group,” said Wilson.

While those against the referendum say they don’t want an extra layer of government.

“The city of Mulberry will offer me nothing more than I’m already getting from Gwinnett County, and I don’t see that it’s needed,” said Steve Hughes.

He says he filed a lawsuit alleging the proposed city’s charter was unconstitutional. A judge ultimately ruled the referendum would remain on the ballot.

Hughes says he worries the creation of a new city would cost more than anticipated.

“There’s the council, there’s the buildings, the operation, there’s the maintenance and there’s the money it takes to support that,” said Hughes.

Some Georgia lawmakers backing the cityhood proposal have said there would be no additional cost to residents.

RELATED: Georgia Senator proposes creating new city in Gwinnett County

“There’s no additional taxes, there will be no property tax levied to the city, you would still pay your property taxes to the county, but no change would happen there,” Sen. Clint Dixon (R-Gwinnett) said in January.

Georgia’s Primary Election is Tuesday, May 21st.

articles.title: Metro Atlanta daycare remaining open after ANF investigation
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A metro Atlanta daycare is staying open after an Atlanta News First Investigates story resulted in $60,000 in back payments coming its way from a state-operated tuition assistance program.

“Without your involvement, I wasn’t getting any answers,” said Chrystalyne Rivera, owner of A Step Above Preparatory Academy, whose two locations are in in southwest Atlanta near College Park and another in Conyers.

Because of a change in how Georgia operates its tuition assistance program, Rivera had to lay off her janitorial staff because she ran out of money and was facing an overall closure of her business.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE FROM BETTER CALL HARRY
Metro daycare may close if Georgia doesn’t reimburse missed tuition payments

Ninety-five percent of the children enrolled at A Step Above Preparatory Academy receive tuition assistance from Georgia’s CAPS program, which provides nearly $63 million annually to about 50,000 low-income Georgia families. Each week, daycares around the state receive CAPS reimbursement payments through the Georgia Department of Early Care and Learning (DECAL).

However, this past November, DECAL decided to streamline the CAPS program, which is also managed by its outside payment vendor, Maximus.

“We simply brought the provider management function in-house with a new system called GACAPS,” said DECAL spokesperson Reg Griffin. “This is providing streamlined services and increasing personal service for providers.”

“For more than 20 years, Maximus has demonstrated an unwavering commitment to the well-being of children, families, and childcare providers in Georgia,” a company spokesperson said. “We stand ready to support the Georgia Department of Early Care and Learning.”

But when DECAL transitioned to its new system, it created chaos for many daycares, which were used to receiving weekly payments.

Many complained in a private Facebook Group called Quality Rated Providers of Georgia. A DECAL spokesperson said the new system doesn’t work perfectly even now - six months after the launch.

“We understand the importance of timely compensation for the valuable services provided by our CAPS childcare providers and are doing everything possible to resolve any payment issues going forward,” Griffin said.

Rivera said at least five payments totaling more than $100,000 still need to be included, three in April and two from last year.

After Atlanta News First Investigates contacted DECAL’s spokesperson for help, Rivera received a call from an account specialist who researched her account and confirmed A Step Above Daycare should receive at least two payments soon, enough to keep Rivera’s doors open.

Those payments totaling $60,000 have been received, with the rest of the back payments promised to be on the way.

articles.title: Records: Buckhead nightclub owner where deadly shooting happened also operated nightclub shut down in 2022
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Management of Elleven45 Lounge in Buckhead, where two people were killed in Sunday’s shooting, also operated the Encore Hookah Bar & Bistro, a downtown Atlanta nightclub that shut down in 2022.

Atlanta News First found business records connecting the two establishments, both operated and managed by Djibril Dafe.

Dafe is listed as a party in a 2022 lawsuit filed by the City of Atlanta against the Encore Hookah Bar.

RELATED: 2 killed, 4 injured in Buckhead nightclub shooting, police say

The city cited safety concerns for urging a judge to close the establishment.

According to the city, the Atlanta Police Department was called more than 171 times to Encore between February 2020 and April 2022.

A hearing for the lawsuit was held on April 20, 2022, and as a result of the hearing, Encore agreed to cease doing business and vacate the property.

Earlier this week, two city sources confirmed with Atlanta News First that the city has launched an investigation into Elleven45 Lounge following Sunday’s shooting.

One potential outcome of the investigation is permanently closing the club.

In a zoning permit application, acquired by Atlanta News First and dated September 7, 2023, Dafe is also listed as the primary applicant for Elleven45 Lounge, located at 2110 Peachtree Street NW.

In a phone call on Friday, property owner Lee Nicholson confirmed Dafe managed Elleven45 Lounge.

Nicholson was critical of how the city and the media have addressed the nightclub following Sunday’s shooting, saying the attention is racially motivated.

“When a shooting happens in any establishment frequented by white people in this city, the focus is on the shooter, not the location,” Nicholson said in a text message to Atlanta News First. “The only reason the media is focusing on the location and not catching the mass shooter who is at large in our city is because the victims and the club owner and the clientele are predominantly Black. This is systemic racism at its absolute worst. Black Lives Matter to me. I wish also they mattered to the media.”

In a phone call, Nicholson defended the property’s safety in recent years.

RELATED: ‘I miss her so much’: Shooting victim’s sister wants city to shut down ‘not safe’ Buckhead nightclub

Atlanta News First acquired a list of 911 calls to the property, dating back to June 2020 to today.

Outside of Sunday’s shooting, Atlanta police were called for two other shootings, 35 fights, and 38 noise concerns.

On Friday, the family of two of the victims announced they plan to take legal action against Elleven45 Lounge.

Michael Sterling Sr., the attorney representing the families, said the club was negligent in ensuring basic safety for those entering the club.

RELATED: City of Atlanta investigation could shut down Buckhead nightclub after deadly shooting

“Someone got in there with a gun because someone failed to find that gun and they were negligent in their basic responsibility,” said Sterling.

Sterling is representing the family of Mari Creighton, who died in the shooting. He is also representing the family of Taylor Holmes, the niece of Creighton who was also shot on Sunday.

Holmes was released from the hospital on Thursday and is expected to be okay.

Sterling said security at the door took Creighton’s mace. The families want to know how someone with a gun was able to get inside.

RELATED: City of Atlanta to take ‘any necessary action’ following deadly shooting at Buckhead nightclub

On Friday, the Atlanta mayor’s office released a statement confirming their investigation into the nightclub.

“First and foremost, the mayor’s thoughts are with the families of those affected by this tragic and senseless act of gun violence,” said a spokesperson for the mayor’s office. “Following the incident and at the mayor’s direction, we are looking into a number of matters involving the property and working with the appropriate departments and agencies to take any necessary action. There are several tools at the mayor’s disposal, and he will not hesitate to leverage any of them to keep our communities safe and thriving. These are ongoing investigations, and the city will provide further updates when possible.”

articles.title: Program helping metro Atlanta families living in motels find permanent housing
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A local nonprofit is working to help families who are using motels for housing find a more permanent place to live.

The “Motel to Home Alliance” program offered by Frontline Housing Inc. assists families through outreach, housing and aftercare.

Ashely Washington, a wife, and mother of three children has benefited from the program.

Washington says last August, her family moved out of their apartment due to repairs her landlord failed to fix.

“This leak went on for a month or two. It just became unsafe and unhealthy to live in. There was mold, there were bugs it was really bad,” she said.

Washington said she and her family were staying in a motel when her husband was laid off.

“I’m getting maybe $600 a week, my hotel fees are about $500 a week. Now I have $100 a week to figure out how are we going to eat everyday? How am I going to keep gas to get back and forth from work,” Washington said.

Washington said that’s when a vicious cycle began.

“I’m forced every week to pack up all of this stuff between five people, load my car, try to find somewhere else. Then I have to go to another hotel, I have another deposit,” she said.

According to the Southern Poverty Law Center more than 25,000 lower-income people in metro Atlanta are mostly families using motels as permanent housing.

“A lot of times, they might find themselves in motels because of credit barriers, their credit may not qualify them for an apartment, or it could be how they show their proof of income,” said Mary Grace King, Frontline Housing Inc. executive director.

King said each participant is required to take a six month course on financial literacy.

“We really try to incorporate a saving program with our housing program so that families stay stable once they are placed in housing,” King said.

Washington and her family moved into a five-bedroom house in DeKalb County last November.

Washington said the program has offered her family a new beginning.

“I just feel like for me they were a blessing,” she said.

articles.title: Construction crew completes first passive house in Georgia
articles.content:
CHAMBLEE, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Construction crews in Chamblee have completed the first passive house in Georgia.

The house was officially certified by the Passive House Institute U.S. (PHIUS), which certifies structures meeting sustainability goals.

Carl Seville has been building and renovating homes for over 40 years.

Yet, this week marked the only time he’s ever conducted a passive house test.

“I became a passive house rater about 15 years ago,” Seville said. “I finally have an opportunity to work on a passive house because this is the first one in Georgia.”

To earn PHIUS certification, the two-story home in Dekalb County passed through a rigorous quality control process.

“We tested the amount of air leaking in and out of the house,” Seville said.

Keeping the cool air in and hot air out, Seville said the home has an airflow that is more energy-efficient than an average home.

“Georgia code is five air changes per hour,” Seville said. “This house is probably about 0.5 air changes per hour. So, this is probably about 10 times better than Georgia code.”

Andrew Goings is a custom home builder with Home and Made Custom Home Builders who’s been leading his team on the project.

Over the last two years, he’s been working hard to ensure the house is uniquely insulated and air-sealed.

Looking ahead, Goings’ goal is to build better homes in Georgia for the future.

“We’re trying to convey to future homeowners how much the energy savings and cost-benefit could really help them out in the long run,” he said.

According to Goings, PHIUS passive-certified houses provide energy savings between 40-60% compared to other homes.

With only one other PHIUS-certified house in the entire southeast United States, Georgia is now the second state to adopt the future of green, zero-carbon building.

“That’s a huge accomplishment for us and for the PHIUS organization as a whole,” Goings said. “We’re really starting to ramp up in the Southeast.”

A couple has already secured the home, buying it for a total price of $1.3 million.

Home and Made Custom Home Builders already has plans to build two more passive homes in the area.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: New village for unhoused Georgia veterans breaks ground in Mableton
articles.content:
MABLETON, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A nonprofit in Georgia is on a mission to end veteran homelessness.

Tunnel to Towers is partnering up with elected officials and Home Depot to develop a new facility in Mableton that will offer safe and secure housing to more than 90 Atlanta veterans.

“Veterans put their lives on the line for us every day and then they come home and they don’t have the access that they should,” said Gavin Naples with Tunnel to Towers.

The future Atlanta Veterans Village, located on what once was the Wingate Hotel, will feature liveable apartments equipped with a bedroom, living room, kitchen, and bathroom. Veterans will also have access to a community gym, business center, cafeteria, commercial kitchen space, and 24/7 support services.

“I know the veterans, when they come home, they really have a tough time adjusting to civilian life. What they are doing in the service is not a normal job, some adjust better than others. They need a place like this where they can...make it back into society,” said veteran Raymond Bressingham.

Friday’s groundbreaking is the beginning of what will eventually become a beacon of hope to those who need support. Renovations on the building are expected to start in the next few weeks.

“At the end of the day, it is about making ourselves available to the veterans in the area,” said Mableton Mayor Michael Owens.

Tunnel to Towers has created housing for veterans in need across 10 other states.

articles.title: Zoo Atlanta’s giant pandas returning to China in late 2024, facility says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Right now, Zoo Atlanta is the only place you can see giant pandas in the United States — but that privilege won’t last for much longer.

“It would be nice if we could keep them on loan for a while longer for all the kids to see,” A Zoo Atlanta visitor said.

The four bears will return to China in the fourth quarter of 2024, the zoo confirmed on Friday. Zoo officials have applied for international travel permits for Lun Lun, Yang Yang, Ya Lun and Xi Lun.

Lun Lun and Yang Yang were loaned to Atlanta in 1999, but the zoo’s contract with Chinese officials has expired.

Ya Lun and Xi Lun are twins and two of the pair’s seven children. The others have already been sent to China’s Chengdu Research Center of Giant Panda Breeding.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE: Atlanta is the last place to see giant pandas in the U.S. — but maybe not for long

The zoo said it will give “significant advance notice” of when the giant pandas are leaving so guests can see the bears one last time.

“While Zoo Atlanta remains committed to the stewardship and long-term conservation of the species, no discussions have yet taken place with partners in China as to the future of the Zoo’s giant panda program following the expiration of Zoo Atlanta’s current agreement,” the zoo said in a statement.

This year marks the 25th anniversary of the zoo’s giant panda program. The zoo plans to celebrate with a “Summer of Celebration,” kicking off on June 1 with cultural performances and educational activities from 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. The event is included in a regular ticket purchase.

Since the program began, the zoo has contributed more than $17 million to giant panda conservation. That includes donations to nature reserves, reforestation plans, genetic diversity studies and more, the zoo said.

Giant pandas are listed as a vulnerable species, with fewer than 1,900 remaining in the wild. Most exist on nature reserves, according to the zoo.

Zoo Atlanta became the last remaining U.S. zoo with giant pandas when the Smithsonian’s National Zoo returned its three giant pandas to China in November 2023.

“It’s a great attraction and everybody loves pandas. They’re big fluffy animals. I mean who doesn’t want to see a panda eat some bamboo and roll around you know,” Zoo Atlanta visitor Jaylin Jackson said.

But the United States won’t be bear-less. The China Wildlife Conservation Association announced that the San Diego Zoo will receive two bears in the summer of 2024. The association is also in talks with a zoo in Washington, D.C.

“We look forward to further expanding the research outcomes on the conservation of endangered species such as giant pandas, and promoting mutual understanding and friendship among peoples through the new round of international cooperation,” Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said.

articles.title: Conservative media personality appointed to seat on Georgia State Election Board
articles.content:
(AP) - A media personality who co-founded a conservative political action committee has been appointed to a seat on the Georgia State Election Board, which is responsible for developing election rules, investigating allegations of fraud and making recommendations to state lawmakers.

Georgia House Speaker Jon Burns, a Republican, on Friday announced the appointment of Janelle King to the board, effective immediately. She replaces Ed Lindsey, a former Republican state lawmaker, who resigned his seat after having served on the board since 2022.

“Janelle will be a tremendous asset as an independent thinker and impartial arbiter who will put principle above politics and ensure transparency and accountability in our elections, and I look forward to her work on behalf of the people of Georgia,” Burns said in a news release announcing King’s appointment.

King is the third new member appointed this year to the board, which has four Republican members and one Democrat. In January, Gov. Brian Kemp appointed Waffle House executive John Fervier to chair the board, and the state Senate approved the nomination of former state Sen. Rick Jeffares. Janice Johnston is the Republican Party appointee to the board, and Sara Tindall Ghazal is the Democratic Party appointee.

King and her husband, Kelvin King, co-chair Let’s Win For America Action, a conservative political action committee. Kelvin King ran for U.S. Senate in 2022 but lost in the Republican primary.

Janelle King has previously served as deputy state director of the Georgia Republican Party, as chair of the Georgia Black Republican Council and as a board member of the Georgia Young Republicans. She appears on Fox 5 Atlanta’s “The Georgia Gang,” has a podcast called “The Janelle King Show” and has been a contributor on the Fox News Channel.

Despite her history as a Republican operative, King said she plans to use facts and data to make the right decisions while serving on the board.

“While my conservative values are still the same personally, when it comes to serving, I believe that I have to do my job,” she said in a phone interview Friday. “So I think I’m going to show people over time that I am fair, I am balanced and that I’m able to put my personal feelings to the side when necessary if that’s what it takes to make the best decision.”

The State Election Board has had an elevated profile since the 2020 election cycle resulted in an increased polarization of the rhetoric around elections. Its meetings often attract a boisterous crowd with strong opinions on how the state’s elections should be run and the board members sometimes face criticism and heckling.

King said that wouldn’t faze her: “Look, I’m a Black conservative. Criticism is nothing for me. I am not worried about that at all.”

Recent meetings have drawn scores of public comments from Republican activists who assert that former President Donald Trump was the rightful winner of the 2020 election. They are calling for major changes in Georgia’s elections, including replacing the state’s touchscreen electronic voting machines with paper ballots marked and counted by hand.

King declined to comment Friday on her feelings about the state’s voting machines, but in a February episode of her podcast she said she has seen “no proof of cheating on the machines” and that she wasn’t in favor of an exclusively paper ballot system.

articles.title: Man sentenced to life for sexually assaulting neighbor, DeKalb County district attorney says
articles.content:
KIRKWOOD, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A Kirkwood man has been sentenced to life in prison plus 20 years after being convicted of sexually assaulting his neighbor, according to the DeKalb County District Attorney.

The district attorney said Eric Haygood, 61, sexually assaulted a woman in her 50s on Feb. 1, 2022. Haygood knocked on her door around 8:30 a.m. before attacking and strangling her and demanding they have sex, prosecutors said.

According to the district attorney, “the victim’s attempts to stop Defendant Haygood verbally and physically were unsuccessful.”

After assaulting her, Haygood told the victim he was in trouble, hugged her, and left.

Haygood was convicted of rape, two counts of aggravated sodomy and aggravated assault strangulation.

He was sentenced to life without the possibility of parole plus 20 years in prison.

articles.title: Chamblee park closes for ‘multi-million-dollar renovation,’ city says
articles.content:
CHAMBLEE, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Dresden Park in Chamblee will be closed for 14 months to undergo renovations, according to the city.

The city said the renovation will include “artificially turfed-rectangular fields and a multi-use field,” a new concessions building, seating and a community center, among other amenities.

The renovations will cost almost $13 million. Some $10.8 million came from funding granted through the American Rescue Plan Act and $2 million came from the city.

“Programming typically held at Dresden will be moved to Keswick Park and other privately owned field locations,” Parks, Recreation and Arts Director Jodie Gilfillan said. “We understand this isn’t ideal but believe once the park re-opens citizens will be elated with the changes.”

The city anticipates that the park will reopen in May 2025.

articles.title: City of Atlanta to take ‘any necessary action’ following deadly shooting at Buckhead nightclub
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - The City of Atlanta is working to take “any necessary action” following a deadly shooting at a Buckhead nightclub.

In a statement from the Atlanta Mayor’s Office, the city is looking into a “number of matters” involving Elleven45 Lounge at Mayor Andre Dickens’ direction following the May 12 shooting. Nykris Ridley, 20, and Mari Creighton, a 21-year-old Albany State University student, were killed in a shooting.

“There are several tools at the mayor’s disposal, and he will not hesitate to leverage any of them to keep our communities safe and thriving,” a spokesperson from the mayor’s office said.

The city has launched an investigation into the club. Sources told Atlanta News First that the probe could lead to its permanent closure.

ELLEVEN45 LOUNGE DEADLY SHOOTING COVERAGE:
City of Atlanta investigation could shut down Buckhead nightclub after deadly shooting
‘I miss her so much’: Shooting victim’s sister wants city to shut down ‘not safe’ Buckhead nightclub

Atlanta police said Ridley was the target of the shooting and Creighton was a bystander. Four others were also injured in the shooting.

Police have not publically identified any suspects, but Police Chief Darin Schierbaum has said an arrest is imminent.

articles.title: 15-year-old killed in Woodstock crash, sheriff’s office says

articles.title: Lawsuit: East Point employee’s firing was retaliation for not removing fine for official’s relative
articles.content:
EAST POINT, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A former East Point employee has filed a federal lawsuit seeking millions, claiming she was discriminated and retaliated against by a city councilmember and a municipal court judge before she was fired.

In the $7 million lawsuit, Kimberly Propst, the former court administrator, claims East Point City Councilmember Sharon Shropshire pressured her to remove a criminal fee for one of her relatives.

The lawsuit claims that when Propst refused to do so, the city councilmember led an effort to retaliate against her. The lawsuit also states that Propst filed a formal complaint against Shropshire.

Propst was fired on Jan. 30 by Municipal Court Judge Rashida Oliver — one day after the city council voted to remove Propst as a department head and report directly to Oliver, the lawsuit states. The lawsuit also says Oliver was given a $40,000 raise during that Jan. 29 meeting.

The lawsuit argues that the two violated East Point ordinances prohibiting city councilors from using their positions to retaliate against city employees and using coercion to give benefits to family members.

“The law does not permit public officials to weaponize the full weight of their trusted offices to destroy the lives of employees who submit good faith complaints about wrongdoing. Such abuses of power can not go unchecked, and the city must be held accountable,” Arnold Lizana, a civil rights attorney representing Propst, said in a statement.

>> READ THE FULL LAWSUIT BELOW:

Propst is seeking lost wages and back pay, along with compensatory damages for “mental anguish and emotional distress,” according to the lawsuit.

The lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia Atlanta Division.

Atlanta News First has reached out to East Point officials for comment on the lawsuit.

articles.title: These metro Atlanta congressional races are already set for November
articles.content:

In District Four, longtime Democratic incumbent Hank Johnson faces no primary competitor. Nor does Republican Eugene Yu, meaning they will meet on Nov. 5, 2024, in a district that Johnson has represented since 2007.

Everything you need to know about the 2024 Georgia primary election

In the 9th, U.S. Rep. Andrew Clyde has represented the northeast Georgia district since 2021. With no Republican opposition in the heavily GOP-leaning district, he is facing Democrat Tambrei Cash this November.

articles.title: Funeral for Georgia airman killed in his home by Florida deputy
articles.content:
STONECREST, Ga. (Atlanta News First) — The family of a DeKalb County senior airman who was shot and killed in his Florida home by a sheriff’s deputy said their final goodbyes Friday.

Airman Roger Fortson was 23 years old. His mother vowed during an emotional news conference to get justice for her son.

The service was held at the New Birth Missionary Baptist Church in the Atlanta suburb of Stonecrest. Fortson grew up in the area before joining the Air Force.

Family, friends and fellow airmen attended the service. One of several speakers included Col. Patrick Dierig, the commander of the 1st Special Operations Wing, Hurlburt Field, Florida. He described Fortson as a man of honor, integrity and courage. Col. Dierig continued to say the sea of Air Force blue at the church, showed how respected Fortson was.

“We would love to take credit for making him great, but the truth is he was great before he came to us,” Col. Dierig said, about Fortson.

The 23-year-old was shot and killed at his apartment by a Florida deputy responding to a disturbance call. Fortson’s attorneys say the deputy was at the wrong door.

articles.title: 2 Troup County students ejected from car in accident, 3 other students injured
articles.content:
LAGRANGE, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Just days away from graduating high school, two teens are fighting for their lives following a crash in Troup County.

Five Troup County High School students were involved in a car crash Thursday afternoon in LaGrange, Atlanta News First’s sister station WTVM in Columbus reports.

According to the Georgia State Patrol, the driver of a black 2008 Volkswagen Tiguan entered the intersection of Whitfield Road and Hogansville Road after stopping at a stop sign and was struck by a Troup County School District truck hauling a trailer.

The Driver of the Tiguan failed to yield and was struck on the passenger side by the Ram 3500.

The truck involved was a Dodge Ram 3500, which slammed into the passenger side of the Volkswagen.

Officials said two of the students were ejected and had to be airlifted to Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta in critical condition. The three other students and the driver of the Dodge truck were injured but police have not provided details on the extent of their injuries.

The identities of those involved have not been released. However, Atlanta News First spoke with one of their siblings who identified the two in critical condition as Mary Joy and Hadilee. Hadilee’s sister tells us that family members are by their side at the hospital as they fight for their lives.

The Troup County High School’s honors night was postponed due to the incident. Its graduation is next Friday.

The Georgia State Patrol is investigating the accident.

Editor’s Note: The original report stated that the Tiguan ran a stop sign. The Georgia State Patrol report stated otherwise.

articles.title: Friday marks last day for early voting in Georgia’s general primary
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First/AP) - Friday, May 17 is the last day for early voting in Georgia’s general primary.

Next week’s election will set the ballot for Georgia’s battleground Nov. 5, 2024, election. Voters will choose nominees for the U.S. House and the state legislature, as well as decide whether one of Trump’s prosecutors will keep her job.

Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, who is leading the prosecution of Trump in a 2020 election interference case, faces challenger Christian Wise Smith in the Democratic primary. Smith is an attorney and author who ran against Willis four years ago.

The judge in the case is also up for reelection. Fulton County Superior Court Judge Scott McAfee faces Robert Patillo, an attorney and radio host, in the nonpartisan race. McAfee is a former prosecutor who was appointed by Republican Gov. Brian Kemp in 2022.

Georgia has neither a governor’s race nor a Senate race on the ballot in 2024, so the state’s 14 congressional districts are the only federal races with primaries on Tuesday. The only open seat is in the solidly Republican 3rd Congressional District, held by retiring incumbent Drew Ferguson.

Of the remaining 13 incumbents, 10 are running uncontested in their primaries. The other three are Democrats Lucy McBath and David Scott and Republican Barry Loudermilk. McBath is seeking the Democratic nomination in the 6th Congressional District, a west Atlanta district that was redrawn in redistricting. She represents the 7th Congressional District.

Scott has represented the 13th District for more than two decades, though his district, like McBath’s, changed significantly in redistricting. His primary has attracted the largest field. Loudermilk, who represents the 11th District, has two challengers in the Republican primary.

Georgia’s state primary election will be held Tuesday, May 21. Polls close at 7 p.m. ET.

Georgia's new congressional districts

Here’s what you need to know about early voting from the Georgia Secretary of State website:

Am I registered to vote?

You must first be registered to vote in the state of Georgia. Visit the Georgia Secretary of State’s website to verify that you are listed as active. If you’re not registered to vote, learn how to register now.

Where do I vote early?
Unlike Election Day, you do not have to vote at an assigned polling location during early voting. You may vote at any early voting location within your county. Find available early voting locations by visiting the Secretary of State’s website and selecting your county of residence from the list. You can also find available locations by logging into your My Voter Page and looking at your polling place information.
When you arrive at your early voting location, you’ll need to bring a valid photo ID such as a driver’s license, passport, or voter identification card.

articles.title: The return of summer means a return to Lake Lanier. Here’s how to stay safe.
articles.content:
LAKE LANIER, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Businesses on Lake Lanier are preparing for peak season.

“It picks up a lot as we’re coming into Memorial Day,” said Heidi Moore with Skier’s Marine and MasterCraft Boats.

She has spent 25 years working the lake and knows boating isn’t as easy as it seems.

“You know, you don’t just get out and drive zigzags across it,” she said.

Lake Lanier has a reputation as a “cursed lake.” Moore scoffs at the idea.

“Lake Lanier is definitely not haunted,” she said.

But you could forgive someone for thinking it so. From 1994-2022, more than 200 people died on Lake Lanier, most of those from drowning.

Moore says it doesn’t need to be that way.

“If you’re 12 and under, you need to be wearing a life jacket,” Moore said.

The rules of boating aren’t that different from driving. There’s right-of-way, rules of the road, and licenses.

“You can’t drive a boat until you’re 16 and have taken a boater safety course,” Moore said.

If you were born after 1997, you’re required to take that course.

You also need one Coast Guard-approved life jacket per person.

The biggest red flag, by far, is one most people associate with boating: alcohol.

Research has shown that up to 70% of drowning victims have alcohol in their blood. The Coast Guard estimates that one-third of all boating fatalities are alcohol-related.

“One of the other things people forget to do is check the weather before they go,” Moore added.

That might sound basic, but choppy water can wreak havoc on boats and boaters.

articles.title: Habersham County street gang associates face RICO charges after arrest, GBI says
articles.content:
HABERSHAM COUNTY, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Seven associates of the Gangster Disciples street gang based in Habersham County now face RICO charges after being arrested, according to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI).

The GBI said the seven were arrested were on Apr. 18 after a several-months long investigation. The GBI said the Habersham County Sheriff’s Office, the Stephens County Sheriff’s Department, the Toccoa Police Department and the FBI Safe Streets Task Force helped with the investigation.

The following people were arrested:

Roger Laquerrius Neal, 34, of Toccoa
Tyler Dallas Cagle, 33, of Waynesville, North Carolina
Sarah Smathers, 31, of Waynesville, North Carolina
Terry Ray Williams Jr., 20, of Waynesville, North Carolina
Shelby Page Stephens, 63 of Waynesville, North Carolina
Quillan Leshun Samuels, 25, of Gainesville
Andrew Nelson Dover, 47, of Habersham County

All seven have been charged with violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, violation of the Street Gang Terrorism and Prevention Act and possession of a Schedule III drug with intent to distribute.

Additionally, Cagle has been charged with simple assault and terroristic threats and Samuels has been charged with terroristic threats.

The Gangster Disciples are a long-running gang that started on the south side of Chicago, but have expanded throughout the southeast United States.

articles.title: Former Georgia lottery official arrested, charged with bribery, GBI says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A man trusted to inspect Georgia’s lottery machines is now being investigated for bribery, according to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation.

62-year-old Michael Kessler was a compliance inspector and now faces accusations that he accepted bribes from store owners, the GBI said.

He now faces three counts of bribery.

articles.title: ‘He was a role model’: Coach remembers Lyft driver allegedly murdered by former APD officer
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A Lyft driver who was allegedly murdered by a former police officer he gave a ride to, is being remembered as a “good soul” by those who knew him.

Reginald “Reggie” Folks, 35, was found shot and killed in a car Wednesday in Union City.

Police arrested Koby Minor, who had been with Atlanta Police six years before resigning the day of his arrest.

Folks was an emerging professional wrestler who trained at World Wrestling Alliance 4 in Atlanta. His coach, Thomas Ballester, said he was doing Lyft to raise more money for his wrestling career.

“A lot of little kids looked up to him,” Ballester said. “He was a role model.”

Ballester showed Atlanta News First a video of Folks dancing in the ring with a group of kids who came to watch him.

“I just wish I would’ve told him I was proud of him more,” he said.

Union City Police said Folks picked Minor up through Lyft to bring him home the morning of May 15. Minor had been on administrative leave with Atlanta Police since being arrested on an unrelated charge in Milton in December 2023.

According to the arrest warrants obtained by Atlanta News First, Minor believed his driver “is in a gay fraternity and was trying to recruit Minor into it and believed he was getting kidnapped by Folks.”

It goes on to say, “He heard what he thought was another voice in his ear talking to him, but did not say what the voice said.”

Minor told police he thought Folks was speaking an “unknown language” and told him he wanted to get out of the car. When Folks reached the intersection of Stonewall Tell Road and South Fulton Parkway, Minor attempted to unlock the car. When he could not, he told police he shot Folks in the head.

Friends of Folks, like fellow wrestler Christian Turner, said they could not believe this happened to him.

“The last time I saw him was Monday. He was very hyped. He was showing everyone his brand new shirt, because he had made his first professional wrestling shirt,” Turner said.

Even though he went by the wrestling name “Reggie Rage,” he was described as always happy.

“A good soul. Life of the party,” Turner said. “He had a smile on his face every day.”

“We will just keep going, because that’s what he would want,” he said.

Ballester said they would be arranging a wrestling tournament in memory of Folks.

Lyft released a statement saying they would be assisting law enforcement with whatever they needed during the course of the investigation.

Minor is being held in the Fulton County Jail, charged with murder and aggravated assault.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Multiple people found shot to death in car in Coweta County, sheriff’s office says
articles.content:

Around 6 p.m., deputies responded to calls about a driver and passenger who seemed to be unconscious in a car near the intersection of Hayward Bishop Court and Hayward Bishop Way, according to the Coweta County Sheriff’s Office.

Police found a man and a woman dead in the vehicle from apparent gunshot wounds, the sheriff’s office said.

articles.title: ‘Self-claimed pimp’ sentenced to 50 years for sex trafficking, Gwinnett County District Attorney says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A Florida man has been sentenced to 50 years in prison after being convicted of trafficking a young woman in Gwinnett County, according to the Gwinnett County District Attorney.

The district attorney said Max Francois Joseph, 34, trafficked an 18-year-old woman in both DeKalb County and Florida in 2022. Joseph also made the woman perform sex acts in exchange for money at two motels in Norcross.

articles.title: 2 arrested in DeKalb County carjacking that left DoorDash driver dead, police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - DeKalb County police said they’ve arrested two men in connection to a deadly carjacking.

Police said they arrested 20-year-old Shamal Smith and 21-year-old Taylor Smith Wednesday night. They both face charges of felony murder and armed robbery, according to jail records.

Authorities said the carjacking and fatal shooting happened at a gas station on Redan Road near Indian Creek Drive early Sunday morning.

Family members have identified the victim as 31-year-old Cequan James.

She says that’s when her son was ambushed.

“You could have just took the car. Why’d you feel you had to take his life?” Lewis said.

Lewis says James worked multiple jobs to provide for his family.

James was shot and killed while delivering food for DoorDash.(n/a)

articles.title: Attorney, family of Georgia airman killed by deputy in Florida give update on case
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - The family of Senior Airman Roger Fortson, who was fatally shot by a Florida deputy, spoke out Thursday.

Fortson, a 23-year-old active-duty airman from DeKalb County, died at his off-base residence, the U.S. Air Force said.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE: Airman from DeKalb County shot, killed by deputy in Florida, military says

Body camera video released by the Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office shows the interaction between the deputy and Fortson.

The family and lawyer for 23-year-old Airman Roger Fortson are demanding transparency, while the Okaloosa County Sheriff says they're being transparent.

Civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who is representing Fortson’s family, believes law enforcement burst into the wrong unit while responding to the call and “used excessive force to execute him.”

The sheriff’s office claims the deputy “reacted in self-defense after he encountered a 23-year-old man armed with a gun.”

“As long as they [the sheriff’s office] continue to say that they went to the right apartment, they are staining his reputation because Roger did not have any domestic disturbance. Roger had no criminal history. Roger has never ever been accused of domestic violence,” Crump said at a press conference with Fortson’s family Thursday.

Crump said Fortson was on a Facetime call with a woman at the time of the encounter. According to Crump, the woman on the call said Fortson was alone in his apartment when he heard a knock at the door. He asked who was there but didn’t get a response. A few minutes later, Fortson heard a louder knock but didn’t see anyone when he looked through the peephole, Crump said, citing the woman’s account.

The woman said Fortson was concerned and went to retrieve his gun, which he legally owned.

“As Fortson walked back through his living room, deputies burst through the door, saw that Fortson was armed, and shot him six times,” Crump said in a statement. “The woman said Fortson was on the ground, saying, ‘I can’t breathe,’ after he was shot.”

“There’s nobody better than him,” Fortson’s mother, Meka Fortson, said. “Roger was light. There would not be a stain on his name. He will not be put to rest in darkness, because he was light.”

“Tell the truth and give my child justice,” she added.

WATCH THE FAMILY’S FULL REMARKS:

“At this time, we humbly ask for our community’s patience as we work to understand the facts that resulted in this tragic event,” Okaloosa County Sheriff Eric Aden said in a statement following the shooting.

Fortson’s remains were returned to his home in metro Atlanta on Tuesday. Funeral services are scheduled for Friday at New Birth Missionary Baptist Church in Stonecrest.

As of Thursday afternoon, the Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office had not yet responded to the family’s press conference.

articles.title: Ousted Georgia GOP exec who voted illegally says he didn’t know he was on probation
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Brian Pritchard, the ousted state Republican party leader who voted nine times illegally while making repeated claims of fraud in the 2020 election, said he was unaware he was still on probation when he cast ballots in Georgia.

“No one should ever vote illegally, you with me,” Pritchard said during an exclusive interview with Atlanta News First. “Anyone in America today, in all these states could possibly vote, unknowing they’re doing something. Anyone could.”

Pritchard, who was convicted on counts of forging checks in 1996, was given probation until 1999. It was then extended twice, according to court records, to last until 2011.

But Pritchard voted in nine Georgia primary, general and runoff elections between July 2008 and November 2010 all while on probation. In Georgia, it is illegal for people on felony probation to vote.

MORE COVERAGE:
Georgia Republicans remove officer found to have voted illegally
Georgia GOP chair calls on top party official to resign

Pritchard claimed he never spoke to a probation officer and moved several times over the course of his probationary period. He removed himself from the voter rolls when he was alerted to his illegal voting in 2014, years after his probation had ended.

It sparked an investigation that ended in March, with Georgia Administrative Judge Lisa Boggs ruling that Pritchard’s claim of ignorance was neither “credible or convincing.”

“Even if the court accepts (Pritchard) did not know about his felony sentences, the record before this court demonstrates that he should have known,” Boggs wrote.

Court documents show Pritchard was present in Pennsylvania court in 2002 and 2004 at hearings where his probationary period was extended.

Calls for his resignation after the March decision poured in, even from some high-profile Republicans.

“Brian Pritchard must resign immediately,” said Georgia’s ultraconservative Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene on Twitter. “At a time when the Georgia Republican Party is successfully building its effort to protect our state from a total Democratic takeover, it is unacceptable for our party to have a man in leadership who has repeatedly committed voter fraud himself.”

>> WATCH FULL INTERVIEW:

Pritchard was elected to serve as the Georgia Republican Party’s first vice chairman last year and even served on the party’s election security task force.

On Friday, with over 80% of the party’s delegates voting for his removal, Pritchard was ousted from his leadership position.

“I don’t know how I can talk to you or others with any kind of authority on election integrity if I’m going to be defending someone who engaged in that pattern of conduct,” said Georgia GOP chairman Josh McKoon.

McKoon said Pritchard first made him aware of his voting issues last year, the same week Pritchard was elected first vice-chair.

“Last summer our discussion was look, I’ve been accused of these things, they’re not true, I’ve got a defense, give me an opportunity to present my defense in court,” said McKoon. “He told me he had a legitimate defense. If I’m guilty of anything, it’s believing Brian Pritchard.”

U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, left, called for Brian Pritchard, right, to resign from his role as vice chairman of the Georgia Republican Party. (WANF)

articles.title: Georgia baby horse gets second chance at life
articles.content:
BROOKS, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - When you look at horses Storm and Gracie, you might see a mother and her baby, but their story is a little different than what you might expect.

“This is not her real baby. Her real baby passed away,” said Julie Nestor with Night Diamond Arabians.

Storm’s baby, Eclipse, passed away.

The Night Diamond Arabians bread rare black-colored Arabian horses. Nestor said she takes rescues in occasionally.

“A friend of mine, Brook and Stacey, they found out about an orphaned foal,” said Nestor.

The baby had been rejected by its mother. It came to the Brooks property from the rescue organization, Save the Horses.

“This is Gracie. She is the orphaned foul that came from Save the Horses and she is three and a half weeks old,” said Nestor.

Storm and Gracie bonded right away. They have been inseparable ever since.

“It really is a little miracle that she is letting her nurse as if she is her own foal,” said Nestor.

articles.title: City of Atlanta investigation could shut down Buckhead nightclub after deadly shooting
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - The City of Atlanta has launched an investigation into Elleven45 Lounge after a deadly shooting Sunday.

The probe could lead to the permanent closure of the nightclub, according to two City sources with knowledge of the investigation.

The City is reviewing the history of crime, the owner’s business license and permits issued to the lounge, located at 2110 Peachtree Road NW in the Buckhead neighborhood.

For some neighbors, the investigation is long overdue.

“How many innocent people have to die to let this keep going?” said James Curtis, who lives in an apartment complex across the street.

RELATED: 2 killed, 4 injured in Buckhead nightclub shooting, police say

Two people died on Sunday, including bystander Mari Creighton, 21.

A source within APD confirmed with Atlanta News First the second person killed, 20-year-old Nakyris Ridley was the target in the shooting.

Curtis has lived along this stretch of Peachtree Road for roughly 20 years. He said he’s complained to city leaders about this club about public safety issues, permitting questions, and noise concerns.

“I’m not saying these people don’t have a right to be here, but if they’re as rowdy as they are, shut the clubs down. We do not need these disturbances,” said Curtis on Thursday.

This online petition, started in 2020, now has more than 10,000 signatures calling for City leaders to shut down the club.

Efforts by Atlanta News First to reach the club owners and property owners were unsuccessful throughout the week.

One neighboring business owner, who wished to remain anonymous due to fear of retribution, said he wished the City would spend more time trying to identify the shooter rather than targeting the club.

RELATED: ‘I miss her so much’: Shooting victim’s sister wants city to shut down ‘not safe’ Buckhead nightclub

Atlanta Police have not identified any suspects.

Police Chief Darin Schierbaum indicated to city leaders on Monday that an arrest was imminent.

“That will happen I believe very shortly, our officers have been working tirelessly since that tragedy unfolded to make sure we have that individual in custody before a court,” Schierbaum said.

Atlanta News First acquired the 911 calls to the listed address of the club, from June 2020 to present day.

Outside of the shooting incident on Sunday, there were two shootings, 35 fights in progress reported and 38 noise complaints made.

Creighton’s family told Atlanta News First there will be a balloon release in honor of Creighton on Saturday in Stockbridge.
