articles.title: Restaurant Report Card: Los Girasoles fails with 65; Southern Belle earns 100
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Just off Upper Riverdale Road in Jonesboro, a Mexican restaurant has some serious problems.

Los Girasoles failed with 65 points and a “U” for unsatisfactory. The report says an employee touched their pants and then handled clean utensils, an employee touched their hair and then prepared a to-go order without washing their hands and chicken, rice, sour cream and several other items were at an unsafe temperature in the cooler.

“We put it all in the trash because it was no good. We put it all in the trash and we made new, and the cooler is working perfect now,” an employee said.

The employee said management corrected all the violations, but we spotted one they forgot about. An old health report of 84 points was posted on the wall instead of their failing one.

Now to an update in Fulton County. Yasin’s Homestyle Seafood on Old National Highway in College Park improved on a reinspection, but not by much, scoring just 72 points and a ‘C’ on a reinspection.

Southern Belle on Ponce de Leon Avenue in Atlanta earned a 100 on their last health inspection. Make that five in a row! Congratulations, they are the winner of this week’s Golden Spatula Award.

This place is special, and let me explain why. Executive Chef Joey Ward is a James Beard nominated chef, and the restaurant is Michelin Guide recommended. And in the kitchen, they use fresh and local ingredients. The food is plated to perfection.

On the menu you can order the strawberry salad, puttanesca toast, Georgia wagyu beef tartare, scallop escabeche and more. Boy, that’s good!

articles.title: Referendum to create new city will stay on ballot in Gwinnett County

articles.title: Man charged with killing girlfriend turns himself in, Sandy Springs police say

ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Officers arrested a man in connection with the death of his girlfriend in Sandy Springs, according to the Sandy Springs Police Department.

They said Mamadi Tambajang turned himself in at the department’s headquarters on Wednesday around 12:45 p.m.

Reverend Ashley Guthas will take over sermons at Maranatha Baptist Church in Plains starting next month. She most recently served as an associate minister at Northside Drive Baptist Church in Atlanta.

articles.title: Morehouse faculty approves honorary degree on President Biden ahead of visit
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Ahead of President Joe Biden’s Sunday Morehouse commencement address, the White House held a two-hour meeting with students and faculty at the nationally acclaimed HBCU.

Steven Benjamin, senior advisor to the president, met with the school Friday morning. In the early afternoon, Benjamin said Morehouse faculty voted to confer an honorary degree on the president.

Last month, Morehouse announced it had invited Biden to become the second sitting American president to deliver Morehouse College’s commencement address, following in the footsteps of his former boss, Barack Obama. Biden is scheduled to deliver the school’s graduation speech on Sunday, May 19, at 9 a.m.

In 2013, then-President Obama — under whom Biden served as vice president — delivered Morehouse’s commencement address for that class.

But almost immediately after the announcement, students, faculty and alumni began expressing concern over Biden’s visit to the campus. It was over Biden’s unwillingness to call for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas. An online petition was also started seeking to persuade Morehouse College to rescind its invitation to Biden.

During a White House press briefing on Thursday Benjamin said that Biden will be able to hear directly from those at Morehouse College on Sunday.

“I’m sure the president will have a chance to engage with faculty, staff and students while he’s there,” said Benjamin

Biden’s Morehouse address is his second time delivering a commencement address to an HBCU. Last year, Biden spoke at Howard University, the alma mater of Vice President Kamala Harris.

When it comes time for Sunday’s commencement ceremonies, Morehouse College President David A. Thomas detailed what will and will not be allowed.

“We will allow silent non disruptive protest,” said Thomas.

He added, “we will also not ask police to take individuals out of commencement in zip ties, if faced with the choice I will cease the ceremonies on the spot.”

This weekend marks the president’s first visit back to the Peach State after a March campaign rally.

Biden’s schedule for Atlanta visit:

Saturday, May 18, 2024

12:30 p.m.: Biden departs Joint Base Andrews en route to Atlanta.

2 p.m.: Biden arrives at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.

4 p.m.: Biden participates in a campaign reception in Atlanta.

Sunday, May 19, 2024

9 a.m.: Biden delivers the commencement address at Morehouse College.

11:30 a.m.: Biden departs from Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.

Atlanta News First will stream the entire Morehouse College commencement, including President Biden’s remarks. Watch live at 9 a.m. by downloading the ANF+ app on Roku, AppleTV, FireTV or YouTube TV. Just search “Atlanta News First” anywhere you stream!

Biden and former President Donald Trump will also be in Atlanta on June 27, 2024, for a historic presidential debate hosted at CNN’s Atlanta’s studios.

The debate will air live on CNN, CNN International, CNN en Español, CNN Max and CNN.com, at 9 p.m.

Both Biden and Trump are the respective, presumptive Democratic and GOP nominees for president, setting the stage for a historic rematch of their 2020 campaigns. They have been polling well within the margins of error for every poll thus far in the election season, making Georgia a virtual toss-up.

articles.title: APD officer charged with murder thought Lyft driver was in ‘gay fraternity’ trying to kidnap him, police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A former Atlanta Police officer accused of murdering a Lyft driver claimed he was hearing voices and thought he was being kidnapped during the ride before the shooting, according to Union City police.

Police said Koby Minor is accused of shooting and killing Reginald Folks, 35, Wednesday after Folks dropped Minor off at his home.

According to police, Minor told officers Folks was driving him home from another Atlanta police officer’s home, when Minor began hearing an “unknown voice” in his ear. He did not tell Union City police what the voice said.

The arrest warrants said Minor told police he believed Folks was in a “gay fraternity” and that Minor believed he was being kidnapped to be recruited into it.

RELATED: Atlanta police officer arrested, charged with murder in Union City, documents say

Minor then asked Folks to stop, but Folks did not. Minor said he tried to get out of the car at a red light at the intersection of State Route 14 Alternate and Stonewall Tell Road.

According to documents, Minor said Folks began to reach for the back seat. Minor responded by firing three shots into Folks’ head. According to police, Folks died at the scene.

Criminal Arrest Warrants for Former APD Officer by Ellie Parker on Scribd

Minor has been charged with murder and aggravated assault. According to police, he resigned from the department Wednesday.

articles.title: Fellow travelers | Inside Sen. Raphael Warnock’s private meeting with the Pope
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - One of Georgia’s best-known pastors is sharing what he discussed with the man leading the largest Christian church on earth.

U.S. Sen. Raphael Warnock of Georgia held a private meeting with Pope Francis, the leader of the Catholic Church, on April 20 at the Vatican. It was part of a trip that involved briefings with the NATO Defense College and the World Food Programme.

Warnock said the two spoke and prayed about humanitarian crises across the globe, including Sudan, Ukraine and Palestinians in Gaza, which is in the midst of a deadly conflict between Israel and Hamas. The senator said Francis, with the help of an interpreter, told him he’s in regular contact with a small congregation of Catholics in Gaza.

“He calls them almost daily and just to check on them,” Warnock said, in an exclusive interview with Atlanta News First Investigates. “As a pastor with a parish, I was just very impressed with that kind of pastoral commitment, that kind of heart.”

Warnock has led Ebenezer Baptist Church - Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s former pastoral home - since 2005. Francis was elected by a papal conclave in 2013 at the age of 76, leading more than 1.3 billion Catholics across the globe.

The senator says the two men of God spoke about their shared faith and helping the needy.

“That’s what guides my work every single day in the Senate,” Warnock said. “I was deeply honored to meet not only the leader of the Catholic Church, but a fellow traveler.”

Do you live in an insulin desert? Warnock hopes to eliminate them

Often revered and criticized as one of the most progressive popes in history, Francis has expressed support to address climate change, immigration and the LGBTQ community.

Warnock believes the Pope’s position on those issues shows his focused on human decency. “That doesn’t mean we always land on the same side of every issue, but what I see in him is an effort to center human dignity,” Warnock said.

The senator said he and the Pope shared a few laughs, but “I’ll keep that between us,” he said.

On Sunday, Pope Francis sits down with 60 Minutes for a wide-ranging and exceedingly rare conversation from his Vatican guest house.

articles.title: Man shot during carjacking, East Point police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A man was hospitalized after being shot during a carjacking, according to East Point police.

Police said the carjacking happened near Virginia Avenue and I-85 southbound. A man was reportedly pumping gas when another man approached him, pulled out a gun and started “making demands for the victim’s vehicle.”

articles.title: Wanted man caught in stolen truck, Gwinnett County police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Gwinnett County police said they arrested a man with outstanding warrants for allegedly stealing a truck.

The Gwinnett County Police Department said officers found the stolen truck on April 30 within hours of it being reported stolen from Jackson County.

Police said they found Timothy Kevin Burke, 46, of Sugar Hill, inside the stolen vehicle in the area of Pass Court in Sugar Hill.

They said Burke had two outstanding warrants from other jurisdictions. He was arrested for the outstanding warrants and a charge of theft by receiving stolen property and was booked into the Gwinnett County Jail.

articles.title: GBI identifies man killed in shooting that wounded three APD officers
articles.content:
Editor’s note: The video is from previous coverage.

ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - The Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI) has identified the man killed in a shooting that left three Atlanta police officers wounded.

On Thursday, the GBI identified the man as 41-year-old Claudy Pierre Jules of Maryland.

Atlanta police officers Jason Hodge, Darien Tabor and Charles Smith were shot during the incident in the Capitol Hill neighborhood in southwest Atlanta on Saturday, May 11.

The Atlanta Police Department said Hodge was treated at the hospital and released. Tabor and Smith both underwent surgery and are recovering.

RELATED: 3 officers shot, suspect dead in Atlanta’s Capitol View neighborhood, police say

The GBI, which is investigating the shooting, said the officers responded to Genessee Avenue and Fairbanks Street SW about a man pointing a gun.

“As officers approached the man, he pulled out a handgun. One of the officers tackled the man and wrestled him to the ground. While on the ground, what sounded like a gunshot could be heard,” the GBI said of the incident. “Three of the responding officers sustained non-life-threatening gunshot wounds.”

Shortly after the shooting, police also said that Jules had a knife.

The GBI said the investigation into the shooting is ongoing. The agency is asking any family members of Jules to contact their Regional Investigative Office in Atlanta at (770) 388-5019.

MORE COVERAGE: Police identify 3 officers shot in Atlanta over weekend; 2 still in hospital

articles.title: Family of Gainesville High baseball player seeking over $700K in wrongful death lawsuit
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - The family of a Gainesville High School (GHS) senior baseball player who died from a batting cage accident is seeking thousands in a wrongful death lawsuit against several of the school’s administrators and athletic staff.

Jeremy Medina, 17, was in a coma from being accidentally hit in the head by a baseball bat while in a batting cage at the high school on Nov. 20, 2023. Medina died on Dec. 11, 2023. Medina was diagnosed with a subarachnoid hemorrhage and other head trauma-related injuries, the lawsuit states.

The family is seeking over $722,000.

Both Principal Jamie Green and Assistant Principal Stacia Dillin were named in the lawsuit. Several athletic staff members — Head Coach Cris Carpenter, Director of Baseball Operations Micah Owings, assistant coaches Jon Mark Ownings and Derek Vaughn, Athletic Director Adam Lindsey, Assistant Athletic Director Adam Miller and trainer Ariauna Washington — were also named in the lawsuit.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE
Gainesville High baseball player dies after batting cage accident
Gainesville High baseball player declared brain dead from batting cage accident, hospital says
Gainesville High baseball player in coma after batting cage accident

The lawsuit claims no school employees or any other adults were there to supervise the practice, which was scheduled during Thanksgiving break.

The lawsuit also claims both administrative and athletic staff failed to operate athletic activities in compliance with rules set by the Georgia High School Athletic Association (GHSA) and the city school system.

“GHSA imposed an absolute, mandatory, and clearly defined duty which specifically required and directed the administrative heads of GHS to operate all athletic activities under direct and complete control of the school administration or designated school personnel,” the lawsuit states.

The lawsuit also states that GHSA has rules and procedures for practices, including from “refraining from holding baseball practices until the start of the season.” The official start of the school’s 2024 baseball season was Jan. 15, according to the lawsuit.

His family filed the lawsuit in Hall County Superior Court.

Atlanta News First reached out to Gainesville City Schools for comment on the lawsuit but has not heard back.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Clayton County inmate allegedly stabs, kills another inmate, sheriff’s office says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A Clayton County Jail inmate is facing more charges after he allegedly stabbed and killed another inmate on Wednesday, according to the county sheriff’s office.

Deputies said the death resulted from a fight between three men. Hakim Shahid, 29, attacked 31-year-old Megale Chadwick unprovoked in the jail’s dayroom around 6 p.m., the sheriff’s office said. Video footage shows him landing punches on top of Chadwick. But then 21-year-old Nicholas Hill allegedly joined from upstairs, stabbing Shahid with a shank made from the building’s structure, according to the sheriff’s office.

Shahid was taken to a local hospital, where he later died. Hill now faces additional charges of felony murder, aggravated assault and possession of prohibited items, according to the sheriff’s office.

Hill previously faced several charges, including riot in a penal institution, aggravated battery and aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.

“Sheriff Levon Allen and the entire Clayton County Sheriff’s Office extend their deepest condolences to the family and loved ones of Mr. Hakim Shahid during this difficult time,” the sheriff’s office said.

Shahid isn’t the only inmate to be killed at the jail this year. On Jan. 4, Abdul Woodard allegedly beat his cellmate to death. He faces charges of felony murder, aggravated assault and simple battery.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE: Clayton County inmate beaten to death by his cellmate, sheriff says

Clayton County Sheriff Levon Allen previously said the jail was overcrowded, with more than 300 inmates sleeping on cell floors.

“When one inmate uses the toilet and the other inmate’s head is down by the toilet, you will have fights. And when you are in a room where everything in the room is steel, metal or concrete, it becomes a deadly cage match,” he said.

In April, former Clayton County Sheriff Victor Hill slammed Allen’s management of the jail on social media. He claimed the sheriff’s office is $14 million over budget while Allen allegedly spent millions of dollars on electric vehicles and thousands on clothing. Hill also said Allen allowed unlimited overtime for friends and family members on the payroll.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE: Former Clayton sheriff Victor Hill criticizes successor over ‘mismanagement’ of county jail; current sheriff responds

Allen fired back, saying Hill’s “love for power overcame his duty to serve the citizens honorably.”

In 2022, Hill was found guilty of violating inmates’ rights and was sentenced to eight months in federal prison, followed by six years of supervised release.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Dispute over car may be motive in deadly Murfreesboro shooting
articles.content:
MURFREESBORO, Tenn. (WSMV) – A dispute over the ownership of a car may have led to a deadly shooting at a gas station in Murfreesboro on Wednesday afternoon.

Devon Loritts, 23, of Georgia, was shot several times during the dispute, according to police, and taken to a local hospital where he died. His brother was shot in the arm but is stable, police said. Detectives have charged 26-year-old Juan Charco, of Antioch, with second-degree murder and attempted second-degree murder in connection to the case. Charco’s brother was interviewed by detectives and released. Charges could be pending as the investigation progresses.

A preliminary investigation shows Loritts had previously purchased a car from Charco. The car was taken from Georgia and eventually tracked to the 7-Eleven Exxon on Joe B. Jackson Parkway in Murfreesboro, where the shooting occurred at about 2:30 p.m.

One of the two people shot and beaten at a Murfreesboro gas station on Wednesday afternoon has died.
PREVIOUS COVERAGE:
Witness recalls Murfreesboro shooting that left 1 dead, 1 injured
1 killed, 1 injured after shooting outside Murfreesboro 7-Eleven

“After the shooting, the Charco brothers began fighting Loritts’ brother who got away and ran inside the store for help,” the media release said. “MPD officers arrived and started emergency medical aid on both shooting victims, putting a tourniquet on the man’s arm to control the bleeding. Murfreesboro Fire Rescue Department firefighters and personnel with Rutherford County Emergency Medical Services took over advanced emergency care.”

Juan Charco is being held in the Rutherford County Adult Detention Center on a $1.5 million bond. A court date is set for July 17 in Rutherford County General Sessions Court.

The case is being investigated by the Murfreesboro Police Department Criminal Investigations Division’s Violent Crime Unit.

articles.title: Man convicted of murder in shooting at DeKalb County gas station, DA says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A Lithonia man was found guilty of murder in a deadly shooting at a gas station last summer, according to the DeKalb County district attorney.

On Wednesday a jury convicted 27-year-old Nathan Weeks of charges including malice murder and felony murder stemming from the fatal shooting of 54-year-old Isaac Godbolt at a gas station in the Stone Mountain area in June 2023, DeKalb County District Attorney Sherry Boston said in a press release Thursday.

Boston said Weeks was also found guilty of aggravated assault and possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony.

On June 20, DeKalb County police responded to a person shot at a gas station on the 4700 block of Redan Road. When they arrived, officers reportedly found Godbolt in his vehicle with multiple gunshot wounds.

RELATED: 26-year-old man in custody in connection to deadly DeKalb Co. shooting

Paramedics took Godbolt to Grady Memorial Hospital, where he died from his injuries.

Boston said surveillance video showed Weeks arrive at the gas station and hang out with a group of people.

Godbolt pulled up in his vehicle and talked to one of the people in the group. Weeks walked over to Godbolt’s car and shot him multiple times as he tried to get out, then ran away.

Investigators said Weeks confessed to the murder in a recorded conversation with his mother.

Weeks was arrested in Columbus. At the time of his arrest, he had a handgun. Prosecutors said testing confirmed the gun fired the shell casings found at the murder scene.

Boston said sentencing will be scheduled in the coming weeks.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: 3 teens killed, 2 others injured in Alpharetta crash, officials say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Three 18-year-olds were killed and two others were injured in a single-vehicle crash in Alpharetta Tuesday night.

The crash happened around 8 p.m. on a bend in the road along Westside Parkway near Maxwell Road.

The Alpharetta Police Department said it appeared the driver lost control of the Honda Accord before crashing into some trees and flipping upside down. Police said they believe speed “may have been a factor in the crash.” That section of the street was closed most of the day Wednesday as officers reconstructed the accident scene as part of their investigation.

Alpharetta police said Sriya Avasarala, a University of Georgia freshman, and Aryan Joshi, an Alpharetta High School senior, died at the scene.

Anvi Sharma, another UGA freshman, died at the hospital on Wednesday morning.

The two others injured, Rithwak Somepalli and Mohammed Liyakath, were taken to North Fulton Hospital for treatment, police said.

Investigators said Somepalli, a Georgia State University student, was the driver of the car. Liyakath is a senior at Alpharetta High School.

The extent of their injuries remained unknown Thursday.

Alpharetta High School is only a week away from graduation. Just hours before the crash, the school held a graduation ceremony practice. In a letter to students and parents, Principal Mike Scheifflee shared mental health and counseling resources.

In a press conference Thursday morning, Lt. Jason Hiott said investigators had not yet determined the vehicle’s speed at the time of the crash.

“There was nothing at the scene to immediately make us think that alcohol was a factor in this,“ Hiott said, adding that the investigation continues. He said it was too early to determine whether the driver might face any charges.

Listening in during the press conference was Meghana Naik, an Alpharetta resident who said her children knew one of the victims.

“I haven’t slept,” she said.

Naik said she plans to urge other parents to use the tragedy as a teaching tool, especially as summertime approaches.

“It’s going to be a lot of beach parties, a lot of pool parties. I don’t know what’s going to be involved in that, but everybody’s going to go home in a car,” she said. “Respect it, respect like it could be a weapon. It could take lives, and that’s exactly what happened.”

This is a developing story. Check back with Atlanta News First for updates.

articles.title: Decatur Planning Commission discusses smoke, tobacco and vape shop regulation
articles.content:
DECATUR, Ga. (Decaturish) - The Decatur Planning Commission discussed Decatur smoke, tobacco and vape shop regulations at their May 14 regular meeting, as reported by Atlanta News First media partner Decaturish.

The meeting was in-person in the City Commission room of Decatur City Hall, 509 N. McDonough St, and over Zoom. The recording of the meeting can be viewed here.

The Community & Economic Development Department requested text amendments to Article 6 and 12 of the Unified Development Ordinance to define the use of smoke, vape and tobacco shops and provide associated regulation and permitting standards.

Said businesses must “have 50% or more of its total display and shelf area dedicated to the retail sale of tobacco, tobacco products and tobacco paraphernalia” and must be located at a minimum of 300 feet from any public schools, private schools, MARTA properties, daycare centers, libraries, churches, and other public locations in the Decatur area. The businesses may not exceed a floor area of more than 2,000 square feet, may only operate from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m., may not feature a drive-up or -thru lane and must remain on the ground floor of their building space only.

Planning commission member Jason Friedlander pointed out that under alcohol sale ordinances, liquor stores may not be within 300 feet of an alcohol rehabilitation center, and questioned whether smoke, tobacco and vape shops should fall under the same requirements. Vice Chair Gregory Chilik dismissed this.

“The rehab of and recovery from alcoholism is a very different situation from someone who might have quit smoking and may be subject to temptation by smelling tobacco smoke,” Chilik said. “It’s in a different class from someone who is recovering from alcohol.”

The commission recommended the request for approval with minor amendments.

In other business:

— The Community & Economic Development Department requested text amendments to Article 6 of the Unified Development Ordinance to clarify the utility services and meters between main buildings and accessory buildings/dwellings. The commission recommended the request for approval

— The Community & Economic Development Department requested text amendments to Articles 6, 7, and 12 of the Unified Development Ordinance to define the use of short-term rentals and provide associated regulation and permitting standards. The commission recommended the request for approval with multiple amendments made, including an amendment that all current operators of legacy rentals must become compliant within 120 days (increased from 90).

The Decatur Planning Commission will next meet on June 11.

articles.title: NASCAR planning in-season tournament in 2025, with opening race in Atlanta
articles.content:
ATLANTA (AP) — Following the lead of the NBA, the NASCAR Cup Series is planning a five-race, bracket-style tournament in the midst of the 2025 season, beginning with a night event at Atlanta Motor Speedway.

The tournament, which comes with a $1 million prize to the winner, is part of a new media rights deal that includes TNT.

The Atlanta-based cable network will broadcast all five races in the tournament, starting with a 400-miler in its home market on June 28, 2025.

“Next year, having $1 million on the line, that’s for sure going to be a goal before the season starts and something that you and your team strategize around and all that,” Kyle Larson said. “I look forward to it. The summer months get stale. Not boring, but it just gets repetitive. You lose some excitement.”

Atlanta, which has produced some of NASCAR’s most thrilling races since the track was redesigned with higher banking, gets the honor of hosting the first tournament race. The remainder of the 36-race schedule will be announced later.

Brandon Hutchison, president and general manager of the Atlanta track, said the venue was eager to host racing after dark after being scheduled for two day races this season. To get the opening event of the new in-season tournament was an added bonus.

“We’ve heard our fans loud and clear,” Hutchison said. “We know that they wanted the night race back. We were excited to even be able to consider being able to give that to them. Then with TNT — a hometown broadcast partner, home track, the first season of the in-season bracket tournament, the first time that’s ever been held in NASCAR — we feel that ... June 28, 2025, is going to be a very exciting time to be at Atlanta Motor Speedway.”

The tournament is patterned after in-season tournaments that are staged by soccer leagues around the world and were brought to the NBA this season. The Los Angeles Lakers won the inaugural event in December, beating Indiana in a title game held in Las Vegas.

The NASCAR tournament will feature the top 32 drivers from three seeding races, which will be held just before the Atlanta race and televised by Amazon Prime.

The drivers will be paired in head-to-head matchups based on seeding, with the winners advancing to the next round in a bracket format that mirrors the NCAA basketball tournaments.

The field of contenders will be reduced to 16 for Race 2, followed by the quarterfinals in Race 3, the semifinals in Race 4 and the final in Race 5.

“It’s never been a better time to be a fan of motorsports, and this new, first-ever in-season tournament will bring a new competitive dynamic to NASCAR’s summer race weekends,” said Craig Barry, executive vice president and chief content officer of TNT Sports.

Hutchison said the Atlanta track will continue to host two races in 2025 though the complete schedule is still pending.

This season, the 1.54-mile oval in suburban Hampton held the second points race of the year on Feb. 25 — a week after the Daytona 500 — that ended with Daniel Suarez edging Ryan Blaney and Kyle Busch in a three-wide photo finish.

Atlanta’s second race of 2024 is set for Sept. 8 as the kickoff to the NASCAR playoffs. Next year, that race will move up to be part of the in-season tournament instead of the playoff.

In a post on X, the social media site formerly known as Twitter, Denny Hamlin called the tournament “such a win for our sport and drivers.” He jokingly added, “I will collect my 1M royalty next season.”

Larson said the tournament will provide a much-needed boost to the doldrums of summer.

“I think this bracket, or whatever you want to call it, is going to add a lot of excitement and more storylines,” he said. “So I love it.”

Osman Sesay, Jr. (left), Al-Hamid Ibrahim Kuyateh (center), and Nazier Lloyd Anderson (right) identified as suspects in murder of 11-year-old Zander Whatley(Paulding County Sheriff's Office)

articles.title: The future of fighting crime: AI helps City of South Fulton Police track and solve crimes
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) -The City of South Fulton is using technological advances to help fight crime.

“You know, it’s odd but when I first got into law enforcement, we didn’t even have computers that we used in our cars and so seeing the evolution of policing is bringing me a great deal of joy,” said Chief Keith Meadows.

He may not have started out with a computer, but Chief Meadows is set on his department having advanced technology.

“We developed a real time crime center, which incorporates surveillance cameras, license plate readers, drones, shot spotter, and other technologies, all into one,” said Captain Brendan O’Neil,” the commander of intelligence and technology.

“Help us be more efficient with how we go about using resources, and putting police officers in the right places,” said Chief Meadows.

All that information is also processed through IBM, thanks to a partnership

“We’re looking to arm our police officers with a high degree of intelligence as they are going out, so that they will be able to respond appropriately in any circumstance,” said Chief Meadows.

“The more information we have, the better we can respond. In the past, we would just have to get to a scene and assess it from there. Now, we have so many tools that we can know what we’re getting into and it’s much safer for the officers and the citizens,” said Captain O’Neil.

Another piece of technology helping officers get to crimes faster: drones and Shot Spotter.

“Shot Spotter are censors strategically placed that can hear gunshots that put them on a map with exactly where the gunshot occurred,” ”said Captain O’Neil.

Those locations and times are saved by IBM and AI helps predict when and where shots could be fired again.

“Technology lets us investigate crimes much quicker, therefore taking offenders off the street more rapidly,” said Captain O’Neil.

articles.title: Metro Atlanta woman raising money for Brazil flood victims, family members
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Monumental flooding in Brazil has led to at least 149 deaths. Dozens more are still missing. Thousands have lost their homes.

The heavy rains started at the end of April and have continued on and off for weeks, causing river levels to rise and overflow in southern Brazil.

Eli Mendes lives in Metro Atlanta, but most of her family lives in Sao Leopoldo.

“I firstly was worried about is everyone alive? Was everyone able to run away,” Mendes said.

Thankfully, everyone in her family survived. But they lost their home and nearly all their belongings in the catastrophic flood. Now they’re living in a shelter.

“I’m afraid they’re going to get sick from the flood, the dirty water,” Mendes said.

As the waters begin to recede, Mendes’ family and thousands more will need help. That’s why she’s raising money to send to South America.

“A little bit, it can help. I don’t know like with 10 dollars or 15 dollars. It’s a lot in Brazil. At least to help them to have a new life,” Mendes’ friend Eva Morais said.

articles.title: Trash piling up at Gwinnett County apartment complex
articles.content:
LILBURN, Ga. (Atlanta News First) — Over the last few weeks, residents say trash has been piling up around the dumpster at the Brentwood Downs apartment complex.

Ebony Fitzpatrick just moved into the apartment complex last fall.

As the garbage grows, she says the smell has become almost unbearable.

“Trash has been piling up and piling up, and it doesn’t seem like it’s being resolved,” Fitzpatrick said. “It just seems like it’s getting bigger.”

The mother of four has spotted all sorts of animals crawling around near the dumpster.

“There’s ducks and goose digging in the trash,” Fitzpatrick said. “Ants, bugs and roaches, it’s disgusting.

Doris Nimley has lived at the apartment complex for over 10 years. She says the dumpster has never looked this bad.

“You pay all this money to be able to be comfortable, to have a peace of mind, and the smell is so overwhelming,” Nimley said.

Another part of the problem is the front gate at Brentwood Downs, which is wide open.

Nimley says this has allowed anyone to drive up and dump their furniture within the complex.

“We pay to have a gated community. The gate doesn’t work,” she said.

The management company for the apartment complex, RPM Living, says the front gate is under repair.

They also told Atlanta News First that their trash compacter broke down last week, causing this buildup. Waste management crews were unable to access the compacter, with two large open bins collecting tons of trash.

Yet, Fitzpatrick doesn’t want to hear any excuses.

“It’s not okay. They need to take care of it,” she said. “If we’re paying for these fees and you’re not taking care of it, then, I mean, where does that leave us, that have to walk by and ride by and look at this every day?”

RPM Living says they plan on clearing out all the trash by Friday morning.

articles.title: Debate between President Joe Biden, Donald Trump to be held in Atlanta
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - In yet another sign that Georgia is one of the most important states in the nation’s political universe, CNN announced Wednesday it will host a debate between President Joe Biden and Donald Trump on June 27, 2024, in the global news network’s Atlanta studio.

The debate will air live on CNN, CNN International, CNN en Español, CNN Max and CNN.com, at 9 p.m.

Both Biden and Trump are the respective, presumptive Democratic and GOP nominees for president, setting the stage for an historic rematch of their 2020 campaigns. They have been polling well within the margins of error for every poll thus far in the election season, making Georgia a virtual toss-up.

In 2020, Biden won Georgia by less than 12,000 votes.

Biden and Trump also have agreed to a second, Sept. 10, 2024, debate hosted by ABC.

The quick agreement on the timetable to meet, according to the Associated Press, followed Biden’s announcement he will not participate in fall presidential debates sponsored by the nonpartisan commission that has organized them for more than three decades. Biden’s campaign instead proposed that media outlets directly organize the debates with both candidates.

CNN said no audience would be present during its debate, and moderators and other details would be announced later. A New York Times/Siena/Philadelphia Inquirer poll released this week shows Trump leading Biden in Georgia and four other critical battleground states.

The polls indicate “an erosion of support for the president among young and nonwhite voters upset about the economy and Gaza,” The New York Times said.

The polls came only days before Biden will become the second sitting American president to deliver Morehouse College’s commencement address, following in the footsteps of his former boss, Barack Obama, who spoke in 2013.

Biden will deliver the address to the private, all-male HBCU on Sunday, May 19, at 9 a.m. His speech will mark the president’s first visit back to the Peach State after a March campaign rally.

But almost immediately after the announcement, students, faculty, and alumni began expressing concern over Biden’s visit to the campus. It was over Biden’s unwillingness to call for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas.

November’s election will be the first presidential electoral rematch since 1956. In 1952, Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower defeated Illinois Gov. Adlai Stevenson after then-President Harry Truman chose not to run for a second full term. Four years later, Democrats again nominated Stevenson for the presidency, which led to a second defeat at then-President Eisenhower’s hands.

Among Republicans, no presidential candidate has ever been nominated for three consecutive elections; Grover Cleveland, a Democrat, was elected president in 1885 and served only one term before being elected to a second term four years later (1885-1889 and 1893-1897). President Franklin Delano Roosevelt holds the record for the most nominations: four.

More details from the Associated Press:

Disagreements about moderators and debate rules were some of the very questions that prompted the formation of the Commission on Presidential Debates in 1987.

The two campaigns and television networks had held weeks of informal talks on ways to circumvent the commission’s grip on presidential debates, owing to years of complaints and perceived slights, according to two people familiar with the matter.

Biden’s campaign had proposed excluding third-party candidates, such as Robert F. Kennedy Jr., from the debates outright. Under the debate commission’s rules, Kennedy or other third-party candidates could qualify if they secured ballot access sufficient to claim 270 Electoral Votes and polled at 15% or higher in a selection of national polls.

Kennedy accused Biden and Trump of “colluding to lock America into a head-to-head match-up that 70% say they do not want.”

“They are trying to exclude me from their debate because they are afraid I would win,” Kennedy said. “Keeping viable candidates off the debate stage undermines democracy.”

CNN held open the door to Kennedy’s participation if he or any other candidate met polling and ballot access requirements similar to the commission’s.

As recently as Wednesday morning, Trump expressed his desire for a large live audience for his debates with Biden.

“I would strongly recommend more than two debates and, for excitement purposes, a very large venue, although Biden is supposedly afraid of crowds - That’s only because he doesn’t get them,” Trump said. “Just tell me when, I’ll be there.”

Trump has been pushing for more debates and earlier debates, arguing voters should be able to see the two men face off well before early voting begins in September. He has repeatedly said he will debate Biden “anytime, anywhere, any place,” even proposing the two men face off outside the Manhattan courthouse where he is currently on criminal trial in a hush money case. He also has been taunting Biden with an empty lectern at some of his rallies.

Trump’s campaign on Wednesday challenged the Biden campaign to agree to at least two other debates between the two candidates, beside the June and September dates. The Biden campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Biden’s campaign has long held a grudge against the nonpartisan commission for failing to evenly apply its rules during the 2020 Biden-Trump matchups — most notably when it didn’t enforce its COVID-19 testing rules on Trump and his entourage.

articles.title: Fulton County leaders backpedal on new jail proposal
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - On Wednesday, Fulton County leaders pulled back on a months-long effort to replace the aging Fulton County Jail with a new facility.

“There’s very little collective support overall for building a new jumbo massive facility that’s going to cost in the billions of dollars,” said Commissioner Bob Ellis. “And I think it’s time for us to have a discussion that really reframes this and gets realistic about what can do, what we can afford, and where we want to collectively move forward as a board.”

The shift comes after County Manager Dick Anderson said state lawmakers showed no interest in pursuing a sales tax to help offset the costs of the new jail.

Without a sales tax, Ellis said the cost burden would fall solely on Fulton County residents.

“I certainly do not support applying significant amounts of new general fund money that will result in raised millage rates for a new facility,” Ellis said during Wednesday’s board of commissioners meeting.

In August 2023, the board voted to move forward with finding funding options for a new jail, estimated to cost $1.7 billion.

In December, the board reviewed the proposal, which included three separate buildings, one dedicated for men, another for women and the third for men’s medical and mental health services.

However, on Wednesday, the board made an abrupt pivot, voting against pursuing a project manager for the planned site.

Commissioner Dana Barrett, who supported moving forward with finding a project manager, said the board is backpedaling on addressing the decades-long crisis at the jail.

ANF INVESTIGATES
How the Fulton County Jail became Georgia’s very own Guantanamo Bay

“There’s no sense in putting a stop to this right now. Once again, it’s slowing things down because we’re looking at a primary (election). We’re looking at a general (election). And people are trying to win votes by keeping taxes low and it’s just a shame,” Barrett said in an interview with Atlanta News First after the vote.

Since August, some commissioners contested that conditions have improved at the jail.

On Wednesday, the county reported that there are no detainees currently sleeping on the ground at any county facility, as was previously the case.

In August 2023, the county had roughly 3,600 people in their jail population. On Wednesday, the county reported a jail population of just below 2,700 people. The county has also invested roughly $13 million in renovating cells at the Rice Street location. Those renovations are expected to be complete by early 2025.

It’s unclear what the next step is for Fulton County should it want to continue pursuing a new jail.

“We have now taken a step back, and it’s incredibly frustrating. I feel like it’s a dereliction of duty for us to not do something about this building that’s falling apart.

In 2022, the Fulton County Sheriff’s Office confiscated more than 1,500 shanks and knives created from parts of the crumbling facility, according to a spokesperson from the Sheriff’s Office.

articles.title: Behind-the-scenes look at MARTA’s Airport Station renovation
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - It’s the first major renovation at MARTA’s Airport Station. Atlanta News First got the exclusive look at the progress before the station reopens.

Since April 8, a shuttle service has connected travelers from College Park Station to and from Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. During that time crews have been working on renovating MARTA’s Airport Station.

Upgrades include everything from new paint to new floors to changes to the tactile strips, which help passengers watch their step as they get on and off the train.

RELATED: MARTA Airport Station to close for 6 weeks during renovations

“The flooring on both levels is our main priority,” said MARTA Senior Project Manager Jermaine White. “We’ve also done a lot with the handrails upstairs, just making sure that we’re going to have this place looking really nice and much safer for everyone.”

MARTA says the six-week closure of the Airport Station saved 17 months of construction time.

“It would’ve been a much longer process where we would only do a small portion of work every night and then shore up that work every night to then be open back up in the morning, so that 17 months was saved by doing just six weeks of work,” said White.

Riders will get a chance to see the changes for themselves when MARTA’s Airport Station reopens on Monday. Until then the shuttle service will continue through Sunday, May 19.

articles.title: Gwinnett police celebrate K-9 retiring after nearly 6 years of service
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Gwinnett County police are celebrating one of their distinguished K-9s as he heads into retirement.

The Gwinnett County Police Department announced Tuesday that K-9 Jekel was retiring from duty on the advice of veterinarians because of a medical issue with one of his legs.

Jekel joined the department in September 2018. He was assigned to Cpl. Jason Woodard, and the two “quickly became a bonded pair both on and off duty,” the department wrote.

Over the next five years, “the duo made a substantial impact on the department’s efforts to make the community a safer place to work, play, and live.”

Jekel was deployed nearly 300 times. He helped the department capture dozens of suspects, including “numerous violent criminals,” locate several missing people, recover 45 items of evidence and seize heaps of illegal drugs.

Gwinnett police said some of Jekel’s noteworthy achievements include more than 5,000 grams of methamphetamine seized in 2018, 500 grams of cocaine seized in 2021, 5 kilos of methamphetamine seized in 2022, and 228 grams of fentanyl and 787 grams of methamphetamine seized in 2022.

Then in late 2023, Woodard noticed that Jekel was struggling with one of his hind legs. After he recently underwent surgery, vets suggested that Jekel retire.

Gwinnett police said Jekel will live out the rest of his life with his best friend, Woodard.

“We wish him a restful retirement,” the department wrote.

articles.title: Gwinnett County police looking for missing 21-year-old woman
articles.content:
BUFORD, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Gwinnett County police are looking for the public’s help finding a missing 21-year-old woman.

Police said Jennifer Ledesma was last seen on the 1300 block of Horizon Parkway in Buford around noon on May 10.

Ledesma’s brother told police he texted and called her several times but that the phone number was no longer a working number. She was supposed to fly to Mexico on May 13 to join their father for a funeral.

Her brother told police that the only thing missing from her room was her shampoo and toothbrush.

In an incident report, Ledesma’s workplace also told police she had not shown up to work.

Ledesma is 5 feet, 7 inches tall and weighs around 150 pounds.

Anyone with information should call 911.

articles.title: Passengers escape using emergency slides after Delta plane catches fire
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (CNN) - A seemingly normal plane trip from Cancun to Seattle quickly turned scary shortly after landing.

Watch as sparks suddenly erupt from the nose of this Delta flight, flames and black smoke begin spouting out.

Passengers and crew were still onboard.

In an effort to get everyone off the airbus, emergency evacuation slides were deployed at the back of the plane.

Just a few moments later you can see passengers start to exit the aircraft and shoot down those slides onto the tarmac as the fire continues to burn up front.

Officials say all the travelers made it off safely and there were no injuries.

By the time firefighters arrived a few minutes later, the blaze was already out but crews hosed it down anyway to be safe.

As for what caused the hot spot officials say a short in an electrical cord attached to the ground power unit is to blame.

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Closing arguments begin in trial for man accused in 2016 Henry County quadruple murders
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Closing arguments began Wednesday in a trial for a quadruple murder in Henry County nearly eight years ago.

If convicted, Matthew Baker faces the death penalty. Baker was 19 years of age when he was arrested and is now 26. His family and others claim he is innocent.

Baker’s mother Angie Lanier and a group of supporters have been in the courtroom since the trial began last week. Lanier told Atlanta News First on Wednesday that she is anxiously awaiting the outcome.

“I just hope the jury sees the truth and sees there’s no evidence, it’s been proven in court there’s no evidence,” Lanier said Wednesday.

This started nearly eight years ago in 2016, when four young people were killed at a farmhouse during a bonfire. Destiny Olinger, Keith Gibson, Sophia Bullard and Matthew Hicks were shot during a possible disagreement, police said at the time. Baker was at the scene that night with his friend Jacob Kosky, according to reports. Kosky later confessed to the murders, but Baker, who was with him, was held as an accessory to the crime.

Kosky is serving life in prison and testified on Tuesday.

“I’m praying in the courtroom, praying for the victims’ families, praying for Kosky, I’m just praying for everybody,” Lanier previously said. “I’m fighting for my child, and I told them that I will fight until I have my last breath.”

Copyright 2024 WANF. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Sandy Springs school issues statement after Hitler assignment controversy
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A metro Atlanta school is responding to backlash to a controversial assignment.

Parents are fuming and questioning the Mount Vernon School in Sandy Springs after their kids were asked about Hitler’s leadership.

The assignment asked students to rate the attributes of the former Nazi dictator. The school now acknowledges this caused distress and the assignment has now been removed from the curriculum.

Head of School Kristy Lundstrom sent the following statement to Mount Vernon parents:

Dear Mount Vernon Family,

I am aware that a screenshot is being circulated on social media and has caused concern and distress. The screenshot is a snapshot taken out of context from a classroom assignment from March 2024. We do not condone positive labels for Adolf Hitler. The intent of the assignment was an exploration of World War II designed to boost student knowledge of factual events and understand the manipulation of fear leveraged by Adolf Hitler in connection to the Treaty of Versailles. When leadership was made aware of how the assignment was written it was removed from the curriculum.

Immediately following this incident, I met with the School’s Chief of Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Action, Head of Middle School, and a concerned Rabbi and friend of the School who shared the perspective of some of our families and supported us in a thorough review of the assignment and community impact. We worked to understand the balance of holding a safe environment for students while doing the important work of sharing history to prevent deniers and to be clear about the atrocities committed. Adolf Hitler and the events of this time period are difficult and traumatic to discuss.

In this very heavy time, when our Jewish students and families have the added stress of world events, we want to be clear that The Mount Vernon School wholeheartedly denounces antisemitism.

Our commitment is to embrace a diverse community where every individual is seen, valued, and heard. Please know that we are here to care for and support your children. We have counselors, faith leaders, and school leaders who have been and will continue to be here to talk to, listen to, and lift up your children.

Kristy Lundstrom

articles.title: California man pleads guilty to Stone Mountain murder, sentenced to life, district attorney says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A California man has been sentenced to life in prison after pleading guilty to a murder outside a Stone Mountain nail salon, according to the Cherokee District Attorney.

According to the district attorney, Tychicus Cameron Wilson, 35, shot and killed Anthony Jordan, Jr., 29, on June 12, 2018 outside a hair salon on the 5600 block of Redan Road in Stone Mountain.

Jordan was standing outside the salon around 5:15 p.m. when Wilson pulled up in a car and shot four times. The district attorney said two shots hit Jordan and the other two went into the hair salon. Another person was injured by flying glass and a third suffered a graze wound. Jordan was taken to Grady Memorial Hospital, where he later died.

The district attorney said Wilson was seen in a gas station convenience store near the salon shortly before the murder.

Wilson was arrested two weeks later in Los Angeles on a parole violation and was later convicted of possession of a firearm by a convicted felon. He was extradited to Georgia after serving his time in California.

Wilson pleaded guilty to two counts of malice murder, felony murder, aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.

He was then sentenced to life in prison.

articles.title: A deadly gap | More than 100 insulin deserts plague Georgia diabetics
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Charlene Davis sleeps on her living room floor in Atlanta to help ease her back pain and make it easier to access a drawer full of drugs to help keep her alive.

Over the past few years, doctors amputated fingers from her left hand and implanted a heart monitor. Davis said it’s all connected to a chronic disease she’s had since 2008: type two diabetes.

The 58-year-said said managing her insulin and other medications takes hours day. “It’s a second job trying to move the medicine, make sure I have a prescription, make sure I have refills,” she said.

Davis has insurance but relies on manufacturer coupons to afford her insulin at $35 a month to manage her diabetes. Without the discount, Davis estimates her insulin would cost about $500 a month.

Davis worries each day the pharmaceutical companies could rescind their discounts at any time. “It would be hard,” she said. “We don’t have a lot now, but we really wouldn’t have anything at that point.”

A survey conducted by the Yale Diabetes Center in 2017 found one in four people reported rationing their insulin due to financial reasons. Davis hasn’t needed to ration insulin yet, but she does reuse needles to save money.

Congress recently capped the cost of insulin at $35 a month for seniors on Medicare, but it doesn’t cover diabetics like Davis, who has private insurance.

According to a bipartisan U.S. Senate report released earlier this year, Davis is one of millions of Americans who live in or around insulin deserts across the country. The report identified 813 of these deserts, which the report defines as counties with high rates of diabetes and the uninsured.

The majority of the deserts are concentrated in the southeast. In Georgia, there are more than 100.

U.S. Sens. Raphael Warnock of Georgia and John Neely Kennedy (R-Louisiana) produced the report and co-sponsored the Affordable Insulin Now Act of 2023, legislation that would cap the price of insulin for everyone at $35 a month.

On the Senate floor this past November, Warnock shared a story about a constituent with diabetes who bought insulin from strangers she met on Facebook groups, meeting up at Chick-Fil-A restaurants at night.

“These are the kind of stories I’ve heard in my state and across the country and I’m glad that we’re on the path to doing something about it,” Warnock told Atlanta News First Investigates in an exclusive interview.

Lacy McGee is the constituent Warnock mentioned on the Senate floor. She attended the 2023 State of the Union address as Warnock’s guest to raise awareness about insulin price disparities.

McGee can now afford the medication thanks to her husband’s insurance, but said “there’s still a big gap for people that are between jobs or don’t have insurance and a deadly gap in many cases.”

The largest insulin manufacturers - Sanofi, Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk - recently reduced the cost of insulin, but it’s a voluntary move. Warnock wants that price cap the law of the land, and believes he can get the legislation passed the finish line. It failed to pass in the Senate by just three votes last year. “I’m seeing hopeful signs,” Warnock said. “I’m under no false pretenses that any of this is easy.”

In a Congress seemingly perpetually gridlocked, Davis hopes lawmakers can prioritize what’s important for some of their most vulnerable constituents. “You need to think about the little people and how it affects them and the impact that it has not only on their pockets but on their health,” she said.

Atlanta News First Investigates reached out to the nation’s top three insulin manufacturers for comment on this issue. Here are their responses:

Sanofi

The company did not specifically respond to the proposed legislation, but provided a statement reiterating its commitment to cutting insulin prices. “Sanofi believes insulin should be affordable for all patients, which is why we have a suite of industry-leading support programs to ensure no patient has to pay more than $35 for their Sanofi insulin,” said a spokesperson. Learn more about the company’s discount program.

Novo Nordisk

The company said it is “aware of the [Affordable Insulin Now Act of 2023] legislation and currently reviewing it,” a company spokesperson said. “We recognize that not all patient situations are the same and we have a number of different insulin affordability offerings available through NovoCare.” Learn more about the company’s discount program.

Eli Lilly

The company did not respond to Atlanta News First Investigates’ request for comment about the pending legislation, but issued a press release in March 2023 about its voluntary decision to cap its costs at $35 a month. “We are driving for change in repricing older insulins, but we know that 7 out of 10 Americans don’t use Lilly insulin,” said David A. Ricks, chair and CEO. “We are calling on policymakers, employers and others to join us in making insulin more affordable.” Learn more about the company’s discount program.

articles.title: 2 women arrested for felony shoplifting, multiple outstanding warrants, Gwinnett County police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Two women, both of whom were already wanted on multiple outstanding warrants, were arrested in Buford on felony shoplifting charges, according to the Gwinnett County Police Department.

On Wednesday, May 8, Gwinnett police responded to a reported shoplifting at the Target located at 3205 Woodward Crossing Blvd.

Officers arrested Demesha Latoya Brown, 30, of Decatur, and Angelique Breshawn Reddick-Gautam, 30, of Atlanta.

Police said the two are suspected of shoplifting the day of their arrest and several weeks before. They also reportedly had six outstanding warrants from other jurisdictions for charges, including shoplifting and retail property fencing.

The suspects were arrested and taken to the Gwinnett County police headquarters, where they were interviewed by detectives. They were both booked at the Gwinnett County Jail after the interviews, according to police.

Brown was charged with felony theft by shoplifting and criminal attempt to commit a felony. Reddick-Gautam was charged with felony theft by shoplifting, criminal attempt to commit a felony and giving a false name to law enforcement.

Police said more charges could be forthcoming as detectives review evidence.

articles.title: Jonesboro youth shelter employee convicted of raping 15-year-old, attorney general says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - An employee at a Jonesboro youth shelter has been convicted of statutory rape and first-degree sexual contact by an employee, Georgia’s attorney general announced Wednesday.

Caleb Randolph, 27, pled guilty to both charges last Thursday, Attorney General Chris Carr said. The man from Macon had a sexual relationship with a 15-year-old girl at Rainbow House, which has since been closed, the attorney general said.

Randolph was sentenced to 30 years, with 17 in prison and the rest on “strict probation,” Carr said. He will also be required to register as a sex offender.

PREVIOUS COVERAGE: 3 Georgia youth shelter workers charged with child sex crimes, police say

“Caleb Randolph was put in a position to care for our state’s most vulnerable children, and instead, he sexually abused a 15-year-old female desperately in need of comfort, support and safety,” Carr said. “For months, he groomed his victim by exploiting her vulnerabilities, and his actions are reprehensible. Rest assured that our case does not end here, and we will continue to pursue any individual who commits or perpetuates child sexual exploitation in Georgia.”

Randolph is the son of Mia Chanel Kimber, formerly the facility’s executive director. Kimber and Monica Jones, the facility’s program director, allegedly didn’t report the incident to law enforcement. Instead, they created a cover-up scheme where the teenager was removed from the facility under false allegations, Clayton County police said.

Caleb Randolph, 27, pled guilty to statutory rape and first-degree sexual contact by an employee. Randolph is the son of Mia Chanel Kimber, formerly the facility’s executive director. Kimber and Monica Jones, the facility’s program director, allegedly didn’t report the incident to law enforcement. Instead, they created a cover-up scheme where the teenager was removed from the facility under false allegations, Clayton County police said. Kimber and Jones face several charges, including failure to report and being a party to the crimes of child molestation, statutory rape and more.(WANF)

According to officials, Randolph was fired but re-hired a week and a half later. But the alleged plan fell apart on March 15, 2023, when an anonymous tipster contacted Clayton County police.

Kimber and Jones face several charges, including failure to report and being a party to the crimes of child molestation and statutory rape, among others.

articles.title: BBB says corporate landlord has 1,800+ complaints in 3 years
articles.content:
SNELLVILLE, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - A Snellville mom and first-time renter said her decision to lease from a corporate landlord was a big mistake.

Amanda Shelton’s rental house is for herself and her two boys. She’s a finance manager and has a small candle making business on the side.

Shelton admitted she missed obvious clues when renting a split-level ranch from Main Street Renewal, a subsidiary of Amherst based in Austin, Texas.

Main Street Renewal is privately held by investors and owns 45,000 homes in 32 U.S. markets.

“Amherst is a vertically integrated real estate investment, development, and operating platform that aims to reimagine some of the most fragmented and inefficient pockets of U.S. real estate, including single-family residential, mortgage-backed securities, and commercial real estate,” Amherst claims on its website.

After making several maintenance requests to prevent her bedroom ceiling from collapsing, Shelton claims the company did not respond to her requests for assistance. Three weeks later, the ceiling collapsed while she was in her bathroom getting ready for work. She called her employer to tell them she’d be late.

“I ran out of the house with sweatpants, wet hair, and a t-shirt and told them to have some grace and mercy for the day because this is what you are going to get,” Shelton said.

After the collapse, Shelton said she waited three weeks for repairs. When she tried to keep her TV from falling from the ceiling, it got damaged.

“I tried to catch it, and when I did it literally fell forward and hit me on my head,” Shelton said.

Shelton said she even threatened a lawsuit. She said Main Street Renewal hired a “nice couple” to repair the ceiling, but now she said the other side of the ceiling is starting to go.

Previous coverage from Better Call Harry
‘Make it right’ | Family continues fighting rental company over moldy, ruined furniture

It’s not her first disaster. In August 2023, Shelton said the basement sump pump failed, sending water and raw sewage into her son’s bedroom. She hired a remediation company and paid $650 for the cleanup. Shelton claimed a Main Street Renewal subcontractor said he could not start the job for seven days.

“If they don’t show up to do the job, I have to get the job done,” Shelton said. “I have to do something. What am I going to do? Just sit in a house with water piling up and building? I couldn’t even get a call back from Main Street.”

Shelton said Main Street Renewal denied her reimbursement claim and the cleaning fee she paid for the damaged ceiling.

Then, on Mother’s Day weekend, it happened again. The sump pump failed, and water and sewage back flowed into the basement.

“I think Main Street (Renewal) needs to figure out their maintenance issues and take people a little more seriously,” Shelton said.

The Better Business Bureau has issued an alert about Main Street Renewal and logged 1,850 complaints in the last three years.

Atlanta News First Investigates reached out to Main Street Renewal and its parent company Amherst. We received the below response.

We worked directly with the resident to resolve the issues with the property, and have credited them for the expenses incurred for their temporary relocation and other out-of-pocket costs. We take any concern raised by our residents seriously, and look forward to continuing to serve and support our residents in the Atlanta area.

Main Street Renewal Spokesperson

articles.title: Downtown Atlanta foot traffic increasing, new data shows
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Downtown Atlanta is becoming more popular and seeing more visitors, new data shows.

Researchers from the University of Toronto studied data from 64 cities. The data was collected from March 2023 to February 2024. Atlanta came in at 29th with 7.4% more visitors during that time frame.

Downtown Atlanta is in the middle of a resurgence.

articles.title: 80-year-old man diagnosed with schizophrenia missing in Griffin, police say
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Police in Griffin are seeking the public’s help finding a missing 80-year-old man who was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.

The Griffin Police Department said Sheldon Pressie walked away from the Griffin Manor assisted living facility around 8:30 a.m. Wednesday.

Police said Pressie has been “diagnosed as bi-polar schizophrenic.”

He was last seen wearing a black and white plaid shirt, a gray jacket and black pants.

Anyone who knows his whereabouts is asked to call 911.

articles.title: Car rams into school bus in Spalding County during morning pickup, district says
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) — Two people, including a 9-year-old, were injured when a car hit the back of a school bus in Spalding County as it was picking up students Wednesday morning, according to Georgia State Patrol (GSP).

Deputies said the crash was at the intersection of Teamon Road and Smoak Road in Griffin, which is close to the Eagle’s Landing at Griffin church. According to the sheriff’s office, only three high school students were on the bus and none of them were hurt, the Griffin-Spalding County School District said.

GSP was called to investigate. The agency said the car “was unable to stop” and crashed into the back of the bus. The driver and a 9-year-old passenger in the car sustained non-life-threatening injuries and were taken to an area hospital.

The car’s front was badly damaged, and it had to be towed away.

GSP said the bus was displaying its lights and stop sign at the time of the crash.

articles.title: Heavy police presence in Marietta as officers look for missing juvenile
articles.content:
ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - There is a “significant police presence” in Marietta Wednesday morning as Cobb County police look for a missing juvenile, the department said.

Officers from several units are at 3125 Sewell Mill Road, which is by the Eastminster Presbyterian Church of Marietta.

Reed Springer, 17, left his house shortly after 12:30 p.m. on Tuesday and was reported missing around 8 p.m. Police said he is described as 6 feet, 2 inches, weighs 175 pounds and has brown eyes and was last seen wearing a grey and brown jacket, black shorts and black shoes. Police said he is mildly autistic and hearing impaired.

Police are asking the public to avoid the area until further notice.

This is a developing story. Check back with Atlanta News First for updates.
