articles.title: Court documents reveal gruesome details of Georgetown Blvd. homicide in Lansing
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Court documents obtained by News 10 reveal new details about the death of a 25-year-old on Georgetown Blvd that happened on May 12.

At around 7 a.m. on May 12, police responded to a physical altercation between Zacarri Marquise Taylor, 25, and several others near the 2100 block of Georgetown Boulevard.

Officers learned Taylor was taken from a home to an unknown location by multiple suspects, and the man could be seriously injured. Officials later found Taylor dismembered at an undisclosed location.

Previous Coverage:

25-year-old man killed on Georgetown Blvd in Lansing
‘High probability of additional arrests to come’ in Georgetown Blvd homicide, says Lansing Police Chief

Court documents reveal that a witness saw Leonard Felton Hayes, along with his brother, Marcus Lee Hayes, get into a fight with the victim that appeared to result in their death.

Documents state that in a video capturing the altercation, Leonard Hayes can be seen physically fighting the victim after being hit by them. The video then showed Leonard Hayes strangling the victim on the floor of the living room of the Georgetown Blvd. apartment.

The victim was seen signaling to forfeit the fight and then became unresponsive. Leonard Hayes continued to strangle the victim.

In the documents, Marcus Hayes stated that he proceeded to strangle the victim after Leonard and then helped him get the victim out of view of the known camera in the apartment into the kitchen.

Officials said Leonard Hayes wrapped the victim in a bed sheet and then carried the victim to his car, where Marcus Hayes stated he rode in the rear passenger seat with the victim lying across the backseat.

Marcus stated that they picked up a third person, Terrence James Jones, who sat in the front passenger seat, and he suggested directing them to the residence of an associate of Jones on Malcolm X Street.

Marcus Hayes said in the documents that they brought the victim’s body into the basement of the home, where they discussed whether or not to burn the body.

Leonard Hayes stated in the court documents that the body would be dismembered, and the men agreed so. The body was dismembered by Marcus Hayes, according to documents.

A search warrant was obtained, and the body was eventually found dismembered, a gruesome detail in the case that’s now being handled by Ingham County Prosecutor John Dewane’s office.

“Whether it’s dismembering, setting it afire, discarding it in a landfill, or anything like that nature,” Dewane told News 10. “So it doesn’t surprise me that a person who has the ability to murder somebody, would take the body and try to make it disappear.”

Dewane said because the case is pending, and the prosecution is just getting started, it’s difficult for him to comment on the details, but based on what he’s learned so far he said it’s “very graphic, and it’s disturbing to hear what occurred in that case.”

Documents state that Leonard Hayes has convictions for a controlled substance in 2007, CCW, and felony possession in 2018, and a firearm discharge in a building in 2018.

Marcus Hayes has multiple convictions, including fraud charges and controlled substance violations.

Terrance Jones has been convicted of armed robbery and homicide in 2006, as well as two counts of assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm in 2020.

“My goal is to ensure that victims have their day in court and that they’re heard,” Dewane said. “And if you commit serious violence in our community, you’ll be held accountable by my office.”

The Hayes brothers and their alleged accomplice, Jones, are expected to be back in court May 31 to determine if there is enough evidence to send the case to trial.

articles.title: State, MSU helping farmers address climate change
articles.content:
EAST LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - We rely on our farmers to produce fresh fruits and vegetables, and they rely on the weather to keep the fresh foods coming. A new partnership between Michigan State University (MSU) and the State Department of Agriculture is working to address challenges in farming.

This new partnership aims to help farmers adjust their practices to climate change. To this end, the state of Michigan granted MSU’s New Agricultural Climate Resiliency Program $5 million to fund four projects. The funds for agricultural research will be released to MSU over three years.

That includes developing climate-smart technology to optimize irrigation, cropping systems, and pest management. Agriculture experts say this is a long-term experiment to solve the challenges of the future.

“Whether it be extreme precipitation, whether it be drought,” said George Smith. Or an unexpected early frost. All types of weather conditions that can destroy crops and put a pause on your next salad.

George Smith, with the Michigan State AgBioResearch, says new state funding will benefit agriculture’s future.

“These innovations are gonna help keep our agriculture industries in business because they need solutions, and it’s a really tough time for agriculture right now,” said Smith.

Hillcrest Farms has provided fresh produce for more than 20 years.

“In the beginning, production was predictable,” said Mark Kastner. “You could pretty much predict the weather and you could grow around or in harmony with the weather. Climate change has changed. Now we grow on our own schedule, and we adapt our protection to protect us against the weather changes.”

Kastner now plants his crops inside greenhouses to protect against changes in weather.

“We’re seeing the effects of climate change in real-time now,” said Tim Boring, Michigan Department of Agriculture and Development. “And that poses a unique challenge to a state like Michigan with a really diversified cropping system.”

The funds will also protect the quality of Michigan water, which Smith says will be important for future generations.

“Michigan is the most diverse agricultural state in the country with a reliable source of water,” said Smith. “We can’t take that for granted, and we have to make sure we utilize the water we have efficiently.”

Agriculture experts say Michigan is heading in the right direction when it comes to agriculture, as the state ranks sixth in the nation for total production.

articles.title: Local superheroes try to recoup losses after trailer catches fire
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - You may have heard of the local superheroes from Michigan’s League of Enchantment. It’s a group of about 20 people who wear superhero costumes and go to local hospitals, spreading smiles to sick children in Mid-Michigan.

The organization was moving when a trailer carrying more than $40,000 worth of items blew a tire and caught fire. Costumes, computers, and toys for hospital care packages were destroyed.

(WILX)

Now, the league needs some help of their own as they try to get back to bringing joy to kids.

The non-profit is made up of people who live and work in Lansing, like President Shamus Smith.

On Wednesday, Smith told News 10 how the fire started.

“We were moving all of our items from our storage area in Dewitt to our new office in Leslie.”

Smith said there were “large storage totes filled with toys that we sort and take to the hospitals with us on our visits.” He said just south of Holt Road, he started to notice smoke coming from the back of the moving trailer.

“I pulled over and walked back to see what was going on. Flames were shooting out of the fender well. I kind of went into rush mode. Ran around the back thinking I could put it out. Opened up the backdoor, got hit by a wall of flames and smoke.”

Smith said his arms and legs are a bit singed, but his wife, Katie, also known as Wonder Woman, said the real damage was done to the items inside the trailer.

“Just so much cause we had already taken some of our care packages out, but this was probably 40 to 50 percent of what we had left. Just trying to stuff in the trailer, trying to make sure that we made this run really worth it, and yeah, just lost everything.”

Katie said, “There were thousands of comic books in there.”

She called it a mix of emotions. “There were a lot of memories in that trailer, lot of things that we can’t replace. But then the overwhelming support from the community has just been absolutely amazing.”

Smith said they have an Amazon Wish List.

Multiple toy drives have been set up in the community to gather toys and other items so the league can continue their mission. You can donate items to the following businesses:

Summit Comics and Games

articles.title: Experts say Canada wildfires could impact US and your health
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Canadian wildfires have reached the northern and central United States.

Last year, air quality alerts in Michigan lasted several days due to the hazy smokey air. And there is potential for the smoke to return this year.

Keeping track of air quality and the health impact of the smoke is important, even if the wildfires are not as bad as last year.

Many Michiganders are already dealing with seasonal allergies. But the EPA says these wildfires carry a mixture of pollutants that will also make you cough and wheeze, making it difficult to breathe.

Canada’s wildfire season is already affecting the US. Smoke has moved into neighboring states and it’s only a matter of time until heavier smoke hits Michigan.

“We saw just a tremendous amount of smoke that came from all the wildfires that burned last year come into our region, and that’s something that we will have to watch out for again this year,” said First Alert meteorologist Colton Cichoracki.

Cichoracki says these wildfires are a result of mild winters in Canada along with dry weather.

“You need rain, you need snow, you need cooler temperatures, and they just haven’t seen a lot of that over the past few years in Canada,” said Cichoracki.

Robert Wahl, a public health professor at Michigan State University, says whatever’s in the fire’s path is going to burn. This includes chemicals and what Michigan’s Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy calls volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Exposure to these pollutants can lead to a variety of health effects.

“People who have asthma are more likely to have asthma exacerbation or have their asthma triggered. If you have underlying heart conditions, you’re more likely to have a heart attack,” said Wahl.

“It can change your lung function, how well you can breathe, how well you exchange your oxygen,” said Karen Barker of UM Health Sparrow Carson.

If wildfire smoke hits Mid-Michigan, some people may experience symptoms that mimic seasonal allergies. Young children, those over 65, and people with lung and heart conditions are most at risk. Barker says to keep an eye out for air quality alerts and remain cautious.

“Stay inside, use your air conditioning, and if you have to go out, limit your time and activities,” said Barker.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has a mobile app called AirNow. It provides daily air quality updates—including a map—and information on active wildfires.

Right now, state-issued air quality alerts, because of smoke coming from Canada, include Montana, North and South Dakota, and Minnesota, as well as parts of Wisconsin and Iowa. Michigan has not issued an alert at this point.

articles.title: Drowning deaths are on the rise, according to CDC study
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Drowning deaths are on the rise after decades of decline, and the number has increased by 500 deaths from 2019 to 2022, according to the Centers for Disease Control.

The study found that 40 million adults in the United States don’t know how to swim, and over half of adults have never taken a swimming lesson.

“The CDC stating that teaching swim lessons directly correlates with saving lives completely aligns with what the YMCA believes about the importance of water safety,” said Megan Hunt, the Executive Program Director at the YMCA in Jackson.

Children 1 to 4 years old, adults 65 years and older, and black people of all ages are at higher risk as they have seen the largest increase in drowning deaths.

“For the most part people will think “I learned how to swim I can handle any situation” but that’s not the case, people usually overestimate their abilities. Yes, we want everyone to know how to swim but we want people to understand knowing how to swim doesn’t substitute proper supervision of children or even teenagers,” said Dave Benjamin, the co-founder of Great Lakes Surf Rescue Project.

The CDC says water training is vital, not only for children but for their parents as well. Drowning is one of the three leading causes of unintentional deaths for people 5 to 34 years old.

“We have a lot of parents that sign their kids up for swim lessons and then they’ll say you know what I don’t know how to swim either. We recognize that sometimes being afraid of water or uncomfortable around water is not just children that feel that way but adults too,” said Hunt.

The study found that swim lessons were a proven way to prevent drowning, but disparities like a lack of access to lessons, lessons being too expensive, and historical factors prevent the people who need lessons from getting them. Organizations like the YMCA are working to close that gap during May, Water Safety Month.

“Our free water safety program in May really focuses on teaching kids to think about what it means to be safe around water but also teaching parents about what it means to be safe around water,” said Hunt.

Water safety activists are pushing for a water safety curriculum in schools nationwide. A bill that was introduced in the Michigan Senate would require public schools to teach students water safety.

articles.title: BWL peregrine falcons get named, banded
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Two peregrine falcons that nest on top of Lansing’s Board of Water and Light (BWL) recently saw their four eggs hatch. At just four weeks old, the babies have now been banded and named.

The Falcon family welcomed three males and one female. Their names are Sonic, Blue, Asher and Marty.

The nest has been on top of BWL’s Eckert power station since 2004, and the Michigan Department of Natural Resources (DNR) has been banding the falcon chicks since 2008. Banding helps track the birds when they become adults.

This banding process was special, as it was the last one the DNR would do in Michigan.

Dina Maneval, also known as “the falcon lady,” has been helping the peregrines since the beginning of 2004. She is now able to see her efforts come full circle.

“They started to lay their eggs up at our roof area,” Maneval said. “I noticed in 2004 that it’s the peregrine falcon, and I said, ‘ok, we’re gonna protect these guys.’”

The peregrine falcon, the fastest creature on earth, was on the endangered species list of Michigan since 1970. Wildlife biologist Chad Fedewa says they have now been downlisted from an endangered species to a threatened species.

“It’s a good thing that they’re being downlisted, and efforts like this aren’t needed anymore,” Fedewa said.

BWL has been helping the falcon’s nest for 20 years. Even though future falcons won’t be banded, BWL will continue to be a home for them for years to come.

Fedewa said all four falcons are healthy and will be ready to leave the nest in three weeks.

articles.title: New website aims to increase community involvement in Lansing

LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Civics students at Michigan State University (MSU) have created a website called the “Lansing Citizens Manual.” The goal is to get more young people involved in their community and local government.

As part of their coursework, the students who created the website wondered why young people aren’t more involved in local politics.

“One of those explanations is that young people don’t see themselves represented in civic institutions, or they don’t see themselves as meaningful participants in the democratic story,” said Nicolas Babarskis, an MSU PHD Student who was closely involved with the websites creation.

Hoping to change that view, about 20 MSU students and their professor, Sarah Reckhow, created the website. It provides information about getting involved, local history, and even a game where players can solve problems throughout the city.

“One of my students did an amazing job pulling together all these resources of local organizations that involve youth in Lansing. So many different organizations focus on service or engagement or interest,” said Reckhow.

The team held a focus group at Lansing Eastern High School, and their students later tested out the completed website. Social studies teacher Sarah Graham says it’s a tool that people, both young and old, could benefit from.

“Especially at the city level, ‘cause so much of our civics education is federal, and that’s important, and state is important too, but local is really what affects our day-to-day life,” said Graham.

A semester-long project inspired by a similar manual created for the city of Detroit.

“There’s an awareness that we need young people to be more engaged in our politics,” said Reckhow.

Hoping to show Lansing teens how to make their voices count. Reckhow says they plan to keep adding to the website and updating it based on feedback.

articles.title: Over $6 million project to restore Moores Park Pool begins
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Moores Park has seen better days and will soon see even better.

The City of Lansing is following through on its plan to restore and reopen the historic Moores Park Pool.

Moores Park Pool has gone through several phases. Now, restoration is finally here, and News 10 has the details. This is a major effort to restore the pool to its former glory.

After months of conversations around construction, designs, and a community-led clean-up, Moores Park Pool is now entering its restoration process.

“We have met so many people who are like, I used to swim in that when I was a kid. I used to sit on the benches waiting in line. So many memories from Lansing residents,” said Emily Steves of Lansing Parks and Recreation.

The century-old pool and its unique shape and design make it an important part of Lansing’s history.

“Wesley Bintz was the city engineer for the City of Lansing, and he designed that pool. So, that’s what makes it significant to us because it kind of the first of many,” said Stevens.

What makes Moores Park Pool so unique are the bathrooms beneath the pool. In 2019, the city noticed that the pool began to leak, forcing them to close the pool. Over $6 million later, Moores Park Pool is getting a new life. Brett Tripp, general manager of Rhino Construction, says restoring the pool has been a team effort, from the community clean-up to local contractors joining in to repair the pool.

“Within this renovation, more than 50% is local Lansing-based contractors. It’ll get all new plumbing, it’ll get all new mechanical, it’ll get all new electrical, it’ll get an entirely all-new pool surface,” said Tripp.

The city’s goal is to keep the pool’s 1920s look, and it plans to use every penny of the over $6 million to restore every detail.

“People are like, it can’t be that much, but it is especially historic, but the city is, we are committed to making sure we get there,” said Stevens.

“There’s this custom concrete pickets; all the broken ones will be replaced. All the globes, you can see the pictures of the pool in its hay day. Had these beautiful globes on top, all of those will be restored,” said Tripp.

As rehab begins, everyone has the same hope—a pool filled with not only water but also people, and 100 more years of memories.

Rhino Construction said the pool’s rebuild begins on Wednesday. It is expected to reopen in the summer of 2025. Ortiz was arrested and transferred to a local hospital to treat his gunshot wound. Two officers and the suspect received non-life-threatening injuries in the shooting.

Lansing Police released bodycam footage of the incident on April 19.

(Michigan Department of Corrections)

U.S. Attorney for the Western District of Michigan Mark Totten announced on Tuesday Ortiz was charged with being a felon in possession of firearms.

“Today’s charge reflects our continued efforts to keep the streets safe from the danger presented by those who cannot lawfully possess firearms,” said Totten. “I’m thankful that the officers on scene were able to minimize the damage caused and that everyone is safe.”

Ortiz allegedly possessed two firearms on April 10, when he could not lawfully do so following a previous felony conviction. His initial appearance in the Western District of Michigan is scheduled for May 20, 2024.

articles.title: State housing policy conference met with protests calling for cheaper rent
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX/WNEM/WLUC) - Protesters gathered in Lansing Tuesday, demanding state officials do something about the rising rent and home prices.

Since the Pandemic, renters and first-time homebuyers in Michigan have struggled to find something affordable. According to Rent.com, Michiganders, on average, are nearly paying an extra $300 a month for rent since the Pandemic hit in 2020.

Protesters, part of the Rent is Too Damn High Coalition gathered outside the Building Michigan Communities Conference Tuesday, where state officials and leaders in the housing industry met to discuss ways to solve the state’s ongoing housing crisis.

Protesters say their goal is to bring awareness to the issue and demand laws currently being considered by the legislature that would protect renters’ rights be passed. The proposed legislation would prevent landlords from hiking rents too high, give renters counsel during the eviction process and prevent a landlord’s ability to withhold a lease based on the person’s income or if they’ve previously been incarcerated.

From March 2023 to March 2024, Michigan saw the second-largest spike in rent prices in the country. The nearly 10 percent increase has Michiganders, on average, paying an extra $97 a month. One of the protesters, Vonettea Sanders, said she’s looking for a new place to live after her housing community of nearly a decade raised rent to a rate she couldn’t afford.

“I’m being priced out and pushed out through eviction. These landlords have too much power, and our politicians have an opportunity to change what’s going on and they’re not doing anything about it,” Sanders claimed.

The Michigan State Housing Development Authority’s Josh Pugh said they are working with lawmakers to try and secure more funding for affordable housing. He also pointed to investments made last year where they gave out $1.2 billion for affordable housing and first-time homebuyers with plans to give out even more this year.

“Rent is too high in Michigan right now. So, we’re focused on doing everything we can to bring that down by building more of every kind of housing and working with locals to make sure those priorities are set at the local level and not just at the state Capitol,” Pugh explained.

The Coordinator for the Rent is Too Damn High Coalition, William Lawrence, said state leaders should be doing more.

“We need to see more from the legislature to protect renters and stand up to the landlords who right now are blocking progress at the state level,” Lawrence said.

articles.title: Gun violence prevention advocacy groups pushing for more safety bills
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - “This time, I don’t want to wait until another tragedy occurs,” said Saylor Reinders, MSU Students Demand Action.

Tragedies like the Oxford High School and Michigan State University (MSU) mass shootings. Saylor Reinders says that gun safety laws won’t bring her peers back.

“It’s about making sure that people aren’t dying because guns are the number one killer of kids today,” said Reinders. Leaders from Moms Demand Action and Students Demand Action are pushing for more safety bills like banning guns at polling places. Kazia Kelly has carried a gun for four years, and she says education starts at home.

“That’s really why we want to pass safe homes, safe Schools,” said Kazia Kelly. “That’s where MDHHS is going to be if this gets passed: give home information to all families who attend Public Schools.”

Governor Gretchen Whitmer signed a package of gun safety bills into law in 2023. Now, advocates say there’s still more to be done. And those same laws have the backing of many gun owners.

“Our ask, we want again to keep everyone safe,” said Kelly. “Our communities, our families, and I am a gun owner. Anyone who is a responsible gun owner knows we need secure storage, and we need measures in place again to keep everybody safe.”

News 10 reached out to the Michigan Coalition for Responsible Gun Owners and the Michigan Firearms Association for comment and did not receive a response.

Reinders says the gun prevention bills were a step in the right direction, but it doesn’t stop there.

“Gun violence is a very multifaceted issue, and it demands nuance solutions,” said Reinders. “So, while we can pass lots of legislation, I don’t think that’s the only solution. I think we also need community violence prevention.”

Violence prevention, they hope, stops the next shooting. Starting this week, if you buy things like trigger locks or gun safes, you do not need to pay sales tax on those items.

That was part of the legislation Governor Gretchen Whitmer signed into law after the shooting at MSU.

One count of Child Sexually Abusive Activity

The alleged sender of the text, El-Amin, requested the person, a decoy who stated they were 15 years old, to perform oral sex. After El-Amin waved his Miranda Rights, he told police he believed the legal age of consent for sexual acts in Michigan was 18. El-Amin also told police he believed the decoy was 15 years old and allegedly admitted he was attempting to meet with the 15-year-old for sexual acts.

He is scheduled to appear in court on May 17.

articles.title: PGA President shares excitement for Championship, program for Military Veterans
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - The 2024 PGA Championship gets underway in Louisville, Kentucky Thursday and ahead of the tournament, News 10 caught up with PGA President John Lindert, who is from Grand Ledge and is also the Director of Golf at the Country Club of Lansing.

This year’s PGA Championship will be hosted by Valhalla Golf Club, a well-known major championship course. Nearly all of the top-ranked golfers in the world will be in the tournament field. Big names as well including 15-time major champion Tiger Woods. Something unique about the PGA Championship is it’s the only major where there are no amateurs in the field.

Lindert has been in the Louisville area for days getting ready for the tournament. He and the tournament’s director spoke to the excitement surrounding the event as we inch closer to the opening round on Thursday.

“I am looking forward to creating memories for people. I remember when my grandfather took me to my first Championship and the memories I had; I am looking forward to creating that for another grandfather and his grandson. or mother and daughter, or whoever comes out and joins us. or best friends. making memories is what we are here for,” said PGA Championship Director Ryan Ogle.

“I think we are going to have somewhere in the neighborhood of 98-99 of the top 100 players on the official world golf ranking playing in this, so it is the strongest field in major championships,” said John Lindert, PGA of America President.

Before the championship, PGA HOPE, which stands for Honoring Our Patriots Everywhere, held its 9th Secretary’s Cup for Military Veterans from across the country. Around 48 Veterans teed off the University of Louisville Golf Club.

The event aims to help rehabilitate Veterans through golf. The tournament took place on Monday, with twelve teams, each consisting of one PGA of America golf professional and four military veterans, competing in a nine-hole match.

Lindert said that this event is special to him, as his father served in the South Pacific during World War II. Lindert says that the Veterans who took part in this special event have over 570 years of combined service.

“HOPE kind of helps the players get reintroduced into society,” said Lindert. “We have seen players who have gone on and actually wanted to be in the industry and have become golf professionals. So it is not only rehabilitating individuals, but it has actually saved lives and changed lives. It is very impactful. But we love to start our championship week off with the Veteran’s championship, if you will, with HOPE.”

“We want them to feel the pressure of playing for something and representing again, but it is a safe environment,” said Christopher Nowak, PGA of America Military and Veteran Liaison. “In hopes that their brain will look at some sort of anxiety issue, stressful issue, different now that they have had a positive outcome.”

The teams for the Secretary’s Cup arrived in Louisville, Kentucky on Friday as part of the overall experience. On Saturday, the Veterans and PGA of America golf professionals attended a welcome reception at Churchill Downs. They will also be attending the PGA Championship practice round at Valhalla on Tuesday.

Lindert tells News 10 the PGA Championship sold out quickly, and thousands of fans will be heading to Louisville, Kentucky this week. According to a report from the Sports Business Journal, tournament officials are expecting around 200,000 fans throughout the week at Valhalla Golf Club.

Lindert also says he’s looking forward to this week when his family will be traveling to join him in Louisville for the tournament. You can see or hear Lindert on several TV and radio broadcasts throughout the week. He will also hand the coveted Wanamaker Trophy to the winner of this year’s PGA Championship at the tournament’s conclusion.

articles.title: Tensions rise in DeWitt amid controversy around pronoun lessons in school
articles.content:
DEWITT, Mich. (WILX) - DeWitt Public Schools held its first board meeting Monday night since the controversy erupted over a plan to teach elementary students about gender pronouns.

The district scraped the lesson just days after announcing it last month. Parents and community members came to the meeting by the dozens. Some support the school district’s inclusivity efforts, and others say children, especially first graders, should not be learning about gender pronouns in school.

“The truth is, teaching 7-year-olds to lie at the command of an adult to protect someone else is abuse, and when those lies and abuse are over a sexualized issue... There’s another word for that: grooming,” said one woman during a public comment.

“When we heard the news of this lesson being canceled, we were very disappointed,” said a DeWitt Public Schools parent.

In April, the Superintendent sent a letter to parents about the lesson that included reading a book, “They, She, He, Me: Free to Be!” it also included teaching proper pronoun use and genders. The optional lesson was ultimately canceled days later after backlash.

“Teaching our children that they can sit there and pick their own gender; Very sad what’s going on today, very sad,” one man from Dearborn said during a public comment.

“I think about the opportunity to educate their peers, and that opportunity was taken away,” said a parent of DeWitt Schools.

Other people arguing this is not a conversation that is appropriate for school.

“I believe the statistic is 1 in 6 students graduate illiterate. Do we really have time to be teaching such an elective course?” said one DeWitt resident.

Despite interruptions from the crowd, Superintendent Dr. Shanna Spickard confirms that their students are fine and that the district will continue working on the best solution for everyone.

“Our students are excelling, and they’re doing a great job, and there’s a lot of false information about proficiency and graduation rates. Our graduations are in the high 90s, our students are excelling at our target of 80 percent average or higher, our proficiency scores are above state and county averages,” said Dr. Spickard.

Throughout the entire ordeal, Dr. Spickard revealed that multiple school staff members had received online threats and even their information doxed on social media. She said most of those came from people outside the DeWitt community. Since then, there has been increased security at the schools and offices.

articles.title: 25-year-old man killed on Georgetown Blvd in Lansing
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Lansing Police are investigating a homicide that happened early Sunday morning.

Police said at 7 a.m. Sunday, May 12, they were called to the 2100 block of Georgetown Blvd for a severe physical altercation between a 25-year-old male and several others.

Officers say that in the call, they learned that the 25-year-old was taken from a residence to an unknown location by multiple suspects and that the 25-year-old could be in serious condition.

In the first three months of the year, there were zero homicides reported in Ingham County. According to the Ingham County Prosecutor, in comparison, there were four homicides in the first quarter of 2022.

The most recent homicide occurred on May 4, 2024, where Lansing police found 14-year-old Jaquez Moye-Young dead following a shooting. Mayor Andy Schor saying the city is doing everything they can.

“There was a domestic violence situation. It’s very difficult to combat that you know,” said Schor. “We’re doing a lot of work. We have Advance Peace that is helping out in preventing retaliations, but when you have someone who’s very bad and does something very bad in a domestic way, it’s just something that you have to navigate and we had several months where we didn’t see that.”

Police say they have multiple suspects in custody, which is still an ongoing investigation. LPD is still attempting to learn the exact sequence of events in this case.

articles.title: National Day Without Childcare isn’t ideal for local childcare providers, but it’s important
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Many parents stayed home, and childcare providers closed their doors. National Day Without Childcare is bringing attention to a childcare system that many say needs fixing.

Workers at one local childcare center understand why this day is important; they couldn’t close their doors on parents.

According to the Care.com 2024 Cost of Care Report, in 2023, a family spent an average of 24% of their household income on childcare. 47% of families spent more than $1500 a month or $18,000 a year. That’s more than the average in-state tuition at a public four-year college in Michigan, roughly $15,000.

Across the nation, parents and childcare providers are rallying together, advocating for affordable and accessible childcare and a livable wage for early childhood educators.

In Lansing, Helping Hands Christian Learning Center supports the National Day Without Childcare but finds closing a challenge when considering working parents.

“A day without childcare would be really hard cause a lot of our families, they need to work. And so, by us being closed, it would be like a nuisance to them,” said Director of Helping Hands Rachelle Parmelee.

According to Care.com, the weekly rate of daycare was $210, about $10,000 a year in Michigan.

Parmelee, director of Helping Hands, says their tuition is used to keep their center open.

“The building itself, all of our staff and employees, the food that we serve, we provide all meals for them. And just providing that safe and nurturing care that goes along with childcare,” said Parmelee.

Amy Sofian, Head Preschool Teacher at Helping Hands, has worked in childcare for 25 years. She says that as a parent, she struggled to afford childcare, and with child workers making $12 to $15 an hour, making ends meet has become a new challenge.

“It’s important that we not only get paid our worth but what is necessary for us to survive. The care that we provide here, especially the care that I provide, is the same care I would provide my son,” said Sofian.

Sofian is glad Helping Hands stayed open but hopes this national day helps get the word out.

“If a lot more people, a lot more centers knew about this kind of protest, I guess you would call it, that it would bring to light the importance of childcare,” said Sofian.

Michigan’s Department of Lifelong Education, Advancement, and Potential announced earlier this month a $59 million investment that will expand and improve 1,100 childcare facilities across the state. This investment follows Governor Whitmer’s push for free universal preschool.

articles.title: Trump’s former lawyer, John Eastman: “That’s laughably false.”
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Former President Donald Trump’s election lawyer, John Eastman, spoke in Lansing on Thursday, claiming the 2020 election was stolen.

“Krebs, the head of CISA, the security agency in Washington DC, says it was the most secure election in history. That’s laughably false,” said Eastman.

The event in Lansing was held by Michigan Fair Elections.

In Georgia, John Eastman has been criminally indicted on conspiracy, fraud, and other charges. He is now suspended from practicing law in Washington, D.C., and the state of California. In March, a judge also recommended the lawyer be disbarred. Eastman tells News 10′s Jordyn Burrell that he has no regrets about getting involved with the former president. He says he is standing up for the truth and insists, despite evidence to the contrary, that there were illegalities in the 2020 presidential election.

“I have no regrets look it’s extremely important that we follow the constitution and play by the rules when we have elections. Rule number 1 is the constitution assigns plenary authority to the state legislatures to direct the manner to choose electors. That was not followed in Michigan,” said Eastman.

Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson says the event was not held to inform but instead pushed election lies as part of a political agenda.

“It’s ironic that one of the least trustworthy voices is somehow now seeking a mantle as someone you should listen to about elections in Michigan. I think the bottom line is citizens shouldn’t be fooled and to expect tactics like these,” said Secretary Benson.

An investigation by Michigan’s Senate Republicans following the 2020 election found no widespread or systemic fraud, but Eastman continues to question how ballots were handled.

“Signature verification didn’t go on in the TCF Center in Detroit; observation that is required by the law was shut down and prevented in large numbers in the TCF center in Detroit, so these are the kinds of things, the laws that were broken that opened the doors for fraud. Quite frankly, the Michigan investigation was pretty anemic,” said Eastman.

Those claims have been proven false. The city of Detroit says signatures were not being checked at the TCF Center because they were checked before arriving. She says voters need to know there are safeguards in place as they prepare to cast their votes for another presidential election months from now.

“We’re supporting efforts on both sides of the aisle to speak the truth and to bring people together and really try to solve problems for our citizens instead of getting in the mud pit around false information about our elections,” said Secretary Benson.

Eastman is encouraging people to volunteer to be poll watchers or poll workers. That may be one area of agreement with Secretary Benson who says helping with elections can also help restore confidence in our election system and voting outcome.

articles.title: Racial disparities remain present in Michigan’s foster care system
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Children of color are put into the system at a disproportionate rate, according to the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services.

Failing to identify cases of child abuse or neglect can have negative impacts. However, over-reporting can lead to families being caught in the court system and their children pushed into the foster care system. One local advocate shares she believes there are ways to avoid this.

Children of color make up 31% of Michigan’s population according to Michigan’s Child Welfare Improvement Task Force, yet they make up 51% of the state foster care population.

“When we separate families, we don’t give anyone a pathway to doing it better,” said Tashmica Torok, co-director of the Firecracker Foundation in Lansing.

The organization frequently works with the foster system. Torok says the problem of over-representation starts with the mandatory reporting of abuse and neglect and the lack of understanding of cultural differences.

“Nurses and doctors or we’re talking about police officers or we’re even talking about teachers. Most of those people don’t share the identities or cultural practices of the people that they’re calling in the state to respond to.”

Children are then investigated, and parents enter custody battles which result in trauma for the children involved.

“Anytime we remove a child from a family regardless of the circumstances we have to understand we are causing harm and trauma.”

Torok says changing the way reports are reviewed and refining abuse and neglect is necessary.

Design a different way of approaching harm and violence that doesn’t mean immediate separation, punishment, and harm to the biological family. That is [actually] struggling with inequities and intergenerational trauma.”

Along with offering parents support in hopes of keeping their child in their home.

“Whether that looks like mental health care, or restorative justice, or transformative justice. There are lots of models for repairing harm and conflict resolutions between people including children.”

Michigan’s Child Welfare Improvement Task Force offered recommendations to Michigan’s Department of Health and Human Services to address racial disparities in the state’s child protection system. Like services and support for relatives and family friends, services that reduce placement in childcare institutions, and funding to assist with these recommendations.

A study from the American Academy of Pediatrics says cases with black children are more likely to be accepted for investigation leading to the removal of a child from their family for a longer period of time and taking longer for the case to be closed.

articles.title: ‘It’s our tradition’: Lansing family does their part to Stamp Out Hunger
articles.content:
LANSING, Mich. (WILX) - Making sure peoples’ mail gets where it needs to go is a big enough job on its own, but letter carriers for the USPS double that workload every May, to give back to the communities they serve.

The Stamp Out Hunger food drive returned Saturday, giving postal workers across the U.S. an opportunity to give back to the communities they serve. But one Lansing letter carrier has made the event a family affair.

Six days a week, Andrew Kozan delivers mail to people on his south Lansing route, but on Stamp Out Hunger day, he’s also delivering meals to people in need.

“Well for me, it definitely helps our community, because we know a lot of people need food with grocery prices being extremely high,” he said. It definitely helps the people who need it.”

Last year, Stamp Out Hunger raised more than 117,000 pounds of nonperishable food items for local pantries nationwide. It’s a tradition Kozan has taken part in for more than a decade, but he doesn’t work alone.

When he’s picking up bags of food from the porches of Lansing residents, the rest of the Kozan family is rolling along in the car, right by his side. An already convenient way to help the Greater Lansing Food Bank keep its shelves stocked, made even more efficient, and more fun with the help of Kozan’s wife, Emily, and his son, Vincent.

“They end up doing a lot of trips back and forth from the street back to the post office to drop off the food, so we like to come out here and help dad get the job done,” Emily said.

While she stays behind the wheel, Vincent stays ready to move in backseat, hopping out the side door each time his dad picks up a bag of food, and putting it in the trunk. It’s not just a unique way to spend his Saturday, it’s his way to give back.

“I like coming to do Stamp Out because it helps other people,” he said. “I think it’s fun to do this.”

Once the Kozan’s trunk is full, Andrew keeps moving on his route to pick up more bags in his USPS van, while Emily and Vincent drop the donations for sorting at the post office. The Kozans say their system is built on teamwork, and they’ve managed to perfect it over the last few years.

They say it’s special way for them to give back to their neighbors as a family.

“There are many more years to come of this,” Andrew said. “Every year we’re going to do it, every May. Every second Saturday in May is Stamp Out Hunger.”

“It’s our tradition,” Emily added.

Stamp Out Hunger only comes around once each year, but the Kozans say local pantries can use donations from the community at any time. They’re hoping to encourage other people to do their part, too.

articles.title: Overdose prevention efforts ramp up across Las Vegas Valley
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Thousands of overdose prevention supplies are being distributed across the Las Vegas Valley this year, especially during the weekend of the Electric Daisy Carnival when hundreds of thousands of people are in town.

In 2023, the Las Vegas Valley saw a record number of deadly fentanyl overdoses with 361 people.

Harm Reduction Circle heads to music festivals across the country and offers thousands of doses naloxone, fentanyl test strips and other supplies. Attendees of EDC can ask volunteers for supplies and instructions on how to use Narcan or test strips.

“I like to compare it with CPR. 51% of Americans have been trained on CPR at some point in their life. You learn CPR to facilitate the people around you. Same thing with carrying Naloxone,” said founder Annastasia Rose Beal.

“Harm reduction is even more important this year than ever. We’ve seen more than 140,000 overdoses this year in the US. And it’s not just impacting opiate users. It’s impacting non opiate users, people that are doing party drugs like cocaine and ecstasy, and buying fake pressed pills. Attendees might find a dealer on the street or wherever they got their substances from. Now there’s fentanyl in it and they had no idea,” Beal said.

The Southern Nevada Health District is tracking and monitoring locations of overdoses and deaths, and will distribute harm reduction supplies and kits to people on the streets or partner organizations.

The data was included in a report from SNHD.

“Fentanyl is primarily driving our overdoses or fatal overdoses in Clark County. We’re also seeing an alarming trend of fentanyl being adulterated into stimulants like cocaine and methamphetamine. That suggests that there are people who are using fentanyl who don’t know that that’s what’s in their supply. There’s an ever-evolving illicit drug supply,” said Jessica Johnson, a SNHD health education supervisor.

Through more funding, SNHD was able to ramp up its Narcan distribution and gave out 11,000 doses in January alone. Distribution happens through partner organizations or even through handing out supplies to people on the streets.

Harm Reduction Circle will be in the Valley all EDC weekend. You can contact them at 949-659-8180 or via direct message on Instagram.

articles.title: Nevada Supreme Court denies appeal of conservative activist seeking to oust county election official
articles.content:
RENO, Nev. (AP) - A conservative activist who embraced unproven election fraud claims has lost an appeal to the Nevada Supreme Court in his bid to oust a top county election official and others.

The high court on Wednesday upheld a lower-court judge’s earlier dismissal of Robert Beadles’ lawsuit, which claimed that Washoe County’s registrar of voters, the county manager and a county commissioner violated the state constitution by failing to respond to his complaints of fraud.

“Taking all the factual allegations in the complaint as true and drawing every inference in favor of Beadles, he can prove no set facts that would entitle him to relief as pleaded,” the Supreme Court ruled.

Beadles, who once briefly ran for Congress in California in 2010, has alleged that the election system is rife with “flaws and irregularities” that robbed him of his vote in 2020.

Beadles lost an earlier lawsuit in state court in 2022 that sought heightened observation of Washoe County’s vote-counting process. He has helped lead attempts to recall or otherwise oust numerous county officials since he moved to Reno from California in 2019.

Washoe County, which includes Reno-Sparks and the north shore of Lake Tahoe along the California line, is considered a swing county in the Western battleground state of Nevada. Registered voters are divided roughly in equal thirds among Democrats, Republicans and nonpartisans.

The Supreme Court’s ruling said Beadles misapplied a section of the Nevada Constitution guaranteeing the right to assemble and petition the Legislature in his most recent lawsuit, which sought the removal of Jamie Rodriguez, then-Washoe County registrar of voters; Eric Brown, county manager; and Alexis Hill, county commission chairwoman.

“There are no set of facts that could prove a violation of that constitutional right based on respondents’ failure to respond directly to Beadles’ allegations,” Chief Justice Lidia Stiglich wrote in the five-page ruling.

The ruling said state law permits a voter to file a complaint with the secretary of state’s office about election practices, but “these laws do not establish that respondents had a duty to respond to Beadles’ allegations.”

articles.title: Las Vegas motorcycle rider critically injured in crash with pickup truck
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Las Vegas police responded at approximately 11:26 a.m. on Friday morning after a motorcycle rider was critically injured in a crash with a pickup truck.

According to a police report, a 2013 Chevrolet Silverado was traveling northbound on N. Jones Blvd. in the right travel lane while a 2012 Kawasaki Ninja was also traveling north in the same lane. Police said that the motorcycle “failed to use due care” as the truck slowed to turn right into a private drive.

Responding emergency medical personnel took the Kawasaki rider by ambulance to University Medical Center’s Trauma Unit, with injuries determined to be life-threatening. The pickup truck’s driver remained at the collision scene and showed no signs of impairment.

articles.title: Animal Foundation reaches critical space crisis
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - The Animal Foundation reported that it urgently needs at least 50 dogs to go into temporary foster homes to make more space in the shelter.

The shelter is open on May 17 from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. for anyone who wants to pick up a foster dog.

“We are out of space to house any more dogs on our campus, and we are facing some very difficult decisions to ensure the well-being of our animals and team. This is our heartbreaking reality, but we just don’t have room for the new animals that are coming in every day.”

The Animal Foundation

Team members and volunteers will be ready to assist you at 655 North Mojave Rd. Las Vegas, NV 89110. They are asking patrons to foster a medium or large-sized dog for at least two to four weeks. To expedite the process, everyone is encouraged to fill out a foster application before arriving at the shelter.

“Shelters across the country are facing very difficult times right now, and we are no exception,” the foundation wrote on its website. “We currently have 747 animals in our care, and over the last week, we have taken in 558 animals. If you can’t foster, please share this information in hopes that it will reach someone who can.”

FOX5 caught up with a couple of families who grew by one member Friday afternoon at the Animal Foundation by taking advantage of free adoptions, including Shannon Hamilton and her newly-adopted husky that she re-named Kaaya.

“Kaaya is such a cute little husky! We found him online,” Hamilton said giddily. “We knew that they had adoptions and they were needing them, and we had to come get him. My husband’s always wanted a husky.”

Matthew Vaillancourt also found his future adopted pet, Percy, online through the Animal Foundation.

“We have another little one at home, and she needs a friend,” Vaillancourt said. “He’s definitely a sweet dog, and we think he’s going to make a great addition to our family.”

To help free up space, the shelter is also waiving adoption fees on May 17 for all adoptable dogs in the shelter. You can view all available and adoptable dogs here:

articles.title: Suspect pointed gun before deputy-involved Nye County shooting
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Nye County Sheriff Joe McGill provided an update on a deputy-involved shooting from earlier this week, revealing that a suspect pointed a handgun at a deputy during the incident.

On May 14, the Nye County Sheriff’s Office received a call requesting a welfare check after an elderly resident reportedly hadn’t been seen in approximately one week. Deputy Nicholas Huggins responded to the residence of Michael Byers, 81.

Body camera footage released by the sheriff’s office shows Huggins knocking on the front door before exploring the side and rear of the residence for approximately three and a half minutes. When the deputy returned to the front door, Byers emerged and pointed a handgun at him as a pair of dogs ran at the deputy.

The sheriff’s office added that all NCSO personnel are safe and unharmed.

Sheriff McGill said that Deputy Huggins fired shots one through five before the suspect returned fire, then went back into his home and called 911. Huggins called for an additional unit and Byers was later taken into custody without incident.

The sheriff said that Byers was taken to a nearby hospital for a “superficial injury” and was released and then booked. He is facing one charge of attempted murder with a deadly weapon and one charge of assault with a deadly weapon on a protected person.

Deputy Huggins has been placed on administrative leave, which is standard procedure following a deputy-involved shooting. Sheriff McGill said that this is Huggins’ third deputy-involved shooting since he joined the office in 2021.

Faith Lutheran High School is asking for help finding a band trailer that was stolen from the school’s parking lot Wednesday morning.

A spokesperson for Faith Lutheran told FOX5 that staff noticed the trailer was gone after arriving at the school. “Students are feeling anywhere from heartbroken to angry about this. They all feel violated.”

The spokesperson says the trailer itself is worth $20,000, while the content inside is worth up to $25,000. Instruments, cables, and other materials were inside the trailer, which was custom-made for the school.

“It has a big Faith Lutheran logo on the side of it, so we’re hoping someone may have seen it,” the spokesperson said.

However, in addition to the band and color guard, other school organizations will also use the trailer from time to time, so the need to get the trailer back is urgent, officials say.

articles.title: Catholic Charities of Southern Nevada celebrates 83 years of community service
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Deacon Thomas Roberts is continuing a mission more than eight decades in the making.

“83 years this month, so 1941, which is a pretty remarkable year in the history of our country, was also the year Catholic Charities started here in Southern Nevada.”

Bishop Thomas Gorman established the organization as the Catholic Welfare Program. Initially created to facilitate adoptions, the mission evolved over the years to meet the Las Vegas Valley’s changing needs.

“And as southern Nevada grew, and got bigger, we added more programs. And certainly, food has always been a program that’s been a big part of our mission for all 80-plus years, and up to today, we’re serving, gosh, about 45 hundred people a day,” shares Deacon Tom, the organization’s president and CEO.

One of the original Meals on Wheels vans.(Courtesy: Catholic Charities of Southern Nevada)

That includes the 25 hundred senior citizens currently enrolled in the Meals on Wheels program. Deacon Tom tells us, many of the rely on drivers for more than something to eat.

“And some of those seniors are alone and really have no one to check on them, so part of the gift of Meals on Wheels is drivers taking seven meals at a time directly to the home and doing a wellness check on that client and often that may be the only human contact that they have.”

Some only have pets for company. Deacon Tom tells us, they’re taken care of too.

“We also provide free pet food, so if a client has a pet, and the pet’s a family member like my dog’s a family member in our house, we’re providing for the pet too, and the client is just as thankful, even more thankful, for the pet food because it’s caring for their family member.”

Catholic Charities also helps keep families’ cupboards full.

“We also have a food pantry, that is serving people, the working poor, people who just aren’t making enough to make ends meet, and we serve about 150 families a day.”

The dining hall has long been a gathering place for those in need to get a hot, delicious meal.(Courtesy: Catholic Charities of Southern Nevada)

And the group fills the stomachs of those who may not have a kitchen, let alone a cupboard.

“Every day we provide a fresh, hot meal to anyone who needs it, and typically that can be over 500 families a day, 500 individuals and families, “ says Deacon Tom. “They’re coming for a free meal, because they have no place else to go.”

And, he says, everyone is welcome.

“I like to say we don’t check religious ID cards around here, so all God’s children are welcome for food, and resources. We’re here to help, we’re not here to judge,” he says.

“It’s a meal delivered with compassion. It’s a high-quality meal, it tastes good. And we have volunteers every day to help us deliver that meal to the clients. So the food is the help and the service is the hope.”

Deacon Tom says it’s been a worthy mission for decades, and it will continue to be so well into the future.

“We’ve been doing this meal for more than 50 years, every single, never missed a day, and that’s God’s grace, that’s the generosity of this community that allows us to do this work, so it’s humbling for me, and I’m grateful and say thank you.”

He invites not only those in need to visit Catholic Charities but the general public as well.

“I invite people to come and see for yourselves, take a tour, sign up on our website, and come and take a look for yourself so you can see God’s vulnerable children are getting help and hope here.”

You can sign up for a tour, make a contribution, or learn more about the services offered on Catholic Community Services of Southern Nevada’s website.

“Over the last several months while serving as the COO of the Las Vegas Grand Prix, we developed a solid plan for this year’s race, established clear lines of communication with governing agencies and furthered critical community relationships,” she said. “With that work in place, it is time for me to return to my prior management consulting practice with C4ward Strategies. I’m confident that I’m leaving the LVGP in a stronger position and wish them every success.”

Renee Wilm, the CEO of the race said that she Fretwell played a critical role.

“Betsy has played a critical role for us as we navigate the complexities of a race of this magnitude in Las Vegas. She has been instrumental in helping us set the table for a successful race this year,” Wilm said. “In our inaugural year, my focus was intently on the establishment and operation of the race. I now intend to bring that same energy and attention to the Las Vegas community as a whole, this year and for years to come. We wish Betsy nothing but the best.”

Fretwell says she is returning to her prior consulting practice with C4ward Strategies.

Clark County School District Police Department Lieutenant Bryan Zink told FOX5 that the female faces battery and assault charges with a deadly weapon on top of disturbing a school. The male was transported to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries and was then released.

One is injured, and another is in custody after a stabbing on a Las Vegas elementary school campus Friday morning.

The stabbing incident happened around 10:50 a.m. Zink said the two had a verbal altercation inside the cafeteria where the ceremony was occurring and then later turned physical outside in a quad area.

The school was under a hard lockdown that cued both CCSD Police and the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department. The school district has confirmed that there is no threat to students or staff at this time. A fifth-grade promotion ceremony has been postponed as a result.

CCSDPD will be handling the investigation into the incident, which is ongoing.

Read the full letters sent to parents below:

This is an update from Wendell Williams Elementary School.

CCSD Police and Metro Police are on-campus due to an altercation on campus involving adults.

Out of an abundance of caution - our school remains on a lockdown. All students are safe in their classroom.

There is no threat to students or staff at this time. Thank you for your understanding and patience as we work to continue with the school day.

Again, we plan to continue with our school day and serve lunch shortly. We have no plans to dismiss students early.

The fifth grade promotion ceremony has been postponed until Monday. I will provide more details at a later time regarding the newly scheduled time.

Thank you,

Cynthia Ireland

Principal

LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - The Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department said 33-year-old Eryka Westover is accused of child abuse or neglect.

On May 17, detectives arrested Westover as the suspect. She was booked into the Clark County Detention Center and is facing felony charges.

The announcement of the arrest was released Friday morning. Police said on April 1 of this year, a report was completed with Metro alleging a student had been abused by a teacher at a learning institute in the 9000 block of Hillpointe Road.

Metro Police did not confirm Westover’s workplace, but court records ordered her to sThe Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department arrested 33-year-old Eryka Westover, a former daycare teacher at Shenker Academy for child abuse.

On May 17, Westover was booked into the Clark County Detention Center and is facing a felony charge.

Police said on April 1, a report was completed with Metro alleging a student had been abused by a teacher at a learning institute in the 9000 block of Hillpointe Road.

Metro Police did not confirm Westover’s workplace, but court records ordered her to stay away from Shenker Academy.

Video FOX5 obtained exclusively shows an incident while Westover was working at Shenker Academy. In the video, Westover appears to yell in a tightly-swaddled child’s face, before slamming the child into a bed or cot face down. Then, Westover can be heard saying, “I just body slammed you.”

The mother of that child, Elisa Valdez, told FOX5 she was horrified when she saw the video.

“Angry at first, extremely angry. I mean who would do that to a three year old?,” Valdez questioned. Valdez stated she confronted the head of the academy, but he gave no apology and showed no remorse.

“He basically said ‘she didn’t really do anything.’ I don’t know how anybody could watch the video and say that and think that nothing happened,” Valdez asserted.

Shaylyn Mandado, who worked with Westover at Shenker Academy for three years, says she started noticing abuse last summer, but it escalated in the last couple of months.

“It kind of escalated really fast, where she got really, really, rough with the kids… and then, when we tried to mention it to our higher ups, they kind of dismissed us,” Mandado recounted.

Shenker Academy’s attorney said as of Friday, their only comment is that Westover is no longer employed at the school. They did not specifically address the allegations.

FOX5 obtained a letter sent to Shenker Academy parents Friday that stated, in part, “the teacher was placed on administrative leave immediately after the board was notified of these accusations…the safety and well-being of our students is our highest priority.”

articles.title: Nevada Contractors Board launches unit to investigate solar company complaints
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - In response to the rising number of complaints about residential solar companies, the Nevada State Contractors Board has announced the launch of a special Solar Investigations Unit.

According to officials, the unit will aim to target solar companies with complaints “involving theft, fraud, abandonment, diversion of funds, and unlicensed contracting.”

“Of the 3,000 complaints the Board receives annually, nearly one-third are homeowner complaints about solar companies,” said Nevada State Contractors Board Executive Officer Margi Grein. “Complaints include misleading sales tactics with promised benefits such as rebates, government incentives, and the complete eradication of electric bills.”

In April, FOX5 reported on one contractor accused of stealing around $250,000 without performing any work over the past two years. The 43-year-old man is facing seven felony counts and one misdemeanor as a result, which may involve up to 65 years in prison.

This is the latest effort from the contractors board to hold companies that have harmed homeowners accountable.

Additionally, the board will be partnering with prosecutorial agencies to provide increased consumer protection against scams, deceptive loans, and aggressive sales tactics. The unit will also meet regularly with state agencies to collaboratively work toward finding “fair and effective solutions,” according to the board.

“We are sending a message to the residential solar industry that protecting consumers is at the forefront of our mission and we will take whatever measures are necessary to continue protecting the health, safety, and welfare of the public,” said Grein.

Homeowner workshops will also be held to provide homeowners with information and education on how to identify licensed contractors, red flags that may indicate scams, and how to apply for the Residential Recovery Fund.

Homeowners can easily verify a contractor’s license by visiting the NSCB website at www.nscb.nv.gov to ensure that the contractor is licensed for the work to be performed.

For more information on the NSCB Solar Investigations Unit or to file a complaint, homeowners should contact the NSCB at (702) 486-1100 (Southern Nevada) or (775) 688-1141 (Northern Nevada).

articles.title: Bally’s chairman: ‘Master Plan’ for former Tropicana site could integrate future resort and stadium
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - A “Master Plan” is being developed for the site of the former Tropicana Hotel to better integrate a baseball stadium and forthcoming resort, according to the chairman of Bally’s Corporation, which could change the placement of both attractions on the property and centralize a ballpark.

The 36-acre portion of land at the corner of Tropicana Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard is owned by GLPI, which offered nine acres to the Athletics for stadium development, leaving 27 acres for a future Bally’s property. GLPI and Bally’s committed the southeast corner of the property for stadium development.

According to Chairman Soo Kim, plans are in the works to create more synergy with a ballpark, a resort and the Strip. Kim met with FOX5 in the Las Vegas Valley to discuss developments.

“Our initial plan was to set the stadium back and leave the rest of the site open to development,” he said. “There is a prevailing thought that maybe we should explore putting it more centrally,” Kim said.

A potential centralized stadium location will, in turn, impact pedestrian and vehicle access for both the ballpark and resort, spurring the need for a cohesive Master Plan. The plan will require coordination with neighboring properties as well, he said.

“There’s an opportunity to offer the patrons more integration, and in that way, make the rest of the remaining acreage more valuable. Great sporting experiences are shared outside the arena, whether it’s the walk, or the concourses, or the energy outside the stadium,” Kim said.

“Modern arena design is what happens outside the stadium. That energy is the way to go,” Kim said. “I think the stadium Is going to be an amazing amenity for the city, for tourism and the community. It’s on us to bring a resort to life that’s as exciting as [John] Fisher’s plan for the stadium,” he said.

Though a representative on a recent Bally’s earnings call indicated that the operator could take time to develop a new resort, Kim said that executives are exploring the possibility of building “simultaneously” alongside stadium construction.

“There’s a lot of work being done. There’s a lot of important decisions we’re trying to make. We had a simple solution early, and now we’re trying to come up with an optimal solution,” he said, saying that members of the Las Vegas Valley community will be pleased with the future results after years of planning and construction.

Representatives of the Athletics, LVCVA and Stadium Authority have said construction could start in spring of 2025 and be ready by spring of 2028.

The company will be “fiscally prudent” as it decides on a construction timeline. he said. Although construction could commence simultaneously, Kim said completion of the entire resort could occur in stages after the stadium’s 2028 opening day.

Although Kim previously discussed in 2023 a focus on a “sports” theme for a future property, he said the priority has been to finalize the Master Plan.

Demolition of the Tropicana Hotel is on time and on schedule with an implosion planned for October or even September, he said, all to deliver a site ready for the Athletics to commence stadium construction.

articles.title: Street vendors help monitor air quality in East Las Vegas during 2-year study
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Is East Las Vegas more impacted by air pollution than other areas of the valley? That is the question researchers set to answer. They equipped street vendors with mobile air monitors for an EPA funded study, and also placed monitors in homes and businesses throughout the community.

Working on the streets, vendors are exposed to a lot of street traffic every day and extreme heat in the summer. In East Las Vegas, there’s not a lot of green space as compared to other parts of the Vegas Valley. That is why East Las Vegas community members, leaders, and advocates are all coming together.

“It is important for all of us to have access to clean air… this community has one of the worst air quality metrics in the region... Things like respiratory disease, asthma, all of those things are exacerbated by poor air quality,” shared Lauren Boitel, Executive Director of Impact NV.

“Buen Aire Para Todos” or good air for all, is a two-year study on air quality in East Las Vegas paid for by EPA grant money.

“We did 20 indoor sensors, 20 outdoor quality sensors, and 20 mobile sensors on street vendors,” explained Boitel. The air quality monitors were placed in homes, in apartment complexes, and even on the carts of street food vendors like Eduardo Moreno who spoke to FOX5 via translator.

“He decided to participate in this study to be more aware of the air quality where he works at during the day... Thanks to the mobile monitors, he has been able to see air quality is good in the morning and then later on in the day is when the air quality worsens,” the translator relayed.

The device shows the vendors a color in real time: green being good, red being bad.

“Each device picks up the amount of particulate matter in a home or outside in real time and it shows up on a map... It will help us make recommendations for what the city can do,” Boitel reported.

The study ended on April 30th and results are still being complied, but preliminary results confirm the air in East Las Vegas is worse than other parts of the Las Vegas Valley. Scientific findings, as well as the feedback of those who took part in the study, will be submitted to the City of Las Vegas in the next month.

The study is a collaborative effort of Make the Road Nevada, Impact NV, Desert Research Institute, and the City of Las Vegas.

articles.title: Stadium Authority moves forward on A’s plan as two voice opposition during meeting
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Nevada State Education Association representatives shared strong opposition to the Oakland Athletics’ stadium plan for the south end of the Strip during a Las Vegas Stadium Authority meeting Thursday.

“We’ve spent more time implementing a world class stadium than we have working to build a world class K-12 education system,” Alexander Marks, representing NSEA, lamented after the meeting. “We’re 48th in the nation, we’ve got the largest class sizes in the nation, and we’ve got the highest vacancy rates. When our politicians get distracted by shiny objects like stadiums, those issues fall by the wayside.”

Marks was one of two NSEA members who spoke out against the plans for the ballpark, which will cost an estimated $1.5 billion, $380 million of which will come from a combination of state and county help.

The board held a couple of votes on the park, one of which acknowledged that Major League Baseball team owners have given their blessing for the A’s to move to Las Vegas. The other recognized that the A’s themselves are committed to moving here.

The board workshopped a non-relocation agreement that would keep the A’s legally bound to Las Vegas until at least 2051, and will vote on it at a later meeting.

Monday, the Nevada Supreme Court rejected a bid by Schools over Stadiums, with whom NSEA is affiliated. The group wanted to put stadium funding on the ballot and let voters have a say. It opposes Nevada tax dollars being used to build a stadium, and is vowing to renew its fight in 2026.

“When we ask for a 20% salary increase and they tell us that’s too expensive, or when we ask for class size reduction measures and we’re told that’s too expensive, and then they turn around and give a billionaire $380 million in public money, that offends everybody,” Marks told FOX5.

The state legislature did set aside $250 million for teacher pay raises, although a similarly-priced class size reduction bill did not pass.

At the tail end of this meeting, the board also received a report on the revenue brought in by Allegiant Stadium. It showed about a 13% boost, thanks in large part to hosting the Super Bowl.

articles.title: Water study gives insight into health problems for unhoused in Las Vegas tunnels
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - “This is probably the first time to our knowledge that a program like this has been deployed in an urban city looking at storm drains where individuals are living in these areas,” said Edwin Oh, Ph.D., associate professor at the UNLV School of Medicine.

A first-of-its-kind study years in the making at UNLV, in partnerships with the Southern Nevada Health District, Water Authority, and others, showed video of wastewater collection, stating, “Typically, this is what wastewater from the Strip might look like in a manhole.”

It all started with wastewater surveillance in 2020, looking for the pathogen that causes COVID-19.

Showing a water sample, Oh said, “That will represent about 12 hours of waste that’s coming from the airport that’s collected every 5 minutes so as to give us a composite sample of both locals and tourists.”

Dr. Edwin Oh and his team soon realized if they could identify these pathogens in wastewater, maybe they could use the same method to study the water in the Las Vegas flood control channels.

“This is the flow that we’re talking about. There really, really isn’t much water there.” Oh added, “We didn’t think that this was going to work, and surprisingly enough, this sample here contained DNA, RNA that allowed us to get a better sense of variants that were present.”

Water samples were collected weekly from channels like the Flamingo and Tropicana Washes, the same tunnels where more than a thousand unhoused people are known to live.

“The challenge with unsheltered homelessness in a city like ours is only growing. We’re talking about thousands of people who are living in these tunnels, and therefore, there are potentially thousands of people who don’t have access to healthcare resources,” Oh said.

Dr. Oh says it’s a population that’s underserved in healthcare and underrepresented in medical studies.

“We don’t have much data about testing and vaccination of unsheltered individuals,” Oh mentioned. “Using this source of water, we’re able to track how much of this pathogen might be present in a community that typically doesn’t get tested.”

Researchers not only found SARS-CoV-2 in the samples, fluctuating over a span of seven months, but could also identify variants in the water.

“The data suggests that by monitoring these storm tunnels, researchers can find times in the year when they see spikes in the viral pathogens,” Oh explained. “When we see these spikes, we can then deploy resources that are usually limited. To provide a choice for the community there to decide whether they would want to be tested, whether they would want to be vaccinated.”

Doctor Oh now hopes to further develop this method to identify other health trends in storm drain water samples.

“To look for influenza, to look for chlamydia, to look for Candida auris, to look for a number of different pathogens which could be treatable, and there could be a vaccine that’s available,” Oh said.

And he foresees other big cities adopting the same method, replicating the same DNA of this groundbreaking research.
