articles.title: Parents outraged by massive event featuring amateur ‘Bluey,’ restaurant apologizes
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Many parents on social media expressed outrage over an amateur event featuring characters from “Bluey” with crowds of disappointed families, while the restaurant offered an apology and told FOX5 that they did not expect the massive turnout with high expectations.

The Dirt Dog restaurant event that was posted on Facebook had a response of 3,000 people. It advertised an event with Bluey and other characters from the popular show, and free offerings like face painting and desserts.

Photos from parents show lines out the door and people posted on social media concerns about capacity and crowd control. When inside the crowded restaurant, people encountered amateur costumes, homemade treats and face painting from a restaurant staff member.

“I was mad. He looked unexpected,” said Sophia, a child who attended the event. “We could see his beard,” she said about the less-than-ideal Bluey impersonator.

“The kids were distraught. Some kids were crying. Some kids were upset, crying in their parents’ shoulders,” mother Stephanie Hernandez said. “How could you do that to little kids: advertise something so fun and eventful for kids ranging from toddlers to six, seven years old, and not actually follow through with it? It was a very upsetting moment to see so many kids, especially my daughter, just really upset,” she said.

Dirt Dog management sat down with FOX5 to explain the well-meaning intentions behind the event. Staff like to plan events for their “regulars,” and they volunteered to be the costume characters, worked as staff for face painting and even baked goods for the event. One restaurant worker personally baked 125 cupcakes, but they were gobbled up shortly after the event started.

“We expected like maybe 50 to 60 people--not in the sense of like the whole city coming out. Just now knowing who Bluey is, we would have planned ahead and would have had security,” said Taj Wilder, a spokesperson for marketing for the restaurant. She said while the event had 3,000 responses on Facebook, many other posts garner similar interest but crowds never turn out.

Wilder apologized to disappointed customers and promises more for customers and families.

“We’re very much family. We love on each other, we support each other. We’re going to continue to make events, create events, especially free ones, for families to come out and have a good time with us,” she said.

The restaurant posted an apology on social media and promises to make it up to the community. Wilder tells FOX5, the restaurant’s marketing team from Los Angeles will come and plan a family-friendly event, and they are working to secure the real Bluey for an appearance.

Parents had mixed reviews and responses online to the event and the apology.

“Thanks for ruining my 3 year olds day!” one parent said.

“I drove one hour just to see a grown man in PJs,” another wrote.

Some defended the restaurant. “A free event. It is a risk you take,” one parent said.

Other parents were pleased with the event. “My son loved this event! Thank you for hosting!” another said online.

articles.title: Las Vegas ordinance would restrict balloon releases
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - The City of Las Vegas will consider new penalties for anyone who releases certain types of balloons.

City Council has discussed banning the outdoor release of lighter-than-air balloons, except for meteorological or government purposes, or if it’s a hot-air balloon that is retrieved later.

The ordinance was introduced a week before a mylar balloon caused a power outage that affected about 12,000 people in the Las Vegas Valley last week. The bill’s sponsor tells FOX5 this should be a sign that more laws around balloon releases are needed.

Thousands of people in the Las Vegas Valley were left without power after an NV Energy outage on Thursday night.

“I think last weekend, what happened was a great sort of wake up,” Councilor Nancy Brune said. “You may think you’re having fun celebrating a graduation or a gender reveal, you release these balloons, and the next thing you know, you’re without power.”

Brune says even before the council votes on it, people should still be aware of what they’re releasing. She said the council is launching a public information campaign letting people know about what might happen if these kinds of balloons are released.

“Graduation season is upon us, and we know that is actually one of the most popular times that our residents use to release balloons,” she said.

Brune told FOX5 there have been about 400 outages caused by mylar balloons in the last four years in Las Vegas. Her bill was voted down by a recommending committee, but is still going before City Council on June 5 for a full vote.

articles.title: Animal Foundation hopes new Pet Support Hotline will help lessen their load
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - A new hotline hopes to keep pets in their homes, and help people find their lost pets quicker.

It’s the Animal Foundation’s Pet Support Hotline, and since its soft launch one month ago, it’s already taken nearly 3,000 calls.

Animal Foundation CEO Hilarie Grey says the hotline can be used for a variety of reasons, including people looking for their lost pet, or who’ve found a pet and need help with their next steps.

“Hopefully we can walk those good Samaritans who find a pet in their neighborhood through easy ways to get that pet home so it doesn’t end up in the shelter,” Grey says.

People who are debating surrendering their pets can also call the hotline for resources and advice.

The shelter has taken in over 300 kittens this month.

“We find that a lot of people who are thinking of giving up their pet just need a bit of help, pet food, programs to help with pet rent, she says. “Connections to low-cost vet care.”

The hotline is available seven days a week from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m.. It’s staffed with four customer service representatives who are hired specifically for this role.

Grey says the shelter took in over 600 pets last week. She’s hoping the hotline will help lessen their load.

“Getting those lost pets home and saving them a trip to the shelter, and then helping the people who are struggling to be able to keep their pets, is gonna make sure that we have the space and resources to devote to the animals that need us the most,” she says.

It’s too early for data to see how the hotline has affected their intake numbers, but they’ll be monitoring it closely in the coming months.

To reach the Pet Support Hotline call: 702-955-5932

articles.title: Mt. Charleston elementary school to close due to ‘repair expenses’
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - Clark County School District announced the closure of the only elementary school in Mt. Charleston on Monday.

According to a parent letter obtained by FOX5, officials decided to close Earl B. Lundy Elementary School “due to the expense of rebuilding the school from the storms and flooding caused by Tropical Storm Hilary in August 2023.”

The elementary school caters to about a dozen students, with many able to walk to and from school. However, they have not been able to do that for months since tropical storm Hilary forced the school to close temporarily, and now it does not seem as though the doors will reopen.

“I would basically wake up and get ready for 30 minutes and walk down to the school,” a student said.

For decades, families in the Mt. Charleston area had the comfort of having an elementary school right in their mountain neighborhood.

“It is convenient but also a necessity for our small children to have a school so close,” Katie Reeh said.

That convenience was wiped away along with roads and trails when tropical storm Hilary slammed into the mountains which did not spare Lundy Elementary School.

“It was an abrupt end to the school year,” Sarah Hickam, a parent said. For a whole school year, students at Lundy were placed in Indian Springs, with about an hour bus ride each way.

“It has been tough, especially for my son. I don’t like him getting up at 5:30 in the morning just to get ready for school,” Anthony Armas said.

Many who chose the mountain lifestyle are now left to rethink their plans.

“There is a lot of little ones in this mountain and more families are coming up here they were depending on having a school, so it is very disappointing,” Jessie Thompson another parent said.

For months, since the storm hit, residents told FOX5 they were hopeful the closure was just temporary, but now that they know the school district’s plans to close, they hope they will reconsider.

Officials say the closure is aligned with school district regulations and will be reviewed by CCSD Trustees in June. Those attending Lundy Elementary will be reassigned to Indian Springs Elementary School.

“The Mount Charleston community would maintain a cohesive, feeder school alignment with the opportunity for siblings to attend the same school as the current middle and high school students assigned to Indian Springs Middle School and High School,” administrators noted in the letter.

The complete text of the letter is as follows:

Dear Earl B. Lundy Elementary School Families:

After much review and consideration, we have made the difficult decision to recommend the closure of Earl B. Lundy Elementary School due to the expense of rebuilding the school from the storms and flooding caused by Tropical Storm Hilary in August 2023. We recognize and understand the impact this decision will have on our students, families, staff, and community of Earl B. Lundy Elementary.

The process to recommend the closure of Earl B. Lundy Elementary School is aligned with Clark County School District Regulation 7113, including a recommendation to close the school to the Board of School Trustees at a Regular Board Meeting in June 2024. In addition, the Clark County School District’s Comprehensive Planning Department evaluated the potential attendance zone reassignment options regarding the recommended closure of Earl B. Lundy Elementary School and recommended reassigning the Earl B. Lundy Elementary School students of Mount Charleston to Indian Springs Elementary School. The Mount Charleston community would maintain a cohesive, feeder school alignment with the opportunity for siblings to attend the same school as the current middle and high school students assigned to Indian Springs Middle School and High School.

Please be assured that District staff will be readily available to assist and support you and your children during this transition. We are confident that by working together we will promote the success of our students. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact my office at 702-799-5310.

Dr. Brenda Larsen-Mitchell, CCSD Interim Superintendent

This is a developing story, please check back later for updates.

Copyright 2024 KVVU. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Death Valley historic salt tram tower damaged
articles.content:
LAS VEGAS, Nev. (FOX5) - A historic salt tram tower in Saline Valley has been damaged according to the National Park Service.

Park rangers believe the 113-year-old tower was pulled over while a person used a winch to get their vehicle out of deep mud. NPS seems to think it happened sometime between April 1 and April 24, 2024.

The tower toppled over, pulling its concrete footings out of the ground, officials said. As the investigation continued, rangers found tire marks nearby. They believe the vehicle drove a short distance off the legal roadway and then got stuck.

”I have hiked along sections of this tramway, and am amazed by the tenacity it took to build,” said Superintendent Mike Reynolds. “I hope the person responsible for this damage will contact us so we can discuss restitution.”

Death Valley historic salt tram tower damaged(National Park Service)

Back in the early 1900s, the Saline Valley Salt Company built the 13-mile aerial tram to transport salt from Saline Valley to Owens Valley.

The salt tram is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is considered nationally significant as it climbed over 7,000 vertical feet at steep grades up to 40 degrees. The age, length and preservation of the tower all reflect why NPS is seeking more information.

Only the first four towers are within Death Valley National Park. Most of the tramway crosses lands managed by the Bureau of Land Management. Tram tower #1 is the tower closest to the Saline Valley lakebed.

A salt tram stabilization project was planned before this damage happened. It is unclear if the funding can also be used to re-anchor the fallen tower.

Park rangers are asking anyone with information on this incident to contact the NPS-wide tip line at 888-653-0009 or submit a tip here.

articles.title: Maine Forest and Logging Museum celebrate alewife migration
articles.content:
BRADLEY, Maine (WABI) - Saturday was the annual Alewife Day hosted by Maine Forest and Logging Museum.

“Every year, millions, literally millions of alewives come back up through here to spawn in Chemo Pond,” explains National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) fisheries biologist Max Tritt. “The problem is with the dams and the barriers that we put in their way, they can’t quite make it. So NOAA, our partners Corps of Engineers, several others designed and built this fishway to help get them back into Chemo Pond.”

Tritt estimates it has been about a decade since the fish ladder was constructed in the Blackman Stream that flows through the museum grounds.

Catching a glimpse of the alewives’ journey to Chemo Pond, visitors were able to give them a hand by catching the fish with a net and releasing them into the fishway. With biologists like Tritt present, they were also able to learn about alewives and their annual migration.

Alewives are anadromous, meaning they can live in both fresh and saltwater. Every year, waves of alewives make their way from the ocean up streams like Blackman to reproduce in Chemo Pond. When these eggs hatch, they will swim out into the ocean to begin their own migration journey.

For many, Saturday was their first time touching a live fish.

8-year-old Stella described the alewife as “slimy”, but catching her first fish made her happy!

It was also Wyatt’s, 5, introduction to fishing. He said how to catch a fish was the most fun thing he learned during the all-day event.

Up the hill from the stream you’ll find the smokehouse, where you can sample smoked alewives yourself... I know I had to!

A day of many firsts, it was Erik Anderson’s first time visiting the museum and trying alewife: “Lots of bones, which is to be expected. But I mean the flavor’s gorgeous, has a beautiful caramelized brown color. It’s got a sweet taste to it.”

Getting out of the mainstream, the museum held blacksmith, wool-spinning, and water-powered saw mill demonstrations across the property.

Operation Game Thief were also on the grounds, serving up a barbeque lunch for visitors. The museum has partnered with the state anti-poaching nonprofit.

Why the big fuss for such a small fish? Because, like most anything in nature, alewives play an important role in our ecosystem!

“Alewives are referred to as ‘the fish that feeds everything’, and it can go to sea and they can feed seals, they can feed Cormorants, they can feed people!” remarks Tritt. “So it’s an intricate web, and they’re an integral part of it.”

Alewife Day can also be cause for a mindful moment, says Anderson: “Just seeing where things that you interact with daily come from, especially when it comes to animals and the food we eat. We’re often detached, just going to the grocery store, so it’s neat to see what you can do with the resources around you.”

For museum Board of Directors President Michael Wetherbee, alewives hold ties in Maine history and our environment.

“We want to celebrate that fact that we need to keep this resource going. It’s important for the animals in the area, it’s important for some of the satellite industries, the lobster industry does use alewives for bait,” says Wetherbee. “You have to be responsible about your community, as in the whole ecological and environment community.”

Maine Forest and Logging Museum is open 365 days a week and holds many events throughout the year. They are always looking for volunteers to help tend to their over 400-acre living history museum.

For more information, head over to their website.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Maine (WMTW) - It’s a sign that summer is just around the corner — the historic pier at Old Orchard Beach opened for the season Friday.

It’s one of Maine’s iconic beach landmarks, which draws in thousands from all over every year.

“We are having dinner, and we want some seafood, and we came here for the pier,” said Kevin Gwinn, who was visiting from New York.

The pier opened to the public back in 1898. More than 125 years and a few rebuilds later, the 500-foot spectacle is still providing food, entertainment and fun for visitors and locals alike.

“It’s a good thing. It’s almost tradition and everybody gets excited about the season and we got a lot of new folks coming in and college kids and schoolteachers getting out of school. It’s a lot of fun for us,” said Rich Redmond, pier operator.

Most of the pier’s businesses opened on Friday, so they’ll be prepared for Memorial Day Weekend.

AAA predicts the holiday weekend could be the biggest since 2000 in terms of travelers headed somewhere more than 50 miles away.

“We can handle major crowds, so it’s nothing new to us,” said Redmond.

Pier businesses aren’t the only ones that will see a spike in visitors over the holiday. Dozens of other businesses in OOB opened their doors Friday to prepare for the busy weekend ahead.

“Summer is short, so let’s do it, do it right and have a good time and have a happy 2024,” Redmond said.

“We started out with pizza, basically just pizza and chicken wings and now we’re adding salads and more sandwiches. We hope to add more pub type grub in the future. Maybe some steaks,” stated Al Strong, Owner, Brewer, Strong’s Public House and Patio.

articles.title: Music as Medicine: Lewiston artist battles psychosis, muscle palsy with ukulele
articles.content:
LEWISTON, Maine (WABI) - May is Lyme Disease Awareness Month.

Maine Tracking Network reported almost 3 thousand Mainers were diagnosed with Lyme disease in 2023.

Lyme Disease is spread through blacklegged tick bites. Per the CDC, undiagnosed Lyme disease can spread to and affect the joints, heart, and nervous system.

Awarded installation artist Amy Stacey Curtis of Lewiston has had a long journey fighting the symptoms of what her doctors call untreated Lyme.

Her battle began in March 2017 as suicidal ideation suddenly took over her thoughts.

“I nicknamed the thing that was going on in my head ‘The Imposter’,” says Curtis on the way she felt her brain was being hijacked by these constant distressing thoughts.

From there, her symptoms only worsened: “Six or seven months into the psychosis, I started to lose all the control of my muscles in my body, including the muscles in my face and also to lose the ability to talk.”

After going through multiple doctors, medications, psychiatric hospitals, and even shock therapy, Curtis was recommended to see a naturopathic doctor.

“He said, ‘I think that you have brain inflammation. It can be caused by different things, but it could be caused by Lyme Disease that was never treated. We can’t treat the Lyme Disease itself because it’s not in your system in that way. Lyme Disease attacked your brain and now you have to recover,’” recalls Curtis. “And he said, ‘I’m confident you can fully recover from this.’”

Brain supplements, diet changes, and occupational therapy sessions helped Curtis slowly regain speech and movement.

With nonlinear and slow-moving progress, Curtis desperately wanted independence. She missed the daily tasks she often took for granted, most notably driving.

Through intuiting what would promote multitasking behaviors like operating a car, she decided to take matters into her own hands by learning how to play the ukulele.

“It is really about the focus that’s involved with doing multiple things at the same time. So within a week, I had learned some basic chords and some songs, and within a week, my speech and my dystonia, and any other little tic, within a week, everything was gone,” comments Curtis.

Despite the stellar progress, Curtis notes that her treatment is still not linear. Her speech and muscles still do get palsied in times of overstimulation.

Patricia Mulholland is a Board-Certified Music Therapist, operating Be Your Note Music Therapy in her home. To her, how music has helped reconnect Curtis’ mind and body is apparent.

“Now I did notice when I listened to Amy that her speech is still somewhat impaired. But when she sings, it’s absolutely clear and she has an absolutely beautiful voice,” explains Mulholland. “So that is one of the intentions of using singing as a way to bring language back. She was working on the fine motor, she was strumming and playing, she was looking at a score, and then of course, she was expressing herself vocally. And I would say that even listening to her, I would say there’s a lot of emotional connection there, so she’s really lighting up her limbic system, that’s the emotional center.”

Starting with “Sunday Singalongs” on Facebook live, Curtis was convinced by her art students in November 2021 to take her talents to TikTok.

Now, she has amassed almost 25 thousand followers and over 155 thousand likes.

“I try to do a post every Tuesday of a new song, and then I’m trying to go live every Friday to do my hour of occupational therapy live,” Curtis explains of her current posting schedule.

She says TikTok has felt much more communal compared to other social media: “I’m getting a lot of comments from people who’ve had similar or connected experiences, folks who have people in their lives who have dementia, or stroke, or other types of brain injury, that it’s helpful as well and they share their stories about how music has helped.”

Mulholland echoes this sentiment, saying she has had patients referred by neurologists to her and uses music to keep them creative and their brain stimulated.

Through years of medical trial and error and concerted effort to regain control of her body and mind, the experience has shown Curtis the importance of self-advocacy.

“Self-advocacy, intuiting what I need to do, using art and music in different ways to heal my brain,” remarks Curtis. “Watching the videos from where I’ve come from, it’s pretty amazing to see the difference.”

Currently, Curtis is involved in a music circle that occurs every second Tuesday in Lewiston. She also has prospects of professionally releasing music and her memoir, documenting her story in her own words.

articles.title: 68 police cadets graduate from Basic Law Enforcement Training Program
articles.content:
VASSALBORO, Maine (WABI) - It was an absolutely gorgeous day on Friday as 68 police cadets graduated from the Basic Law Enforcement Training Program.

Over 44 state, municipal, and county law enforcement agencies were represented by one of the biggest classes ever in the program.

Each of the cadets comes in with their own reason to serve.

“I just want to help people. I love helping people,” said Ian Facella of the Orono Police Department.

“I felt a little bit of a call to the job. My dad was a state trooper. So, I kind of grew up around troopers and police officers and it just felt great. I want to serve my community,” said Jared Willette of the Bangor Police Department.

This class in particular included 23 military veterans.

“It’s an opportunity for me to give back and serve and protect and take the skills that I’ve learned not only through this training but through my military experience and do my part in that way,” Willette added.

It’s a long road to get to this point as cadets take on 18 weeks of training.

“In the beginning there’s a lot of yelling and screaming but you get used to it. But near the end, you learn a lot, a lot of different things. A lot of things will help you on the road. It seems like at the beginning 18 weeks is a long time. But once you get to the end, it goes by really quick,” said Facella.

When it’s all said and done, they’re joined by their families onstage to commemorate the end of a journey and the start of a new one.

“It’s elating I mean, just standing there and you know, my father that has put so many years in the State Police standing there and kind of almost like passing the torch down and having my wife being they’re the one that’s my rock and I was always there support me, sitting there with them. Big 7 Travel and enjoytravel.com just ranked the top 50 sexiest accents in the country, and the Maine accent came in at number 4.

articles.title: High schoolers prep for medical emergencies with “mock disaster”
articles.content:
PITTSFIELD, Maine (WABI) - How would you react in a medical emergency?

That was the question for Maine Central Institute students Thursday in Pittsfield.

As part of their Introduction to Medical Concepts class, held in conjunction with Northern Light Sebasticook Valley Hospital, they performed in a mock disaster scenario.

The hospital’s Health and Wellness Education Coordinator Laurie Alexander sets the scene: “The scenario was that there was a track and field event going on, the stands were filled with students and parents and visitors. And this portion of the stands collapsed. And so, what happened, there was a bunch of people that were able to leave the scene, but the five that couldn’t were injured.”

Five student volunteers acted as victims with various medical injuries to gauge how students would treat them. Makeup and prosthetic achieved the look of open wounds on the head and arms and even a broken leg. One volunteer had blue and white face paint under his eyes and on his fingertips to simulate low oxygen circulation. Another had no visible injuries at all, but was prompted to act as if he was internally bleeding.

After the victims were prepped, it was time to send out the crews.

The students were quick to act, patching up wounds, stabilizing bone breaks, and even performing CPR and using a defibrillator.

“I was just like, ‘Oh my God, what patient do I want to go to first? Which one needs the most help?’” MCI student Skyla Dean describes of the experience.

Student Grace Cunningham took the role of team leader, who says: “It was a little stressful. I had to go around to every patient and see what was happening, and then make sure whoever was over there had what was going on.”

Alexander says this mock disaster is the culmination of 14 weeks worth of classes. The Introduction to Medical Concepts class teaches students medical skills like CPR and first aid, as well as job shadowing healthcare workers at Northern Light Sebasticook Valley Hospital.

The class’s teacher at MCI, Angie Palonis, hopes that these hands-on experiences will entice more students to pursue healthcare in the future: “What it is is a great way for students to be introduced to healthcare careers so that they get a better idea of what they might like to do, what they’d like to pursue. As we know in the state of Maine, we’re always needing more healthcare.”

“It’s one thing to read about a career online or talk to somebody on the phone, but to actually see them doing their job and finding out why they liked the job. What are the limitations? What are the challenges, what’s exciting about that career? It really gives them an opportunity to see the whole picture,” remarks Alexander on the significance.

Dean says the emergency scenario has only reaffirmed her desire to pursue healthcare: ”I myself want to go into the ER and be a nurse, so this experience is kind of just a way for me to get an experience of what that’ll be like in a few years to come.”

For students who may be turned off from emergency aid, the job shadowing allows them to peer into many different departments that make up hospitals to find their perfect match.

Ultimately, students got the chance to test their instincts and learning in times it’s needed the most.

“I think it’s very important, so if they do find themselves in these real world emergencies, they already have previous experience with it,” says one student actor Demarcus Smith.

This mock disaster was the first one in four years, due mostly to COVID. It was the third time MCI and Northern Light Sebasticook Valley Hospital conducted this exercise.

articles.title: Congressman Jared Golden demands answers after VA spent millions on bonuses to senior officials
articles.content:
BANGOR, Maine (WABI) - Congressman Jared Golden says he is seeking answers and action following a Veterans Affairs Inspector General report showing the department improperly awarded nearly $11 million in bonuses to senior officials at its central office.

According to Golden, the money came from critical skill incentive payments.

That funding was appropriated by Congress to help recruit and retain employees with in-demand skills that are in short supply. But instead it was used for bonuses for 182 senior executives in the central office.

Golden and a bipartisan group of legislators wrote a letter to the Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, asking why the money is still begin recouped 8 months later and no disciplinary action has been taken.

You can read Golden’s full statement below:

Congressman Jared Golden (ME-02) On Wednesday sent a letter from a bipartisan group of representatives to Dennis McDonough, Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, seeking answers and action following a recent VA Inspector General report that showed the department improperly awarded nearly $11 million in bonuses to senior officials at its central office.

The letter was signed by Golden and Reps. Don Bacon (NE-02), Abigail Spanberger (VA-07), Marie Gluesenkamp Perez (WA-03), Mary Peltola (AK-AL), and Mike Thompson (CA-04).

The VA Inspector General found in September that the agency had used $10.8 million in critical skill incentive (CSI) payments — funds appropriated by Congress to help recruit and retain employees with in-demand skills that are in short supply — to fund bonuses ranging from $39,000 to more than $100,000 to 182 senior executives in the central office.

“While we appreciate that upon learning of these payments in September you demanded the executives reimburse the VA, eight months have passed, and the money is still being recouped,” the members wrote in the letter. “... The VA has an obligation to the veterans and families they serve to claw back the millions of dollars that were improperly distributed, reallocate the funds to their original purpose, and discipline the senior executives who do not comply.

“We will ensure these egregious missteps cannot happen again, and the VA continues to provide veterans and their families with the highest level of quality and access to care.”

The members asked the Secretary whether the VA is working with the Office of the Inspector General to follow its recommendations, what steps the agency is taking to recoup the bonuses, how it will hold senior officials who approved the bonuses accountable, and how it will protect funds from being misused in the future.

You can see the full letter here.

articles.title: Maine comedian joins fundraising effort for Unlimited Solutions Clubhouse
articles.content:
BANGOR, Maine (WABI) - For the third year, adults living with various obstacles will take the stage in Bangor to bare their souls.

Once again, they’ll be joined by friends, both old and new, to share their message of inclusion and hope.

“Unlimited Solutions Clubhouse is, we like to say, the best kept secret. We’d like to be the best-known solution, though,” said Carrie Lemos, executive director, Unlimited Solutions Clubhouse.

Located across from the Bangor Police station on Summer Street, Unlimited Solutions Clubhouse is a therapy through work program. The clubhouse helps adults living with various mental challenges find employment, decrease social isolation, further their education, and increase their overall wellness.

“I really appreciate the clubhouse being here because without it I would really, really struggle,” said April Dowling, member, Unlimited Solutions Clubhouse.

Like all nonprofits they could always use more friends - and more funding.

Back in 2019 they started Melodies for the Mind, a benefit concert to help spread the word about the clubhouse and their services.

“The clubhouse is all about music. If you’re here on a daily basis, we like to say it’s like an episode of ‘Glee,’ Lemos said. “Somebody might break out into song. And so, a benefit concert was kind of a natural place for us to go for a fundraiser.”

As part of the event, a group from the clubhouse takes the stage to sing “Suddenly,” a song written and composed by a fellow member.

“I sing the song ‘Suddenly’ every night before I go to bed, which is the song we’ll be performing,” Dowling said. “The song is all about overcoming your obstacles and reaching new heights.”

Thursday’s lineup includes the annual appearance from Maine Street R&B Revue.

And, in a first this year, Maine comedian and new clubhouse ally Tim Sample will be performing.

“A room full of people, old people, young people, black people, white people, people of different cultural and economic and political backstories, in the same room at the same time laughing at the same thing is a magical transformative experience,” Sample said.

Sample says he jumped at the opportunity to participate in Melodies for the Mind.

He says he has his own personal connection to mental and emotional health issues stemming from a traumatic brain injury as a child that led to a learning disability.

“It was completely undiagnosed and untreated, and created a lot of cognitive dissonance as I went along,” Sample explained.

Now in his 70s, he’s not performing as much.

But he’s looking forward to returning to the Gracie stage with a goal similar to the clubhouse’s mission: bringing people together.

“A place where you feel like you belong, and you don’t belong because you check off all the boxes. You belong because you’re you and that’s a powerful thing,” Sample said.

Melodies for the Mind is scheduled for Thursday, May 16, at the Gracie Theater at Husson University starting at 6:00 p.m.

Tickets are available online at unlimitedsolutionsclubhouse.com or you can buy them at the door.

articles.title: Maine native hosts special screening of film to support veterans
articles.content:
BANGOR, Maine (WABI) - Maine Filmmaker Billy Hanson honored Maine veterans with special screening of his Debut Film Bone Cold.

Wednesday night’s screening was at Gracie Theater at Husson University.

Hanson said he has always wanted to shoot a film in Maine where he lived for the first 18 years of his life.

The film has a central theme revolving around PTSD.

Wednesday night’s screening coincides with mental health awareness month.

Following the film showing there was a discussion portion to talk about the film and its meaning.

“At its core Bone Cold is about a man struggling with PTSD and struggling with his own demons essentially, and so as the story unfolds, you start to see more and more as the layers are peeled back and you realize sort of what the monster is, what it’s trying to do, and what he has to do to stop it and it becomes much more of a mental game then a physical one,” Hanson said.

“Film has a way often of getting people to feel things and talk about things that are just hard to talk about. So when I do psychotherapy with people with PTSD, one of the first things we have to get over is it is uncomfortable to talk about. A film will give them a whole other way to get into that conversation and hopefully start some healing if that needs to occur,” psychologist Dr. David Prescott said.

All proceeds collected were given to the Maine Veteran’s Project.

articles.title: Ex-wife of Robert Card, other relatives expected to testify before Lewiston commission on Thursday
articles.content:
BOWDOIN, Maine (WMTW) - Cara Lamb, the ex-wife of Robert Card, confirmed to Maine’s Total Coverage Wednesday she plans to testify before the independent commission investigating the Lewiston mass shootings on Thursday.

In a March interview with Maine’s Total Coverage, Lamb detailed what she described as warning signs ignored, in her view, by the Sagadahoc County Sheriff’s Office and the U.S. Army Reserve.

Lamb says two more relatives are also planning to testify Thursday before the commission in Augusta but declined to specify who.

Lamb was the first person to report concerns about the eventual Lewiston mass shooter’s deteriorating mental health and is the only family member to speak publicly since.

In a text message to Maine’s Total Coverage Wednesday, Lamb explained why she decided to testify.

“We are doing it to make sure that people, victims, families, ourselves, that we all have as much of the information as possible, that our sheriff’s and army reserves are going to be forced into accepting they did NOT do their jobs to an extent that must be, that change MUST happen. What happens the next time someone goes to them for help????? That’s it. That’s what we all need to know,” she wrote.

Lamb says there is no-one-single moment or missed opportunity that would have directly prevented the shootings that killed eighteen people at two locations in Lewiston.

However, she did say it didn’t have to happen.

Lamb said when the Sagadahoc County Sheriff’s Office went to Card’s home in Bowdoin for a wellness check in September, they should have done more to make contact with him.

“They should have made contact with Rob. They should have kept making contact, trying to make contact. They did not. They did not,” Lamb said.

The commission stated in a press release Thursday’s testimony, “will include members of Robert Card’s family and an official from the Psychological Health Program – Army Reserves.”

Thursday’s hearing begins at 9:00 a.m. inside Jewett Hall at the University of Maine, Augusta campus.

articles.title: Northern Light offering remedy kits for irritation caused by Brown Tail Moths

Northern Light Health says they’re seeing an influx of patients with symptoms caused by the caterpillar’s hairs.

Brown Tail Moth season lasts from mid-April to mid-October.

Northern Light is selling kits at their pharmacies to treat rashes.

If you have any trouble breathing, shortness of breath, any unusual really unusual swelling, you would want to see your provider,” said Pharmacist Heather Sudik.

articles.title: UTC hosts career fair for students
articles.content:
BANGOR, Maine (WABI) - Summer is fast approaching, and for some students at UTC in Bangor, that means they’re set to enter the workforce soon.

On Wednesday, the school hosted a career fair to help students connect with potential future employers.

“I love job fairs. I love meeting people and seeing what actual opportunities are around this area that I can actually like. It’s very effective. I could actually walk away with having a plan and saying, okay, these are my opportunities, real world opportunities that I can do outside of school and can actually be beneficial for me in the long run, I guess,” said Embree Thomas, a Health Occupations student.

UTC is a school in which local high school students can come and learn a trade or skill.

Getting that kind of experience early on can be enticing for employers.

“We’ve always had great success with the students here at UTC. We find that they’re very professional. They’re so eager to learn, and you can pick them right out of the group, you know, that you know who’s going to go the furthest, you know, in their education,” said Susan Cronkhite, a clinical supervisor at St. Josheph Hospital.

The school offers a range of different professions to learn about, and the fair was full of options.

“I think these things are always great because it gives all students from different programs look into like, fields around the area, and I think that that’s very important because especially since we live in Maine, we want people to stay in Maine,” said Sam Wingard, a law enforcement student.

“I talked to the Old Town police officers, and that’s like a department that like, I really think is interesting because like, I want to stay in the area. And, I do want a future in law enforcement once I like graduate college and stuff,” Wingard added.

For many, the future can be uncertain, but that’s where the fair comes in.

“Yeah, it’s definitely settled a lot of nerves for me for sure. It’s going from knowing nothing, like how do I even get a job? You know, because school doesn’t really teach you that. To go into a job fair meeting these people who are like, I have a job where you know, you can work here,” said Thomas.

Officials say as they started to put the fire out, the bales started falling down which created a hazard for firefighters.

articles.title: Maine Forest and Logging Museum gears up for Alewife Day
articles.content:
BRADLEY, Maine (WABI) - On Saturday, you can get a taste of Maine’s rich logging and forestry history all while witnessing the migration of hundreds of thousands of alewife fish.

This is part of Maine Forest and Logging Museum’s Alewife Day.

“Every year we have a migration of the alewives, which is a river herring. They come up Blackman Stream, and they migrate their way up to Chemo Pond,” explains museum volunteer Bryan Harper.

According to Harper, how many alewives pass along the stream is dependent on various factors including weather. He says due to colder weather last year, about 550,000 fish migrated through the stream. The year before, Harper estimates it was about 600,000 alewives.

With the warmer weather this week, Harper is hopeful of their outcome.

“I’m hoping that for the fish, you will see a huge influx of them as the day warms up. Sunday, we had 12,500 that went up through the fish ladder, and Monday we had 15,000 by, I think it was, 10 a.m.,” he said.

Alongside the alewife migration, the museum will be brimming with activity for all-age fun and learning. You can participate in the 5K fun run, visit the blacksmith shop or water-powered sawmill, or the smokehouse to sample some alewives yourself!

Due to permits, the museum is able to catch about 250 fish to smoke. It is a three-day process of brining the fish and hanging them in the smokehouse to cook. Volunteers like Harper must tend to the fire inside the smokehouse every three hours to ensure efficiency.

Perfectly placed to see the alewives pass through during their pilgrimage, the museum saw it as an opportunity for a lesson in Maine forestry history.

“We have been here for over 60 years. We cover over 400 acres. It’s a living history museum, and logging is such an incredible history, especially in Maine,” comments Alissa Wetherbee, who is on the museum’s Board of Directors. “You usually find someone whose father, grandfather, great grandfather, grandmother, had logging in their family history.”

“Part of the history with Maine and the forestry industry, especially out in the woods, would be trying to maintain your logging camps with fresh produce, fish, so smoking was a big part of that in this area because of the migration of the alewives,” explains Harper on alewives’ connection to the area. “It gave them that unique opportunity to have a supplement for their food source.”

The fun run is slated to start at 9 a.m., and the festivities will run until 3 p.m.

It costs $10 for adults and $5 for kids, but museum members get in for free.

For more information, visit Maine Forest and Logging Museum’s website.

articles.title: Iowa teen with no limbs trains on custom truck by Maine company
articles.content:
DECORAH, Iowa (KCRG) - A teenager is gaining independence with a new truck. One that’s unlike any other on the road.

As Anders Lovstuen is getting ready to finish up high school, he’s also learning to drive his newly outfitted truck.

People from Maine to Texas helped make this vehicle possible.

“There are solutions out there to a lot of problems that you didn’t even know existed,” said Anders.

Decorah native Anders Lovstuen, 18, was born without arms or legs.

“I’ve never really known anything different. So you know it’s not necessarily... Yeah, there are a few things I can’t do, but most things I can do, even if I do them a little bit differently than everybody else,” said Anders.

And that includes driving.

When Anders was 15, he reached out to his local Vocational Rehabilitation Services to see what the options were.

Decorah’s VR got Anders in contact with Texas-based Driving Ambitions, a company that helps people with disabilities drive.

“Did the initial evaluation, you know how or what sort of system is going to be necessary for me to drive?” said Anders.

From there Anders trained on an outfitted van learning all the controls. But because Anders lives on a gravel road, they quickly learned he needed something a bit bigger.

So, they looked into a Maine-based company called Electronic Mobility Controls -- and they were able to outfit a truck with everything Anders needs to drive.

“Little regular things like that really help sink in the magnitude of me being able to drive and, you know, go places and do things that I want to do,” said Anders.

Once the truck was outfitted, it was shipped back to Iowa for Anders to complete his training.

He uses a joystick with his shoulder to drive and a touch screen with his nose for things like putting the truck into gear.

Michael Courtney, a driver evaluator for Driving Ambition said he’ll go through 40 hours of training.

“It’s very comprehensive. We take them everywhere in between the parking lot to the freeway and of course, working on parking and everything else, getting them prepared to be able to control the vehicle,” said Courtney.

Anders said once he passes his driver’s exam, he’ll drive himself to graduation parties and see his show cattle on his Grandpa and Uncle’s farm.

“I can just go there by myself,” said Anders.

And Anders said for those with disabilities, it’s never too late to give up on the chance of independence.

“If you really look hard, there a lot of problems have already been solved that you might not think would have,” he said. “Yeah, there’s a lot of different cool stuff out there.”

articles.title: Rep. Golden reacts to decision by USPS to delay proposed changes to Hampden facility until January
articles.content:
HAMPDEN, Maine (WABI) - The United States Postal Service says it will pause proposed changes at the Hampden Processing Facility until January 1st.

The Postal Service proposed converting the Hampden facility into a local processing center which would force outgoing mail to Scarborough.

USPS also says it will pause similar changes to other facilities across the nation.

The response from USPS follows a letter sent by a bipartisan group of senators including Maine’s Susan Collins, Rep. Golden, and Angus King.

Collins said in a statement Tuesday, “This USPS pause is welcome news for the people of Maine. This pause, however, should not be temporary – it should be permanent. The USPS should abandon these proposed changes entirely until there can be a study that ensures mail delivery will not be harmed, and we will continue to press them to do so.”

Meanwhile, Golden released the following statement following the announcement:

“I’ve fought tooth and nail to protect rural communities from the restructuring proposed by USPS because I know how Mainers rely on the mail to receive medicine, conduct business, and keep in touch with their loved ones,” Golden said. “This announcement is a big win for the entire state, and I’ll continue to push for a permanent stop to any plans that threaten mail service.”

USPS’ moratorium follows Golden’s introduction of bipartisan legislation to freeze Mail Processing Facility Reviews (MPFRs) nationwide and his repeated outreach to DeJoy throughout the review of the Hampden facility to express concerns about the agency’s consolidation process.

“We were very pleased to see that the Postal Service is pausing the current network changes until next year,” Scott Adams, President of the American Postal Workers Union of Maine, said. “That should give sufficient time to assess the current delayed mail issues and hopefully correct them, inclusive of returning the process to the way it was before DeJoy’s changes were implemented.  There are no details to the effect this will have on the Eastern Maine P&DC, but since most changes have yet to take place, we see this as great news that should benefit Mainers and their mail service.  Again, thanks to Congressman Golden’s efforts on this, as the decision clearly came about from the pressure from Congress and Postal patrons.”

In a letter today to Sen. Gary Peters, chairman of the Senate’s Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee, Postmaster General Louis DeJoy said he “need[s] more time to evaluate” the effects of MPFRs on timely mail service following outreach from lawmakers in both chambers and that he “will not advance these efforts without advising you of our plans to do so, and then only at a moderated pace of implementation.”

Mail Processing Facility Reviews were launched in 2021 to study the feasibility of relocating certain postal operations from local facilities to larger regional ones. The USPS first announced that it was reviewing consolidation of some mail processing from the Eastern Maine facility into its Scarborough site last November, and its decision to move forward with the plan follows a February public hearing that garnered widespread opposition from Mainers across the state.

Last month, Golden introduced bipartisan legislation to eliminate funding for the Mail Processing Facility Review process, effectively blocking the USPS’ plans to shift mail processing from Hampden to Scarborough. The Timely Mail Delivery and Postal Services Protection Act would also require any future consideration of consolidation to be reviewed by the Postal Regulatory Commission, an independent and bipartisan oversight panel composed of members appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate.

Prior to his legislation, Golden demanded answers about what steps the agency was taking to prevent mail delays and job losses in the Second District.

Full text of the legislation can be found here.

articles.title: Maine governor refuses to sign dozens of bills passed by lawmakers on Veto Day
articles.content:
AUGUSTA, Maine (AP) - The chaotic conclusion of the Maine Legislature’s session won’t include any new laws: Democratic Gov. Janet Mills said Tuesday she won’t sign any of the 35 bills sent to her on the final day of the session, allowing all of them to die.

Mills, who believed Democratic leaders were disregarding her request to be fiscally responsible, was at odds with those who sought to vote on 80 additional bills requiring spending on a final day, which is normally reserved for vetoes. She said it was wrong to try to adopt so many additional bills after the statutory adjournment date had passed.

Mills’ position caused tension when the Senate attempted to deliver 35 enacted bills to her office on Friday. Her office initially declined to accept them, creating a standoff between the executive and legislative branches. The House did not try to adopt additional bills, heeding the governor’s wishes. Ultimately, lawmakers adjourned without further action.

In a written statement, the governor said she was rejecting “harmful precedent” by declining to act on the bills, and she chastised legislative leaders for disregarding constitutional norms that provide “important institutional safeguards.”

“While well intentioned, the Legislature’s decision to consider and enact dozens of additional spending measures on veto day without clear constitutional authority erodes longstanding norms and would create a destabilizing precedent that may be used by future legislatures to achieve aims not so desirable,” she wrote.

State law required the legislative session to end April 17 but lawmakers were allowed to return to deal with vetoes. A spokesperson for the governor said there’s precedent for lawmakers to take up a few other bills on the so-called “veto day” but only with the consent of both parties. Enacting all of the proposed bills would’ve invited lawsuits, the spokesperson said.

Copyright 2024 WABI. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Palmyra woman frustrated, claims drivers ignore stop signs
articles.content:
PALMYRA, Maine (WABI) - Heather Hill is frustrated.

She says drivers ignore a stop sign at the intersection of Spring Hill and Wiers Roads.

“Maybe a third of the people just go through the stop sign. Maybe another third kind of slow down to a rolling stop, and then maybe the other third actually make a complete stop,” said Hill, who lives near the intersection.

“She has a legitimate complaint. She lives in a rural area. It’s a four-way intersection there, four-way stop. Every vehicle approaching the intersection is supposed to come to a complete stop before they proceed through the intersection and a lot of vehicles don’t, and, you know, I understand we’ve had several complaints from people living in that area that people will roll right through that stop sign. Some of them won’t even slow down,” explained Mike Mitchell, Chief Deputy, Somerset County Sheriff’s Office.

“I think law enforcement is overwhelmed with a lot of other problems, and they simply don’t have the people and the time and the resources to devote what is necessary to the corner,” added Hill.

Somerset County’s Deputy Chief says deputies do enforce the laws when they are present.

“All the deputies for the Somerset County Sheriff’s Office that patrol that particular area are aware of the complaint and during their discretionary time when they’re out on patrol, they should be passing through that area and taking enforcement action as deemed necessary, if they see motorists failing to stop at one of those intersections,” Mitchell stated.

Hill continues to try and have her voice heard.

“I have contacted the town select board, I’ve contacted the town office, I’ve contacted the state and state police, sheriff, you know, and a lot of times they’ll say, ‘well, if people are going through the stop sign, it’s a law enforcement issue,’ and we have made all kinds of phone calls,” said Hill

“This is a town-maintained roadway as opposed to a state highway. The town could, there’s some implements that they could put, like speed bumps in that area if they wanted to, flashing yellow signs, caution stop sign ahead, you know, to give somebody a warning, maybe another sign prior to approaching that intersection, it warns you that a stop sign is ahead. These are things that several towns have put near intersections, particular dangerous intersections,” added Mitchell.

Copyright 2024 WABI. All rights reserved.

articles.title: Employers connect with young Mainers at Maine Employer Summit
articles.content:

“Today has been pretty interesting and entertaining. There’s a lot of fun and interactive things to do and you get to learn about a lot of different things and people,” said Ethan Griffith, a sophomore at Nokomis High School.

“We wanted to be able to bring employers together to be able to have critical conversations about some of the needs that they have while also elevating and bringing in young people, youth, and young adults’ perspective,” explained Kay Kerina, Program Manager, Maine Career Exploration Program.

Bath Iron Works even brought a trailer to show what a career there could look like.

“This trailer gives us an opportunity, one is to test their skills, to give them a job interview. We can do that through virtual welding, painting, augmented reality. We can also use this trailer for training simulations, give people the opportunity to see what it’s like to work at our shipyard and experience some of the trades that some schools might not be able to offer,” said Thomas Stevens, Director of Training, Bath Iron Works.

The event aims to let youth and young adults find out what works or doesn’t work for them.

“It’s all about relationship building and people are going up and saying, ‘Why is this your passion?’, and they might find something in their brain and be like, ‘Oh my God, I never thought that that would be something I want to do,’ and it’s just as important for someone to walk up and be like, “It’s super cool that you do that, but I’ve just learned through this conversation. I don’t want to do that’, and I think that’s important, too,” explained Devon Mulligan, a program coordinator with Maine Youth Action Network.

“Really an opportunity for young people to try potentially hands on. ‘What does this career look like before I commit to it for an internship or a paid work experience? What does this look like?’ and so, the employers have brought a variety of things for young people to try, and it’s been incredible,” added Kerina.

articles.title: Maine funeral home owner will surrender license as funeral home practitioner
articles.content:
GARDINER, Maine (WABI) - The Maine Board of Funeral Services met Tuesday to address complaints against Harold “Chip” Lamson.

Lamson Funeral Home locations have been under investigation, and two, one in Lincoln and the other in Millinocket, were recently searched as part of a theft investigation

Complaints against Lamson pertain to issues with mortuary trusts, deficiencies with funeral services, and failing to communicate with families, among other things.

Nine complaints were brought against Lamson that included more than 60 violations.

On Tuesday morning, Lamson, along with his attorney and the Assistant Attorney General representing the Board Staff, presented a Consent Agreement to the board.

“As part of a consent agreement, Mr. Lamson admits to all of the factual allegations that have been made in the notice of hearing. He acknowledges the truthfulness of each of those factual statements. We have nine different matters. Like I said, he does not dispute any of the facts in any of the complaints against him,” said Assistant Attorney General John Belisle

Lamson agreed to surrender his license in no more than 120 days.

“The reason that we’ve agreed to 120 days is to give him time to essentially run his business, provide continuity to the community, and wrap up any ongoing client obligations he has, as of today. It would give him an opportunity to sell, lease, transfer, or close businesses or to hire another licensed, responsible person that can come in and run his operation for him,” said Belisle.

If Lamson settles these items and finds a new licensee to take over, he has to notify the board and likely surrender his license sooner.

“As part of this probationary period of 120 days, Mr. Lamson has agreed to fully cooperate with any mortuary trust audits that he has for any mortuary trust accounts that he currently manages. With that, the audit will be carried out by staff and we’re complying officer and Mr. Lamson has agreed to provide full cooperation and access and copies of any records that he himself has custody and control of.

Lamson’s license will be revoked for five years.

He could reapply in three years, but would need board approval to be reinstated.

“As additional oversight and terms of probation. Mr. Lamson has agreed to submit weekly written reports to board staff. Next, Mr. Lamson is agreeing to return all client property and funds and to respond to requests for records and he is committing to make reasonable efforts to resolve any of the outstanding issues and the nine complaints at issue this morning,” said Belisle.

The board discussed points of concerns of the agreement with Lamson and his attorney.

“I just hope that the severity of what has happened over the last several years is acknowledged and the acknowledgement that there are very, as I said earlier, very scared families right now not knowing what’s going to happen if they have a death. I just really hope that’s acknowledged by Mr. Lamson and that he sees that this behavior whether it’s from him or from any other license,” said Belisle.

After further discussion and review, the board voted to accept the Consent Agreement.

“It is a unanimous four,” said a board member.

articles.title: Fallen law enforcement commemorated at 32nd memorial service
articles.content:
AUGUSTA, Maine (WABI) - National Police Week falls on May 15 this year, a yearly remembrance event to commemorate all law enforcement lives lost in the line of duty.

The 32nd annual Maine Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Observance was held in Augusta Tuesday morning.

Eighty-eight names on the Maine Law Enforcement Memorial eternalize the state troopers, officers, game wardens, and more who made the greatest sacrifice while serving and protecting their communities.

The monument was erected in 1991 by the Maine Chiefs of Police Association following the death of Lewiston Police Officer David Payne.

Speakers observed all 88 officers on the memorial and acknowledged the sacrifices families and loved ones of law enforcement make every day, never knowing what their officer’s work day will bring.

“In my 29 years of law enforcement, I can confirm there is no greater burden and no greater honor than to bear the loss of a friend, a colleague, or a loved one in service to our communities,” said Auburn Police Chief Jason Moen during his remarks.

He told us the importance of never forgetting the single name of a fallen Maine officer, “They gave the ultimate sacrifice in service of the state, and when you lay down your life for someone else, that is the greatest sacrifice you can make, and it’s very important for us to make sure that we honor that every year.”

Gov. Janet Mills was the keynote speaker, who honored the service and sacrifice officers make every day in our communities.

“We grieve the loss of friends, family, and neighbors taken from us through this violence. May we also pause in solemn gratitude that we need not add another name for this memorial today,” said Mills during her address. “As district attorney, as a private attorney, as your attorney general, and now as your governor, please know that I see the unexpected risks that each of you take when you report to duty every day. I see the sacrifice of your loved ones, waiting to know if you will come home safely. And I see the spirit of our fallen officers embodied in your commitment to serve our community and to keep this state the safest place in the nation to live, work, and raise a family.”

Despite all the differences fallen officers hold in their stories, Mills united them under one principle: “A principle that governed how they upheld the law, a promise to practice integrity, fairness, respect, and compassion in the 1000 daily acts they performed on behalf of the Maine people. As they patrolled our roads, guarded our cities and towns, our woods, lakes, bays, and skies, always ready for that one urgent call that may mean the difference between life and death.”

For Department of Public Safety Commissioner Michael Sauschuck, the importance of the memorial service lies in continuing their legacy in law enforcement and recognizing loved ones: “It gives us an opportunity to honor their lives, their careers, as well as their families for all that they’ve given to all of us.”

White carnations were given to loved ones to honor the memory of their fallen officer and to acknowledge the sacrifices they make every day.

The family of State Trooper Charles Black, who died in service 60 years ago, make it a point to attend the memorial every year.

“It was three weeks before I was born,” said Trooper Black’s son Charlie Black II. “That was kind of a defining moment and defining date for our family. It was never the same after that. You never know when routine can go to tragedy in an instant.”

Four years ago, the Black family began the nonprofit organization Trooper Black Foundation. Their mission is to provide resources and support to first responders and their families during times of crisis or need.

articles.title: New industry readies for launch as researchers hone offshore wind turbines that float
articles.content:
ORONO, Maine (AP) — As waves grew and gusts increased, a wind turbine bobbed gently, its blades spinning with a gentle woosh. The tempest reached a crescendo with little drama other than splashing water.

The uneventful outcome is exactly what engineers aimed for.

The demonstration featuring a 13-foot-tall (4-meter-tall) floating wind turbine in an indoor pool aimed to ensure it can withstand the strain of powerful water and wind when much larger versions are deployed in the ocean.

It’s the University of Maine’s contribution to a worldwide race to improve floating machines to tap wind that blows across deeper waters offshore, too deep to attach turbines to the seabed with permanent pilings.

In the next decade, UMaine researchers said, they envision turbine platforms floating in the ocean beyond the horizon, stretching more than 700 feet (210 meters) skyward and anchored with mooring lines.

“These structures are massive,” said Anthony Viselli, chief engineer for offshore wind technology at the university’s Advanced Composites Center, after the demonstration wrapped up. “These would be some of the largest moving structures that humankind has endeavored to create. And there would be many of them.”

As the technology advances, dozens of designs are being promoted by experts who see floating wind turbines as a way to address climate change by shifting away from burning fossil fuels.

Floating turbines are the only way some countries and U.S. states can capture offshore wind energy on a large scale. In the U.S. alone, 2.8 terawatts of wind energy potential blows over ocean waters too deep for traditional turbines that affix to the ocean floor, according to the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. That's enough to power 350 million homes — more than double the number of existing homes in the U.S.

The first floating wind farm started operating off Scotland's coast in 2017. In the United States, the Department of Interior two weeks ago proposed the first floating wind energy auctions for the Gulf of Maine, following lease auctions for the West Coast that began in 2022. The nearly 1 million acres up for auction off the New England coast could generate enough clean wind energy to power more than 5 million local homes, the department said.

UMaine is home to the nation's largest team of engineers dedicated to floating offshore wind. Other big players include Equinor, which has installed a demonstration floating project of the coast of Norway; global company Principle Power, which has installed small-scale projects off Scotland and Portugal; and SBM Offshore, which has a demonstration project off France.

Floating offshore wind is still a nascent industry, however, making it expensive.

The Norwegian company Equinor postponed its Trollvind floating initiative, citing technology availability, rising costs and a strained timetable to deliver on the original concept.

Danish wind energy developer Ørsted decided to focus its efforts on fixed-bottom turbines, foregoing deeper offshore regions including Japan, Norway, Spain, Portugal and the U.S. West Coast. "We care a lot about affordability of renewable power, and floating wind is a lot more expensive than bottom-fixed," said CEO Mads Nipper.

But others are moving forward.

Gazelle Wind Power is developing a modular platform system to make manufacture and assembly cost-effective and efficient.

“This is a global problem and this is an ideal solution in order to deliver power to shore,” said Gazelle Wind Power CEO Jon Salazar.

UMaine launched its first floating prototype a decade ago and became a surprise global leader after a study showed that the Gulf of Maine had the wind energy potential of 156 nuclear power plants, due to fast, consistent wind.

The state could meet all its home heating needs and power every car — if they were all electric vehicles — by tapping just 3% of that water. That improves the odds of successfully sharing the resource with fishermen, recreational boaters, the military and, of course, marine life. Indeed, the federal government's lease proposal spares Maine's key lobstering grounds from development, removing a potential obstacle.

Trailblazers in offshore wind are benefiting from work done by the oil industry, which engineered floating oil and gas rigs, said Habib Dagher, director of the Advanced Composites Center.

The university's wind wave basin, which looks something like a swimming pool with wave and wind generators that can mimic ocean conditions up to a 500-year storm, takes that work to the next level.

On a recent day, the semi-submersible floating turbine was tethered to the bottom of the basin. Its 1:70 scale represented a real turbine standing about 800 feet (240 meters) tall atop a platform in the ocean. The goal is to have industrial scale turbines of 15 to 20 megawatts each, Dagher said.

Size and efficiency are keys to profitability. Larger wind turbines mean fewer are needed, reducing construction, installation and maintenance costs, Viselli said. With greater size and efficiency, developers envision only about 50 turbines needed to produce about the same amount of electricity as a nuclear power plant.

Full-size turbines generate peak power starting at about 20 mph (32 kph). In powerful storms, they shut down automatically to avoid stressing the equipment or breaking. The mooring lines tethered to the ocean floor are made of rope nearly thick as a telephone pole and under heavy tension. That makes them safer for marine mammals.

For all the turbine technology, the platforms developed by UMaine can be built locally with concrete, a simple material that's readily available. The university already has partners around the world interested in licensing its technology. The state of Maine plans to develop a port facility in the Searsport area to build the floating bases and attach turbines before sending them into the Gulf of Maine.

A brand new industry means some experiments in design will succeed and some will fail. And there is work to ensure that wind farms are good neighbors, overcoming objections from others using the ocean.

“We’re going to have some problems and we have to figure out how to roll up our sleeves and solve these problems,” Dagher said. “And I think we have no choice as a society but to do that.”

___

McDermott reported from Providence, Rhode Island.

articles.title: Another Mainer charged in Jan. 6 Capitol riot
articles.content:
KITTERY, Maine (WMTW) - Another person from Maine has been arrested for their role in the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021.

Lincoln Deming, 44, of Kittery, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building and parading, picketing, or demonstrating in a Capitol building.

Deming was arrested on May 11 in Maine and was scheduled to make his initial appearance Monday in federal court in Maine.

According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Deming was on the West Plaza of the U.S. Capitol, where police officers had erected barricades made of interlocking metal bike racks to prevent the crowd from advancing closer to the Capitol building.

According to prosecutors, the video shows Deming pulling on a bike rack barricade in an apparent attempt to infiltrate the police line and allow rioters to overtake the West Plaza. He is seen falling while pulling on the barrier.

Body-camera footage shows Deming approaching the police line again and, at approximately 2:07 p.m., throwing an object toward officers on the West Plaza. Deming left the West Plaza and made his way up a set of stairs to the Upper West Terrace at approximately 2:18 p.m.

Court documents say Deming entered the Capitol through the Senate Wing door at approximately 2:23 p.m. and remained inside the Capitol for approximately 33 minutes. He made his way to the third floor, where he attempted to open several locked doors, including the Dome Bulfinch door and also entered the Senate Gallery.

Deming exited the Capitol through the Rotunda Doors at approximately 2:56 p.m.

He is at least the 10th person from Maine charged in connection with the riot.

In the 40 months since Jan. 6, 2021, more than 1,424 people have been charged in connection to the breach of the U.S. Capitol, including more than 500 people charged with assaulting or impeding law enforcement.

articles.title: Sen. Collins questions proposed changes to volunteer fire department standards
articles.content:
WASHINGTON - Sen. Susan Collins has questioned the acting Secretary of Labor about proposed changes to volunteer fire department standards she says would be detrimental to rural communities in Maine.

The proposed changes are from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

In an Appropriations hearing last week, Collins said rural departments have concerns about meeting the compliance costs and potential training requirements in order to continue operations.

Collins asked the acting Secretary of Labor if she would work with small, rural departments in order to keep them running.

”Yes, I will definitely commit to you that we will work with all stakeholders, but especially what you’re saying, the voluntary and rural first responder forces that are so vital, both to make sure that we hear them, and that we produce a standard that keeps them safe as well,” said Julie Su, the acting Secretary of Labor.

Collins says OSHA has estimated the nationwide compliance costs for the proposed changes would exceed 100-million dollars per year for volunteer fire departments.

articles.title: Bangor modifies public restroom plans
articles.content:
BANGOR, Maine (WABI) - The city of Bangor is moving forward with plans to add public restrooms to areas around the city.

After public forums in March and April the city has decided to go forward with five public restrooms rather than the originally proposed six.

The latest proposed locations are Broad Street, Cascade Park, Abbot Square, Essex woods, and Coe park.

During a meeting with Councilors, organizers said the facilities will be maintained twice a week by a third party service and checked on by Parks employees daily.

Two units can be completed approximately every 3 weeks.

”For me, what’s top of mind is safety and cleanliness, and so having to just start being able to figure out the maintenance schedule and how to maintain it. What I hope is that these public restrooms are going to gain a reputation that they are safe and clean and people want to use them,” said Council Chair Cara Pelletier.

“Just to reiterate that we do a lot for our unhoused population, but this is not a program specifically targeted to our unhoused, It’s targeted to everyone,” said Councilor Gretchen Schaefer.

The city intends to start with Broad Street and Cascade park, allowing time for a trial run.
