DODGE COUNTY, Wis. (WMTV) - A Dodge County Board Supervisor and school board member that was arrested for allegedly bringing a gun with him into a school appeared in court Thursday afternoon.

Daniel Siegmann was arrested on Wednesday for allegedly bringing a gun into a meeting at a Herman Neosho Rubicon elementary school, according to law enforcement.

The Dodge Co. Sheriff’s Office says they asked the Ozaukee Co. Sheriff’s Office to take over the case due to Siegmann being critical of Dodge Co. law enforcement in the past.

Ozaukee Co. District Attorney Adam Gerol said he is not aware of any criminal history with Siegmann and that he is a concealed carry permit holder.

“I am asking that the court release the defendant on a $5,000 signature bond,” District Attorney Gerol said on Thursday. “I’m asking that the court order him not to possess any weapon in any public facility, any prohibited location and certainly not within 1,000 feet of a school.”

In a letter sent to families in the Herman Neosho Rubicon School District, District Administrator Chris Nesemann said “At no time did the board member post any kind of threat, and the board member agreed to be escorted out of the school.”

The letter also stated the district is in full cooperation with Dodge County law enforcement as they continue this investigation.

As of early Wednesday evening, Siegmann does not appear on the Dodge Co. Jail roster.

His preliminary hearing is scheduled for June 20th.

Here is the full statement from the district:

Dear Families:

I am writing to update you about a situation that took place on school grounds yesterday.

At approximately 3:00 pm, a Herman-Neosho-Rubicon School District board member attended a scheduled

meeting at the Honor Elementary District Office. The board member checked in as a visitor, as per normal

procedure. During the meeting, the board member noticed that the concealed gun they were licensed to carry

was not removed before they walked into the school. After notifying me of this, I followed policy and

immediately escorted the board member to their vehicle, and they drove off the school grounds.

At no time did the board member pose any kind of threat, and the board member agreed to be escorted out of

the school. Also, as per policy, I contacted local law enforcement to inform them of the situation. We are in

full cooperation with the Dodge County Police Department as they continue this investigation. At this time, I

am not aware of any charges or tickets issued by law enforcement.

The board member involved in the situation has voluntarily resigned from their position with the

Herman-Neosho-Rubicon School District.

Thank you for your attention to this communication.

Sincerely,

Chris Nesemann, District Administrator

articles.title: Wisconsin election officials fear voter confusion over 2 elections for same congressional seat
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (AP) — Wisconsin election officials voted Thursday to provide more details to voters than normal to avoid confusion about a ballot that will have both a special and regular election for a vacant congressional seat.

The rare anomaly for the 8th Congressional District is due to the timing of former U.S. Rep. Mike Gallagher’s surprise resignation. Under state law, if Gallagher had quit before April 9, a special election before November would have had to be called.

Gallagher quit on April 24, which required Gov. Tony Evers to call the special election on the same dates as the Aug. 13 primary and Nov. 5 general election.

That means that voters in the northeastern Wisconsin congressional district will be voting to elect someone in a special election to fill the remainder of the current term, which runs until Jan. 3, and then vote separately for someone to fill the regular two-year term starting in January.

“There is a source for confusion present here and it will be very difficult to avoid any voter confusion,” said Wisconsin Elections Commission attorney Brandon Hunzicker at a meeting Thursday.

To help avoid confusion, the commission voted to have the ballot show the length of both the special election and the regular term. Voters in the congressional district will also be handed an explanation of why the same congressional seat is on the ballot twice.

The exact wording of both the ballot and the information sheet will be considered by the commission next month.

“If we’re not clarifying that for the voter, we have done the voters a disservice,” commissioner Ann Jacobs said.

Candidates for the office will also be required to circulate separate nomination papers for both the special and regular elections. Those nomination papers are due June 3.

State Sen. André Jacque, of De Pere, former state Sen. Roger Roth, of Appleton, and former gas station and convenience store owner Tony Wied, are all running as Republicans for the seat. Wied has been endorsed by former President Donald Trump.

Dr. Kristin Lyerly is the only announced Democrat in the race.

Wisconsin’s 8th Congressional District is solidly Republican, but Democrats have vowed to make it competitive.

Trump won the district by 16 percentage points in 2020, even though he lost the state by less than a point to President Joe Biden. Gallagher won reelection three times by no fewer than 25 points. The district includes the cities of Appleton and Green Bay, Door County and covers mostly rural areas north through Marinette.

articles.title: River Food Pantry set to build new facility after raising over $11 million
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - Over $11 million has been raised to build a new food pantry on Madison’s north side. The River Food Pantry’s new facility will help serve more meals to the community.

The new building will be triple the size of the pantry’s current one.

“A new building is really necessary for us,” River Food Pantry executive director Rhonda Adams said. “I’ve been here for 11 years and the need has been since day one.”

The River Food Pantry serves over 2,500 people per week. This year, the pantry said its demand is up around 25% and is serving more people than ever before.

“Really understanding that food insecurity is real, that it is our neighbors or family members or coworkers that are struggling to make ends meet and to put food on the table,” Adams said.

The pantry rents its current warehouse on Darwin Road. The new building will be along Packers Avenue and will be entirely owned by the nonprofit organization.

“Just as inflation increases and food is getting more expensive, and more people are coming for services, it’s our job to keep up and be able to meet our community’s needs,” River Food Pantry Director of Operations Helen Osborn-Senatus said.

The 32,500-square-foot facility will support expanded food and meal programs.

“It’ll be delicious food and an atmosphere that they’re comfortable in,” Osborn-Senatus said. “Maybe they can’t afford to go out to a restaurant, but they can count on the River to have a really good dinner and bring their family too and then get to meet other people as well.”

Money for the new building has come from donors, a federal grant and public funding from Dane County and the City of Madison.

“It’s a little bit overwhelming,” Adams said. “I have to pinch myself to know that this is really happening.”

The pantry has raised around $11.4 million through its Recipe for Hope campaign. It’s just short of their $12 million goal.

Adams said the pantry is still accepting donations. To donate, click here.

The new building is slated to open by summer of 2025.

Sober Social(WMTV)

Sober Social is meant to bridge the gap between sober living and society. Bright says some people are worried a sober lifestyle means they will miss out. She says that’s not the case.

articles.title: Experts share how DNA and genealogy matching identified Chimney Doe
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - A team of DNA lab technicians and bioinformatic experts worked with a single hair from 1989 and online genealogy matching databases to identify Chimney Doe.

DNA lab experts broke down a rootless hair found with Ronnie Joe Kirk’s bones and then matched it with his relatives online to identify his remains. On Monday, the Madison Police Department shared Kirk’s identity, a discovery made this year after a decades long investigation. Kirk’s skeletal remains were found inside a Madison music store’s chimney in September of 1989.

A team of forensic scientists made the identification possible through their volunteer organization called the DNA Doe Project.

The DNA matching process behind identifying Chimney Doe(Marcus Aarsvold)

”Everyone deserves to have their name in death,” DNA Doe Project Lab Logistics Director Kevin Lord said. “Often times this does help lead to some form of justice.”

Lord said the rootless hair from Kirk’s remains proved the most challenging part of trying to identify him. “It’s often too fragmented to use the traditional forensic methods that they use in crime labs,” he said. “It’s very degraded. It’s lots of very small DNA fragments.”

Lord’s team sent the hair to a lab in California where it was broken down into Kirk’s own unique DNA and then put together as a genetic sequence, then sent back to Lord who matched it online using databases GenMatch and Family Tree DNA.

”So the bio-informatics process essentially makes sense of of all of those small fragments of DNA,” he said. “So, it assembles them basically, into that persons genome. Then we look at the various spots or snips that we actually care about for the genealogy purposes and essentially pull those snips out of the whole genome data that we have. Then create a file that can then be uploaded.”

After more than 34 years, authorities have successfully identified Dane County Chimney Doe as Ronnie Joe Kirk, originally from Tulsa, Oklahoma. Kirk's last known ties were in Madison, Wisconsin. The identification was made possible through the collaborative efforts of law enforcement, forensic experts, and the DNA Doe Project, employing investigative genetic genealogy.(WMTV)

Madison Police Chief Shon Barnes said the process is crucial in helping investigators find out what happened to Kirk. He said it could lead to new clues as to how Kirk ended up inside of a 12-inch-wide chimney.

”People can come forward and say, ‘Hey, that was my family member. We last saw him or her on this time,’ Or what they may have been involved in,” Chief Barnes said. “It does help paint the picture for our detectives.”

Lord said the work is rewarding when it results in an identification like Kirk’s situation.

The DNA matching process behind identifying Chimney Doe(Marcus Aarsvold)

”By identifying the person, then that allows law enforcement also to work on their criminal investigation and also get justice for that person,” Lord said.

DNA Doe Project works on 25 to 50 cases across North America every year. According to Lord, they’ve helped identify 200 people since they started online genetic matching seven years ago.

articles.title: Fewer US overdose deaths were reported last year
articles.content:
NEW YORK (AP) — The number of U.S. fatal overdoses fell last year, according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data posted Wednesday.

Agency officials noted the data is provisional and could change after more analysis, but that they still expect a drop when the final counts are in. It would be only the second annual decline since the current national drug death epidemic began more than three decades ago.

Experts reacted cautiously. One described the decline as relatively small, and said it should be thought more as part of a leveling off than a decrease. Another noted that the last time a decline occurred — in 2018 — drug deaths shot up in the years that followed.

“Any decline is encouraging,” said Brandon Marshall, a Brown University researcher who studies overdose trends. “But I think it’s certainly premature to celebrate or to draw any large-scale conclusions about where we may be headed long-term with this crisis.”

It’s also too soon to know what spurred the decline, Marshall and other experts said. Explanations could include shifts in the drug supply, expansion of overdose prevention and addiction treatment, and the grim possibility that the epidemic has killed so many that now there are basically fewer people to kill.

CDC Chief Medical Officer Dr. Deb Houry called the dip “heartening news” and praised efforts to reduce the tally, but she noted “there are still families and friends losing their loved ones to drug overdoses at staggering numbers.”

About 107,500 people died of overdoses in the U.S. last year, including both American citizens and non-citizens who were in the country at the time they died, the CDC estimated. That’s down 3% from 2022, when there were an estimated 111,000 such deaths, the agency said.

The drug overdose epidemic, which has killed more than 1 million people since 1999, has had many ripple effects. For example, a study published last week in JAMA Psychiatry estimated that more than 321,000 U.S. children lost a parent to a fatal drug overdose from 2011 to 2021.

“These children need support,” and are at a higher risk of mental health and drug use disorders themselves, said Dr. Nora Volkow, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, which helped lead the study. “It’s not just a loss of a person. It’s also the implications that loss has for the family left behind.”

Prescription painkillers once drove the nation’s overdose epidemic, but they were supplanted years ago by heroin and more recently by illegal fentanyl. The dangerously powerful opioid was developed to treat intense pain from ailments like cancer but has increasingly been mixed with other drugs in the illicit drug supply.

For years, fentanyl was frequently injected, but increasingly it’s being smoked or mixed into counterfeit pills.

A study published last week found that law enforcement seizures of pills containing fentanyl are rising dramatically, jumping from 44 million in 2022 to more than 115 million last year.

It’s possible that the seizures indicate that the overall supply of fentanyl-laced pills is growing fast, not necessarily that police are whittling down the illicit drug supply, said one of the paper’s authors, Dr. Daniel Ciccarone of the University of California, San Francisco.

He noted that the decline in overdoses was not uniform. All but two of the states in the eastern half of the U.S. saw declines, but most western states saw increases. Alaska, Washington, and Oregon each saw 27% increases.

The reason? Many eastern states have been dealing with fentanyl for about a decade, while it’s reached western states more recently, Ciccarone said.

Nevertheless, some researchers say there are reasons to be optimistic. It’s possible that smoking fentanyl is not as lethal as injecting it, but scientists are still exploring that question.

Meanwhile, more money is becoming available to treat addiction and prevent overdoses, through government funding and also through legal settlements with drugmakers, wholesalers and pharmacies, Ciccarone noted.

“My hope is 2023 is the beginning of a turning point,” he said.

___

AP medical writer Carla K. Johnson contributed to this report.

___

articles.title: Child care costs more than a mortgage in 45 states
articles.content:
(CNN) – Child care costs continue to be a major financial burden for many parents.

According to Child Care Aware of America’s latest annual report, if you have two kids and live in one of 11 states or Washington, D.C., child care costs at least twice as much as rent.

Those states include: Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nebraska, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont and Wisconsin.

In every other state in the United States, placing two children in a child care center costs at least a quarter more than the average rent.

If you have a mortgage, the child care bill exceeds annual typical mortgage payments in 45 states, and Washington, D.C., according to Child Care Aware.

The report looked at care for an infant and a 4-year-old.

Nationwide, the average annual cost of care rose to nearly $11,600 per child last year.

articles.title: Criminal complaint released for Reindahl Park attempted homicide
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - A Madison man appeared in court in connection to a shooting at Reindahl Park on Sunday night.

Lamont Moses, 45, faces an attempted first-degree intentional homicide charge and was in court Tuesday afternoon.

His cash bond was set for $250,000. If paid, he cannot have any contact with the man he allegedly shot, he cannot go to Reindahl Park or possess any firearms.

According to the released criminal complaint, Moses and another man fought over a parking spot.

Moses allegedly parked in a spot that was previously occupied by a man and his acquaintance. The acquaintance was allegedly angered by the stolen parking space and Moses claims that he felt “disrespected.”

Moses says after the encounter he and the man had a cordial conversation that turned into an argument. In the complaint, it says two individuals rushed over to hold back the man. He allegedly broke free and charged at Moses with a gun.

The complaint says the man fired one round at Moses, narrowly missing his head. Moses said he “feared for his life” and returned fire at the man.

The man suffered several gunshot wounds with one still lodged in his body, according to the complaint. He was taken to a local hospital where he is now okay.

Investigators recovered Moses’ firearm at the scene but did not find the firearm the man allegedly fired at Moses. Law enforcement also found 19 shell casings, the complaint stated.

During Moses’ court hearing, Prosecuting Attorney Theresa Lewandowski said, “On the scene there was no physical evidence to support the victim was shooting.”

Attorney Charles Andrew Ver Hoeve says that Moses legally possessed his firearm and has a concealed carry permit.

“He was cooperative from the beginning to the end with law enforcement,” Ver Hoeve said. “He was the one that made a call to the police in regard to the shooting,” Attorney Ver Hoeve said.

If convicted, Moses could face up to 60 years in prison. His next court appearance is scheduled for May 21.

articles.title: Epic Systems bridge construction raises concerns among community members
articles.content:
VERONA, Wis. (WMTV) - Epic Systems is in the process of building a new four-lane bridge along their campus in Verona, and it has community members concerned.

The Wisconsin DNR held a public informational hearing regarding the construction Thursday evening at the town hall in Verona. The event aimed to provide community members with the opportunity to learn more about the proposed project.

However, some residents stated they were not aware of the project until a couple of days ago and are now worried about the wildlife living near the wetlands, specifically the area of Sugar River Valley.

“They’re putting a four-lane bridge across a pristine section of the Upper Sugar River, in a beautiful valley that is pretty much untouched,” said Caryl Owen, a director of the Verona Rural Preservation Alliance. “That’s got wildlife, has solitude, and is now going to be in the middle of a four-lane highway.”

According to Whitewater Policy Coordinator - State DNR Crystal Von Holdt, the project is currently in the public notice comment period. The Wisconsin DNR says the project is tentatively approved and has received an initial application.

The department is in the process of reviewing the application internally, which includes asking for more information regarding design updates before making a permit decision.

“The goal of our state wetlands requirements is to avoid wetlands first,” Von Holdt said. “When an applicant shows that they can’t avoid the wetland then the state requires that you minimize. So we’ve worked really hard with the consultant and the applicant to really evaluate what alternatives they have.”

The comment period ends on May 19. Statute provides staff 30 days to make an official decision.

articles.title: DeForest continues to grow with new residents and businesses

DEFOREST, Wis. (WMTV) - As more people move to DeForest, more businesses are building facilities in the growing village.

According to DeForest Village Administrator Bill Chang, his development team has approved over 500,000 square feet of construction space for new businesses to build over the last two years.

Chang said the draw to the village is that the area is quiet, calm and not too far from bigger cities like Madison.

Professional golfer Ryan Ranguette grew up in Waunakee near DeForest and said the area has change drastically over the last few years.

DeForest continues to grow with new residents and businesses(Marcus Aarsvold)

“Waunakee and DeForest are growing like crazy right now,” he said. “I think as you look at different opportunities within different markets, where the school districts are and what is driving new home owners to the area, we’re excited to be a part of that.”

Ranguette owns PinSeekers, a driving range and entertainment facility in DeForest built in 2023.

“We looked at a lot of different locations throughout the east side of Madison and ultimately ended up in DeForest,” he said. “Really with the vision of the village and what they were trying to do with a sports complex, we thought our golf and entertainment facility would fit really well into that.”

DeForest continues to grow with new residents and businesses(Marcus Aarsvold)

Chang said businesses like PinSeekers proves the village is a hot spot. “It seems like DeForest is kind of the place to be,” he said. “We hope to continue that.”

He said the influx of business is good but comes with challenges.

“Whenever you’re a growing community at a pace that we have, there are growing pains. You get residents that like to see DeForest the same as it’s always been,” Chang said. “We’re being mindful of the growth and wanting to be careful and wanting to be able to manage it and keep growing the good life here. We want to be the greatest community here in Dane County, the state of Wisconsin and so we’ll continue to strive that way.”

DeForest continues to grow with new residents and businesses(Marcus Aarsvold)

According to Chang, Kwik Trip will build its second campus in DeForest with plans to finish by the end of summer 2025.

articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - A 52-year-old Madison man was arrested for his third OWI on Monday after a three-vehicle crash on the city’s south side, Madison Police Department reports.

MPD says officers responded around 11:45 a.m. to the 1600 block of Beld St.

Police learned a truck crashed into another pickup which then hit another vehicle.

Marijuana and brass knuckles were also found inside the vehicle, police report.

The man is also facing charges for possession of marijuana with intent to deliver.

This incident remains under investigation.

articles.title: Woman allegedly kicks and injures officer following disturbance, says Madison Police
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - A woman allegedly kicked and injured an officer after a disturbance outside a tavern early Monday morning, says Madison Police.

At about 1:50 a.m., officers were dispatched to the 1500 block of Williamson Street on a report of a fight occurring outside a tavern. According to MPD, witnesses reported a Jeep backing into a motorcycle.

The jeep allegedly tried leave, which caused a disturbance. When a person inside the bar came outside and attempted to take a picture of the incident, a man inside the Jeep allegedly hit them.

A 24-year-old Madison man was arrested for battery and disorderly conduct.

A female passenger of the Jeep tried to stop the arrest and allegedly kicked and injured an officer who was taking her into custody. MPD says the officer sustained minor injuries.

A 26-year-old Madison woman was arrested for disorderly conduct, resisting or obstructing and battery to a law enforcement officer.

According to MPD, the driver of the jeep was arrested for their first OWI. The investigation remains ongoing.

articles.title: MPD: Man arrested for fourth OWI after telling police a friend stole his keys
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - The Madison Police Department says a man was arrested for his fourth OWI Monday night after allegedly reporting his friend stole his keys.

At about 7:50 p.m., officers responded to a convenience store along the 4700 block of Lien Road after a man reported a woman stole his keys. MPD says that once officers arrived on scene, the man was allegedly intoxicated.

The woman allegedly told police that the reason she took her friend’s keys was because of how intoxicated he was.

A 36-year-old Madison man was arrested for his fourth OWI and a probation violation. MPD says he was taken to the Dane County Jail.

articles.title: Suspect charged in Sun Prairie bank robbery
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - A suspect in the robbery of a Sun Prairie bank last month was charged on Monday, police confirmed.

The Sun Prairie Police Department explained that officers arrested Isaiah Freeman on April 29, the day of the robbery, on a probation hold. He was also a person of interest.

Court records show the 26-year-old was charged Monday in Dane County Court with robbery of a financial institution, and his bond was set at $10,000. Should he post bond, he would not be allowed to be at any bank, credit union or savings & loan company.

Old National Bank at 1516 W Main St. was robbed around 3:45 p.m. on April 29, the Sun Prairie Police Department reported.

An individual allegedly walked into the bank, demanded money from the staff and then ran away.

SPPD noted no one was hurt during the robbery.

articles.title: Gov. Evers orders special election for Mike Gallagher’s seat in Congress
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WBAY) - Gov. Tony Evers issued an executive order Tuesday for a special election for the 8th Congressional District.

The district, which includes Green Bay and much of Northeast Wisconsin, has been without a vote in the House of Representatives since Mike Gallagher resigned in April.

The special election will be held on November 5, coinciding with the general election when a new representative for the 8th District will be elected to a two-year term.

The winner of the special election would serve in Congress for less than two months, providing Northeast Wisconsin with a vote in the House until the next Congress is sworn in on January 3, 2025.

Because of the timing of Gallagher’s resignation, a special election couldn’t be held sooner.

Potential candidates can begin circulating nomination papers immediately and must submit them to the Wisconsin Elections Commission by 5 p.m. on June 1.

Action 2 News has reached out to the candidates in the 8th congressional race. We are awaiting replies from Andre Jacque, Kristin Lyerly and Tony Wied.

Republican Roger Roth confirmed he’ll run in both the special and general election. “I will be running to represent Northeast Wisconsin for the remainder of this term and for the full two-year term, while helping deliver Wisconsin for President Trump,” Roth said through a spokesman.

articles.title: Utilities start work on power line crossing in Mississippi River wildlife refuge
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (AP) — Utility companies have started construction on a contentious power line crossing in a Mississippi River wildlife refuge.

ITC Midwest and Dairyland Power Cooperative are looking to string the final mile (1.6 kilometers) of the Cardinal-Hickory Creek transmission line across the Upper Mississippi River National Wildlife and Fish Refuge near Cassville, Wisconsin. When finished, the 102-mile (164 kilometer) line will link Iowa’s Dubuqe County and Wisconsin’s Dane County.

A coalition of conservation groups sued in March to block the refuge crossing and won a preliminary injunction from U.S. District Judge William Conley. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals stayed the injunction on May 7, however, clearing the way for construction to begin. The utilities said in a joint statement that preliminary construction work began Monday with tower footings slated to be poured the week of May 27.

The conservationists have asked Conley to issue another preliminary injunction. Conley held a hearing on the request Tuesday but didn’t rule on it. He said he remains concerned about damage the line could cause to the refuge but the reality is the line will be completed and cause damage somewhere.

articles.title: Wisconsin GOP-led Senate votes to override nine Evers vetoes in mostly symbolic action
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (AP) — The Republican-controlled Wisconsin Senate voted Tuesday to override nine vetoes of Democratic Gov. Tony Evers in a mostly symbolic move that comes less than six months before the November election.

The overrides included bills combatting PFAS pollution, setting a population goal for gray wolves and requiring a new post-election audit.

But despite the Senate’s votes, all of Evers’ overrides are likely to stand.

To be successful, two-thirds of both the Senate and Assembly must vote to override a veto. Republicans have a two-thirds majority in the Senate, but they are short of that in the Assembly. There are no immediate plans for the Assembly to hold a vote and Republican leaders there did not return messages Tuesday.

Democratic Sen. Mark Spreitzer said lawmakers were “wasting time” on overrides that Republicans “know won’t be sustained.”

Even though the overrides appear ultimately to be doomed, the votes will give Republicans fodder for the campaign trail to use against Democrats.

One of the most contentious ongoing fights between Republicans and Evers was the focus of one override.

The Senate voted to override the veto of a bill that would have created grants to spend $125 million fighting pollution from “forever chemicals” known as PFAS.

Evers and Republicans have not been able to agree on the best way to combat pollution from PFAS, chemicals that have polluted groundwater in communities across the state. Evers and Republicans have both said that fighting the chemicals is a priority, but they haven’t been able to come together on what to do about it.

“We’ve done nothing on PFAS,” said Democratic Minority Leader Dianne Hesselbein. “Worse than nothing.”

She urged Republicans to “get the dollars out the door.”

Republican Sen. Mary Felzkowski accused Democrats of playing politics over PFAS funding.

“You’re playing with peoples lives, their investments and their families,” she said. “And it’s time to stop.”

Evers has repeatedly called on lawmakers to release the $125 million in funding approved last year in the state budget. But Republicans object to handing the money over to the state Department of Natural Resources and instead want to funnel it through the grant program created under the bill Evers vetoed.

Republican Sen. Eric Wimberger said doing what Evers wants would give the state DNR a “slush fund” that wouldn’t protect innocent landowners from lawsuits, fines and other harm.

The bill Evers vetoed called for spending the money on grants for municipalities, private landowners and waste disposal facilities to test for PFAS in water treatment plants and wells. Landowners with property that became contaminated through no fault of their own also would have been eligible for grants.

Evers said in his veto message that he objected to the bill because it would limit the DNR’s authority to hold polluters liable.

The Senate also voted to override the veto of a bill to make $15 million available for emergency hospital services in Chippewa or Eau Claire counties.

Similar to the fight over the PFAS funding, Evers and Republicans have not been able to agree on the best way to spend $15 million on health care in the wake of hospital closures in Eau Claire and Chippewa Falls. Evers signed a bill into law allowing for the spending, but the Legislature’s GOp-controlled budget committee has yet to approve it.

Among the eight other vetoes the Senate voted to override were bills that would require new post-election audits; set a new goal for the state’s gray wolf population; change the framework for teacher apprenticeship programs and require the transportation department to put the words “not valid for voting purposes” on identification cards of people who are not citizens.

Not a single Democrat voted for any of the overrides.

articles.title: Ceremonial football for 2025 NFL Draft begins Wisconsin journey
articles.content:
MILWAUKEE, Wis. (WBAY) - It’s an important, ceremonial day for Green Bay and the 2025 NFL Draft.

The ceremonial handoff football is beginning its journey in Wisconsin, leading to the 2025 NFL Draft countdown at Lambeau Field.

The handoff is like the passing of the torch, if you will, from Detroit to Green Bay. Detroit had an incredible turnout for this year’s draft with over 700,000 attendees. Green Bay is expecting 250,000 for draft events that will be more centrally located around the Titletown district

The Lake Express Ferry left Milwaukee Tuesday morning on a mission across Lake Michigan to pick up the special delivery in Muskegon, Mich. and returned shortly before noon. Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers walked off the ferry carrying the football one-handed, gleefully showing it to the small crowd that was waiting.

Gov. Tony Evers carries the ceremonial handoff football for the 2025 NFL Draft that made a ferry trip from Michigan to Wisconsin(WBAY)

The football begins its Wisconsin journey in a part of the state that has a lot of pro football history. Early NFL teams were located in Milwaukee, Racine and Kenosha, and in 1939 Milwaukee hosted the NFL Draft. The Packers even played a portion of their schedule in Milwaukee from 1933 to 1994.

That football needs to make its way to Lambeau Field and Titletown for another ceremony -- the unveiling of the NFL Draft countdown clock.

It’ll make its way north from Milwaukee not by car but by bike. The group carrying the football includes riders from the Green Bay Packers, Travel Wisconsin, Wisconsin Bike Fed, and Green Bay-area bicycle shops and cycling advocates. The Packers say the cyclists will pedal past a few landmarks along the way to highlight tourism and the state’s stunning trails and outdoor activities.

Packers Director of Public Affairs Ryan Popkey joked, “Remember this is a no-drop ride,” saying he didn’t want to get left behind.

Getting the football to Lambeau Field is taking most of the day. It’s expected to reach Titletown around 6:30 p.m.

As the football is carried on the final leg from the Ray Nitschke practice field to Lambeau Field, kids are invited to carry on a Packers tradition. Kids will bikes should be in place for the ride on Armed Forces Drive by 6 p.m.

The 2025 NFL Draft starts Thursday, April 24, in less than 345 days.

articles.title: Flags to be half-staff for Hmong-Lao Veterans Day in Wisconsin
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - An executive order was signed Monday ordering United States and Wisconsin State flags to be flown at half-staff on May 14 in honor of Hmong-Lao Veterans Day.

Governor Tony Evers signed Executive Order #224 and recognized Hmong-Lao veterans’ participation during the Vietnam War.

“Today and every day, we recognize their remarkable sacrifices, reflect upon the profound contributions they have made to our communities and our state, and express our gratitude for their commitment to upholding and defending the freedoms and values we hold dear,” said Gov. Evers.

According to officials, thousands of Hmong-Lao people fought alongside U.S. troops during the war. Following the end of their service, many faced harsh retribution from the Vietnamese and Lao governments for their participation.

Officials say many were forced to leave their homes and ended up settling within United States communities, including Wisconsin.

On May 14, 2021, Gov. Evers designated the date as Hmong-Lao Veterans Day within the state by signing the 2021 Wisconsin Act 31. This act requires the governor to issue an order annually that asks for flags at the State Capitol Building to be flown at half-staff.

The executive order states this will be in effect from sunrise to sunset on May 14.

articles.title: Man faces hit-and-run charge after crash on Madison’s southwest side
articles.content:
MADISON, Wis. (WMTV) - An allegedly impaired driver faces a hit-and-run charge after crashing into a retaining wall and a parked vehicle Friday night on Madison’s southwest side, police reported.

Madison Police Department reported the driver ran from the area of the 3100 block of Muir Field after he crashed. Officers responded around 7:20 p.m. to an apartment complex on Muir Field Road and noted multiple people saw the crash.

Police indicated the man was not in the apartment complex when they arrived. EMS was called for a man laying on the ground around 8 p.m. on Alabane Court, and MPD determined this man was the suspect involved in the crash.

Officers arrested the 34-year-old man, who faces charges of hit-and-run and first-offense operating a motor vehicle while impaired.

articles.title: Middleton mom advocates for affordable child care, fair educator wages
articles.content:
WAUNAKEE, Wis. (WMTV) - A Middleton mom has changed her work hours to raise awareness of the challenges faced in the child care industry.

Monday was “Day without Childcare” and Cora Holme reflected on how far her single parent household has come over the past five years.

“It was very difficult to find childcare,” Holme said. “We started way before TJ was even born and the prices were crazy back then.”

Holme says she affords childcare for her son at Arthouse Preschool through a scholarship.

“With that scholarship I was able to support myself and TJ as a single parent,” Holme said.

The owner of Arthouse says parents and child care providers need one another.

“Without us, parents cannot work, and they need a place to drop off their kids where they are not only learning but they know they are cared for so they can work successfully at their own jobs,” Heather Murray said.

Holme believes child care workers deserve better pay to support themselves and their own families.

“They are helping raise your children because that’s exactly what’s going on here with my son,” Holme said. “The education that he’s received has been, you know, a huge relief for me as a single parent.”

She knows her son receives the best care at Arthouse.

“A lot of people are not in the same boat, and they have to trust their well-being to their child to complete strangers,” Holme said.

She reminds parents they are not alone, and every family’s needs are different. Whether it’s staying at home with the children or sending them to a child care facility.

“Word of mouth is a lot of things,” Holme said. “That’s how we found out about Arthouse was from a friend, so like word of mouth is huge.”

Arthouse serves 30 kids and in January the tuition price for the preschool went up.

articles.title: Family seeks damages for boys who passed away in Sun Prairie retention pond
articles.content:
SUN PRAIRIE, Wis. (WMTV) - The family of the two boys who passed away earlier this year in a Sun Prairie retention pond are seeking damages from the city.

Officials responded around 3:20 p.m. Friday, Jan. 5, to a retention pond near S. Thompson Road, in Sun Prairie, after it was reported two children fell through the ice. Kiana Sims, mother of the two boys, said they had just gotten off their school bus at the Wildwood Apartments when 6-year-old Antwon Amos Jr. fell through the ice.

8-year-old Legend Sims had tried to save his little brother, but the two of them eventually passed away.

According to the family’s attorney, they have filed a notice for a claim. The City of Sun Prairie, Sun Prairie Fire, Police, the school district and the district board of education have six months to respond to the terms.

If an agreement is not reached, a lawsuit will be filed. The family seeks damages for the pain suffered, as well as for the medical and funeral expenses.
